questions.text: A 15-year-old boy came limping and sat down with his left knee flexed, complaining of pain, limitation of movement, stiffness, and swelling over the knee joint. His parents describe what is classical of 'night cries'. An X-ray taken is shown below.  A chest radiograph showed right upper lobe airspace disease with associated hilar adenopathy. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is tubercular arthritis.

The clinical vignette of a young patient between 10-25 years of age, presenting with pain, swelling, and stiffness, restriction of movement at the knee joint, typical 'night cries' along with right upper lobe airspace disease, hilar lymphadenopathy with the knee X-ray showing joint space destruction and marked periarticular rarefaction is suggestive of a case of tubercular arthritis.

The spread of infection of the bones and joints occurs through the bloodstream, referred to as tertiary spread, and begins locally as synovitis or osteomyelitis. As the synovial membrane and subchondral bone have a common blood supply, a simultaneous infection may be seen.

The patient presents with complaints of pain, swelling, fever and night sweats, loss of weight, and restricted joint movement. As articular erosion progresses, deformity of the joint becomes apparent. The patient begins limping and the knee is kept flexed. Discharging sinuses may be present.

During the night, subsequent to local muscle relaxation, there is stretching to compression of the affected tissues at night, leading to periods of intense pain called 'night cries'.

An X-ray shows the bone ends having a 'washed out' appearance with narrowing of joint space. Epiphyseal enlargement, soft-tissue swelling, and peri-articular osteoporosis are observed. In the later stages, there is subarticular bone erosion on both sides of the joint with an absence of periosteal reaction.

On further investigation, the Mantoux test or Heaf test will be positive and there is an elevated ESR. Synovial fluid appears cloudy on aspiration; a culture of this fluid or that of synovial biopsy specimen shows the growth of M.Tuberculosis.

Management involves both conservative and operative procedures. The affected knee is immobilized by below-knee skin traction and plaster of Paris cast above-knee. Antitubercular chemotherapy is started.

Operative procedures are:

  1. Synovectomy in cases of synovial tuberculosis
  2. Joint debridement when articular cartilage is preserved
  3. Arthrodesis

Other options:

Option A: Rheumatoid arthritis is the chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints. It occurs between the ages of 20 to 50 years and women are more commonly affected. The presence of four or more of the following is indicative of rheumatoid arthritis: Morning stiffness, swelling of three or more specified joints, swelling of joints in the hands and wrist, symmetrical swellings, rheumatoid nodule, rheumatoid factor positive, X-ray showing erosion or unequivocal peri-articular osteopenia.

Option B: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative disease primarily affecting the articular cartilage, which occurs in elderly people, mostly in weight-bearing joints of the lower limb such as the knee and hip when the disease is primary and is usually bilateral. Secondary osteoarthritis occurs due to an underlying disease of the joint such as avascular necrosis, coxa vara, and malunited fractures of the hip. It occurs at any age after adolescence and commonly affects the hip.

Option D: Psoriatic arthropathy presents as a polyarthritis, with the involvement of distal interphalangeal joints. It is also associated with the presence of psoriatic skin disease, nail disease characterized by onycholysis, pitting, splinter hemorrhages, and ocular disease in the form of uveitis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old Caucasian man had a fever, malaise, myalgia, and diarrhoea for 3-4 days. Following this, he developed tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension and was admitted to the emergency. He gave a history of rodent infestation in his apartment, and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary edema. Which of the following can be the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome caused by the Hanta virus.

Transmission of Hantavirus occurs by inhalation of the virus contained in dried excreta of rodents. Hantaviruses are natural pathogens of rodents like mice, rats, and voles. 

Patients may initially have symptoms like fatigue, fever, myalgia, and GI symptoms for 3-4 days. This may then progress to pulmonary edema. Tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension can develop in severe cases. This is known as Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome. 

Hantavirus infection can also present as hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS). 

Hantavirus is a bioterrorism category C agent. Hanta and Nipah viruses are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future because of availability, ease of production, dissemination, the potential for high morbidity and mortality rates, and major health impact.

Other options:

Option A: Legionella causes Pontiac fever and Legionnaire's disease. Legionnaire's disease presents with fever, non-productive cough, and dyspnea, which rapidly progresses to pneumonia if left untreated. Diarrhea and encephalopathy are also common. It is often included in the differential diagnosis of atypical pneumonia. Pontiac fever presents with a mild influenza-like illness. Infection is typically caused by inhalation of aerosols produced by cooling towers, air conditioners, and showerheads, which act as disseminators. No animal reservoirs exist, no human-to-human transmission occurs, and no carrier state is established.

Option C: Bunyavirus infection causes encephalitis, aseptic meningitis, and fever. Most bunyaviruses are mosquito-borne.

Option D: Leptospira can cause Weil's disease. A history of fever with liver (icterus) and kidney(hematuria) involvement should arouse suspicion of leptospirosis (Weil's disease). Hemorrhages (petechiae and purpura) can also be seen. Rats are the most important reservoir of leptospira.

Note- The family Bunyaviridae contains four medically important genera- Bunyavirus, Phlebovirus, Nairovirus, and Hantavirus. They are RNA viruses that are mostly arthropod-borne. Hantavirus is rodent-borne.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with cough and cold is brought to a primary health center for further evaluation and management. On examination, the child's respiratory rate is 45 breaths/ minute and there is no chest indrawing or grunting. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Cotrimoxazole two tablets twice a day
Ask the parents to return quickly if child's condition worsens

questions.solution:
The next best step in management is home-based treatment with amoxicillin.

The given clinical vignette of a two-year-old child with cough and cold with fast breathing (respiratory rate being 40 or more per minute in a child aged 12 months to 5 years) without chest indrawing and grunting is indicative of pneumonia, that is not severe. Since the child does not have any danger signs, the child can be given home-based treatment. Children above the age of 3 months without any danger signs can have home-based treatment. Amoxicillin 40-50 mg/kg/day is the preferred first-line drug.

The child should be admitted to the hospital if:

  • Age < 3months
  • Oxygen saturation (SpO2 ) < 92%
  • Marked tachypnea (e.g., 20 breath/min above the cutoff for that age)
  • Severe malnutrition
  • Severe dehydration
  • Intermittent apnea
  • Failure of OPD treatment

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the casualty with an injury to his leg. On examination, bruises and ecchymoses of varying ages are noted all over the body. The x-ray shows a spiral fracture of the femur. Which of the following is less likely to be seen in this condition?

choices.text: Head injury as the most common cause of death

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with a spiral fracture of the femur and bruises of various ages points to a diagnosis of battered baby syndrome, where evidence of strangling or stabbing is less likely to be seen.

A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian, there may also be deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection. The syndrome is also known as child abuse syndrome, non-accidental injury of childhood, Caffey's syndrome, and maltreatment syndrome in children.

The syndrome must be considered in any child:

  • In whom the degree and type of injury vary with the history given
  • When injuries are of different ages and in different stages of healing
  • When there is a purposeful delay in seeking medical attention despite serious injury
  • Who exhibits evidence of fracture of any bone, subdural hematoma, or skin bruising
  • Who dies suddenly

Classical features:

  • Multiple bruises, lacerations, and abrasions of varying ages and shapes all over the body
  • Round pitted burns from cigarette stubs
  • Tear of the frenulum resulting from efforts to silence a crying or screaming child
  • Infantile whiplash syndrome - subdural hematoma and intraocular bleeding as a result of shaking the child, as described by Caffey
  • Subgaleal hematoma
  • Traumatic alopecia, appearing as bald patches
  • Perforations and rupture of abdominal viscera
  • Retinal separation, vitreous, subconjunctival, and retinal haemorrhages and black eye

Skeletal injuries that are commonly seen:

  • Skull fractures
  • Large periosteal hematomas
  • Epiphyseal separation and periosteal shearing in the limbs
  • Transverse and spiral fractures of long bones - Due to compression, bending, and direct forcible blows
  • Fractures of ribs in the midaxillary line due to anteroposterior compression of the chest
  • Fractures at the costochondral junctions due to violent squeezing of the chest from side to side
  • Multiple rib fractures (called knobbing fractures) along the posterior angles of the ribs, in the paravertebral gutter, giving rise to the string-of-beads appearance on x-ray (Option B)

A skeletal survey, which includes the following, should be done in a case of suspected child abuse:

  • AP views of the entire skeleton
  • Dedicated views of hands and feet
  • Lateral views of the appendicular skeleton, skull, and spine

Head injury is the most common cause of death in battered baby syndrome (Option C), followed by rupture of an abdominal organ(Option D).

questions.text: An elderly patient came to you with lower abdominal pain and was unable to pass urine since the previous night. His wife says that he was prescribed a new medication for his depression which he has been taking for one week. Which of the following drug can be the one which caused the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms point to urinary retention. Among the given drugs, this is most likely due to imipramine which is a tricyclic antidepressant. 

Tricyclic antidepressants have anticholinergic (antimuscarinic) effects like urinary retention (especially in elderly males with an enlarged prostate), epigastric distress, dry mouth, constipation, blurred vision, and confusion. 

Tricyclic antidepressants are mainly used in depressive patients who are unresponsive to commonly used antidepressent such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRI).

Other options:

Option A- Trazodone is an atypical antidepressant with no antimuscarinic effects. It is known to cause priapsim.

Option B- Sertraline is an SSRI with no antimuscarinic effects. 

Option C- Venlafaxine is an SNRI with no antimuscarinic effects.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presented with progressive difficulty in hearing for the past 3 years. An MRI of the brain shows bilateral cerebellopontine angle tumors that are consistent with schwannomas. There is also a family history of gliomas and meningiomas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is neurofibromatosis type 2.

Neurofibromatosis type 2 refers to a syndrome characterized by bilateral schwannomas of the eighth cranial nerve, meningiomas, and gliomas. This is an autosomal dominant disorder caused due to a mutation in the NF2 gene.

The image below shows bilateral schwannomas seen in a patient with neurofibromatosis type 2.

Other options 

Option A: Neurofibromatosis type 1 presents with gliomas of the optic nerve, hamartomas, and pheochromocytomas. These patients have other features like intellectual disability, Lisch nodules (pigmented nodules of the iris), and cafe au lait spots (hyperpigmented macules on the skin).

Option C: Sturge-Weber syndrome presents with port-wine stain lesions of the skin in the area supplied by the trigeminal nerve. They might also have venous angiomas and intellectual disabilities.

Option D: Tuberous sclerosis presents with hamartomas and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas. Hamartomas appear as cortical tubers and subependymal nodules. This is associated with various cutaneous manifestations like angiofibromas, shagreen patches (localized leathery thickenings), ash-leaf patches (hypopigmented areas), and subungual fibromas.

Related Pearl: Chromosomal abnormalities and syndromes associated with brain tumors

Syndrome Gene defect Tumor

Neurofibromas,

malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, optic nerve gliomas,

hamartomatous lesions, pheochromocytomas.

 
Neurofibromatosis type 2 Schwannomin (chr 22q)

Bilateral eighth nerve schwannomas, multiple meningiomas,

ependymomas of the spinal cord

Dysplastic cerebellar gangliocytoma (Lhermitte-Duclos disease),

meningioma, astrocytoma

Hemangioblastomas, Retinal angiomas

Pituitary adenoma, malignant schwannomas

Gliomas, medulloblastomas

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method of direct transmission of communicable diseases?
questions.solution:
Airborne transmission by droplet nuclei is not a method of direct transmission of diseases.

It is a method of indirect transmission of diseases.

Droplet nuclei are tiny particles of size 1-5 microns range that may be formed by either due to evaporation of droplets coughed or sneezed into the air or are formed from aerosols.

These droplet nuclei remain airborne for long periods of time and can transmit diseases like tuberculosis, influenza, chickenpox, measles, Q fever and other respiratory infections.

Droplet transmission, vertical transmission, and contact with soil are methods of direct transmission of diseases.

Differences between droplet and droplet nuclei are summarised below:

DROPLET NUCLEI  DROPLET 
Indirect transmission Direct transmission
It is the residue from evaporated droplets It is produced while coughing, sneezing, talking
<5microns in diameter ≥5 microns in diameter
No need for close contact for transmission Requires closeness and direct contact for transmission
Diseases transmitted: chickenpox, measles etc. Diseases transmitted: diphtheria, meningococcal meningitis etc.

Related Pearl: Modes of Transmission of Communicable Diseases

Direct

Indirect

Direct contact

Droplet infection

Contact with soil

Inoculation into skin or mucosa

Vertical (transplacental)

Vehicle-borne

Vector borne – mechanical or biological

Air borne – droplet nuclei or dust

Fomite borne

Unclean hands and finger

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with a known case of sickle cell disease presented with sustained painful penile erection for the last 5 hours. Blood gas analysis from the penis shows hypoxia, hypercapnia, and acidosis. Aspiration of the sludge of blood and intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine failed to produce a response. What should be the next best line of management?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette in this patient is suggestive of ischemic priapism secondary to sickle cell disease and the next best line of management among the given options is to perform Quackel's shunt. It is a proximal shunt between corpora cavernosa and spongiosum. 

Priapism refers to a persistent erection lasting >4 hours, not related to sexual stimulation. There are two types of priapism:

  • Ischemic -more common
  • Non-ischemic

Ischaemic priapism occurs due to venous congestion, and consequent thrombosis. On examination, the penis is tender. Blood gas analysis of penile blood shows hypoxia, hypercapnia, and acidosis. Risk factors for priapism are sickle cell disease or trait, malignancy, medications, cocaine abuse, and total parenteral nutrition.

Detumescence should be ensured in 6-12 hours to avoid progressive, irreversible damage to the corpus cavernosal tissue with subsequent fibrosis and erectile dysfunction. Initial management can be done with oral agents like pseudoephedrine or baclofen.

  • First-line treatment- Aspiration of the sludged blood in the corpora cavernosa
    • By insertion of a large 18-gauge needle into the lateral aspect of one corporal body 
  • Intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine (an alpha-adrenoceptor agonist) is the next line of therapy.
  • Surgical shunts
    • Distal shunts like Winter shunt (in the emergency room), Al-Ghorab shunt (operative shunt)
    • Proximal shunts like Quackel shunt (proximal cavernosum-spongiosum), Grayhack (corporal-saphenous vein)

For those with sickle cell disease, hydration and oxygen administration should be performed first. 

Non-ischemic priapism usually occurs after blunt perineal trauma. A fistula develops between the central penile artery and the sinusoidal space, leading to a persistent, painless erection. Blood gas analysis shows characteristics of arterial blood. Treatment is not an emergency and is done by selective arterial embolization. (option D)

Other options:

Options A and B- Glansectomy and penectomy are generally performed for penile carcinoma.

questions.text: A young woman with atrial fibrillation is started on unfractionated heparin. After 6 days, she complains of reddening, swelling, and severe pain in her lower limbs. Her platelet count is 90,000/μL. Laboratory investigations reveal the presence of antibodies against heparin-platelet factor 4 complexes. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Discontinue unfractionated heparin and start warfarin
Discontinue unfractionated heparin and start lepirudin
Reduce the dose of unfractionated heparin and start with low molecular weight heparin

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis due to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. The next step in the management of this patient is to discontinue unfractionated heparin and start lepirudin.

Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) results due to the formation of antibodies against heparin-platelet 4 complexes. These antibodies also bind to the platelet Fc receptors and promote thrombosis. Features of HIT are usually seen after 5-10 days of starting heparin and are more common in females than in males. The platelet count usually drops to less than ≤100,000/μL or decreases to ≥50% compared to the levels before the initiation of heparin. The patients can also show the features of deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, acute myocardial infarction due to extensive formation of thrombi.

Stop heparin immediately and start with parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors, such as lepirudin, argatroban, or bivalirudin, or factor Xa inhibitors, such as fondaparinux or rivaroxaban. Do not give platelet transfusions. Warfarin is not given until the platelet count returns to its baseline level. Patients with HIT already have low levels of protein C. Giving warfarin to these patients without thrombin inhibitors further decreases its levels and causes skin necrosis. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) should also not be used to treat HIT patients because most HIT antibodies exhibit cross-reactivity with LMWH.

Heparin acts by activating antithrombin. The antithrombin inhibits thrombin and factor Xa. It can be given subcutaneously or by continuous intravenous infusion. Heparin therapy requires monitoring and can be monitored using the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) or anti-factor Xa level.

Important side effects of heparin are:

  • Bleeding- is the most common side effect. Recent surgery, trauma, concomitant use of antiplatelet or antifibrinolytic agents increases the risk. Serious bleeding due to heparin is treated using protamine sulfate.
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
  • Osteoporosis
  • Modest elevations of hepatic transaminases.

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

Fibrin non-specific plasminogen activators

  • Streptokinase - least fibrin specific and has the lowest incidence of intracranial hemorrhage

  • Tenecteplase - most fibrin specific and given as a single bolus dose

questions.text: A young man presented with a growing mass in the neck. It was found to be medullary thyroid carcinoma after workup. Further investigations revealed the presence of pheochromocytoma and parathyroid adenoma. He mentions that his uncle and his grandfather also had some form of cancer. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has medullary thyroid cancer, along with pheochromocytoma and parathyroid adenoma. He is likely to be suffering from multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2A.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia is characterized by the presence of tumors in two or more endocrine glands. It can be MEN 1, MEN 2A, MEN 2B (MEN 3), or MEN 4.

MEN 1 is associated mainly with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors. 

MEN 2A is associated mainly with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenoma. 

MEN 2B is associated mainly with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibers, and megacolon.

MEN 4 is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, and reproductive organ tumors.

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text:
An elderly man with leukemia came to you 3 days after his chemotherapy with complaints of weakness, flank pain, seizures, vomiting, and hematuria. His laboratory investigation is shown below. He is started on a drug that inhibits xanthine oxidase. Identify the drug that was given to this patient.
S. Uric acid:     9.0 mg/dL
S. Potassium:   6.0 mEq/L
S. Calcium:      6.0 mg/dL
S. Phosphorus: 7.0 mg/dL
S. Creatinine:   2.4 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the laboratory investigations are suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome. Among the given options the drug that inhibits xanthine oxidase (XO) is allopurinol. 

Allopurinol and its primary metabolite alloxanthine will inhibit xanthine oxidase which converts xanthine to uric acid. At low concentration, it inhibits XO competitively while at high concentration it inhibits non-competitively.

Oral therapy with allopurinol is effective for:

  • Primary and secondary gout
  • Hyperuricemia secondary to maliganacies
  • Calcium oxalate calculi

The aim of the therapy is to reduce serum uric acid to less than 6 mg/dL. The most common side effect with allopurinol is the hypersensitivity reactions that manifest after months of therapy. 

Tumor lysis syndrome is a condition that can occur spontaneously after the initiation of chemotherapy and is associated with certain metabolic disorders leading to end-organ damage. Metabolic disorders associated with tumor lysis syndrome are:

  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hyperuricemia

Tumor lysis syndrome is most commonly seen in patients with leukemia who have a very high white blood cell count. Signs and symptoms associated with tumor lysis syndrome can develop up to 72 hours after the initiation of chemotherapy. 

Patients with tumor lysis syndrome generally present with:

  • Abdominal pain and distension
  • Dysuria, oliguria, flank pain and hematuria
  • Anorexia, vomiting, cramps, seizures, spasms, altered mental status, and tetany due to hypocalcemia
  • Weakness, and paralysis due to hyperkalemia

Other options:

Option A: Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid by organic acid transporters

Option B: Rasburicase is a recombinant uricase. It lowers the urate levels

Option C: Pegloticase is a pegylated uricase. It catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid to allantoin which is a more soluble, inactive metabolite

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with pain in the foot after she tripped while walking on the road and twisted her ankle inwards. On examination, there is tenderness over the prominence at the base of the fifth metatarsal bone. The x-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this patient?

choices.text: Above-ankle cast and immobilization for 6 months
Conservative management with rest, followed by early mobilization

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the x-ray findings are indicative of a fracture involving metaphysis of the 5th metatarsal, which is known as a Jones fracture. The treatment of choice is conservative management with rest, followed by early mobilization.

Mechanism of injury: Forced inversion of the foot (pothole injury) may cause avulsion of the base of the fifth metatarsal, with pull-off by the peroneus brevis tendon or the lateral band of the plantar fascia. The peroneus brevis tendon and the lateral band of plantar fascia insert onto the base of the fifth metatarsal.

Proximal avulsion fractures can usually be treated symptomatically with initial rest for 6-8 weeks and support with a plaster cast, but with early mobilization and return to function. 

Note: A relative watershed area of blood supply is present in the fifth metatarsal at the junction between the diaphysis and metaphysis and is most susceptible to injury.

Other options:

  • Open reduction and internal fixation are usually done if the patient's functional demands and expectations with respect to sports and activities are high.
  • Above-ankle cast and immobilization for 6 months are not warranted for Jones fracture.
  • Immediate return to function can worsen the symptoms and would not be beneficial for the patient.

Other fractures that are seen around the base of the 5th metatarsal are shown in the image below:

questions.text: A woman presents with a history of recurrent abortions. A hysterosalpingogram is done and shown below. The intercornual angle mentioned in the report is 70 degrees, and the cleft depth is reported to be <1cm.  Ultrasound reveals an intercornual distance of less than 4 cm. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a history of recurrent abortion with the given hysterosalpingogram and intercornual angle of 70 degrees, a cleft depth of less than 1cm, and intercornual distance of less than 4 cm suggests a diagnosis of a septate uterus, for which transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum is the appropriate method of treatment.

The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of cesarean sections for future pregnancies, improving the outcomes.

The following table differentiates the septate and bicornuate uterus:

Study and parameter Septate Bicornuate
Hysterosalpingography(HSG) - cornua position Horns do not diverge Widely diverging horn
Intercornual angle - coronal plane (MRI/3D USG) <75 degrees >105 degrees
Intercornual distance <4 cm >4 cm
Fundal contour Convex, flat or minimally indented Fundal cleft >1 cm from the intercornual line
Intervening myometrium Thin (fibrous) Thick

Other options:

Jones' metroplasty, Strassmann's metroplasty, and Tompkins's metroplasty are surgeries that involve a transabdominal approach, which causes uterine scarring and is hence not preferred. Strassmann's metroplasty is a unification procedure for the bicornuate uterus.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female patient presented with complaints of poor vision, eye pain, photophobia, and watering from her right eye along with headache for the past one week. Examination reduced visual acuity with only light perception, a deep anterior chamber, and the finding as shown in the image. Intraocular pressure increased. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a patient with signs and symptoms of glaucoma (diminution of vision, eye pain, photophobia, watering, headache, corneal edema, mid-dilated pupils, raised intraocular pressure) occurring in association with a senile hyper mature Morgagnian cataract (as shown in the image). Presence of a deep anterior chamber points towards the diagnosis of secondary open-angle glaucoma - phacolytic glaucoma.

Phacolytic glaucoma is secondary open-angle glaucoma occurring in association with hyper mature morgagnian cataracts.

Trabecular obstruction is caused by high molecular-weight lens proteins that leak through the intact capsule in cases of the hyper mature cataract into the aqueous humour; macrophages containing lens proteins may also contribute to this.

Presentation:

  • Eye pain
  • Diminished vision
  • Photophobia
  • Lacrimation 
  • Headache
  • Increased intraocular pressure
  • Deep anterior chamber with fine white protein particles which may settle as pseudohypopyon
  • Open-angle seen on gonioscopy
  • Lens: Milky white cortex with sunken brownish nucleus (Morgagnian cataract)

Treatment:

  1. Medical therapy to lower the intraocular pressure
  2. Surgery to extract the lens.

Option A: 

Phacogenic (previously phacoanaphylactic) glaucoma is an autoimmune granulomatous reaction to lens proteins following exposure due to incomplete cataract extraction, trauma, or rarely capsular degeneration. The patient usually presents with a history of trauma or ocular surgery and a latent period following which the symptoms of glaucoma manifests. It is also a type of secondary open-angle glaucoma. 

Option B: 

Phacomorphic glaucoma is an acute secondary angle-closure glaucoma caused by an intumescent cataractous lens due to rapid maturation of cataract or following traumatic capsular rupture. The swollen lens obliterates the angle by forcing the root of the iris against the cornea. The patient presents with features of acute glaucoma with a shallow anterior chamber and a swollen cataractous lens.

Option D:

Phacotopic glaucoma is an acute secondary angle-closure glaucoma due to anterior subluxation or dislocation of the lens into the anterior chamber and spherophakia. Examination reveals a shallow anterior chamber.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of recurrent periods of prolonged sleep with intervening periods of normal sleep. She says that she sleeps up to 20 hours at a time, has a voracious appetite and increased libido. She has had these symptoms for the preceding five weeks and had a similar episode when she was aged 20. She does not have any pre-existing disorder, is not on any medication and menses are regular. The most likely diagnosis is:

choices.text: Hypersomnia due to drug or substance use

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Kline-Levin syndrome.

Kleine Levin syndrome is a disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of excessive sleep called hypersomnia along with cognitive and behavioural changes.

Affected individuals may sleep for up to 20 hours per day during an episode and these episodes usually last for a few days to a few weeks. An episode may start abruptly and during an episode, people with Kleine Levin syndrome can also display abnormal behaviour, such as excessive food intake, irritability, childishness, disorientation, hallucinations, and an abnormally uninhibited sex drive. Affected individuals are symptom-free between episodes.

The time between episodes varies. Kleine Levin syndrome primarily affects adolescent males, but it also affects females and individuals of other ages. The underlying cause of this condition is unknown. Episodes tend to decrease with advancing age. 

Other options:

Option A: Menstrual-related hypersomnia manifests as excessive daytime sleepiness beginning a few days before the onset of menses and stops shortly after menstruation begins. 

Option B: Idiopathic hypersomnia manifests as sleep that is prolonged, undisturbed and unrefreshing nocturnal sleep in addition to which there is difficulty in waking up, amnesia and dysfunction of the autonomic nervous system characterised by symptoms like migraine-like headaches, syncope and orthostatic hypotension. The age of onset is 15-30 years.

Option D: Hypersomnia due to drug or substance use is characterised by sleepiness that occurs due to abuse of drugs like sedative-hypnotics, opioid analgesics and sedating antihistamines.

questions.text: A 72-year old man presented with complaints of reduced vision in the right eye. Kinetic perimetry revealed right homonymous hemianopia. What is the most likely location of the defect in the optic pathway?
questions.solution:
The most likely defect in this patient presenting with right homonymous hemianopia is in the left optic tract. Homonymous hemianopia involves a loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes.

Other options:

Option A - A lesion affecting the optic chiasma produces heteronymous hemianopia. It involves loss of vision on the opposite sides of visual fields in both eyes. 

Options C and D - Lesions of the retina and optic nerve affect the visual field of only that eye. The visual field of the opposite eye is normal. 

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A cardiologist wants to study the effect of an anti-hypertensive drug. He notes down the initial systolic blood pressure of 50 patients and then administers the drug to them. After a week of treatment, he measures the blood pressure again. What is the most appropriate statistical test to be chosen to compare the change in blood pressure?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, a paired t-test (before and after) would be used. As the effect of a drug to change the blood pressure is measured on the same sample, making it a dependent sample.

T tests are performed when experimental subjects are divided into two different groups. One group is treated with one intervention and the other group with a different intervention. 

Other options:

Option B: Unpaired t-test or a student t-test or independent t-test is used when the two groups under comparison are independent of each other.

Option C: ANOVA or analysis of variance is a test used to compare and analyse the difference between the means of more than two groups.

Option D: Chi-square Test is a method of testing the significance of the difference between two proportions. 

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman is being evaluated for post-menopausal bleeding. Her family history is significant for ovarian and colonic cancers. The pedigree chart plotted is shown below. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an endometrial thickness of 16 mm, and a provisional diagnosis of endometrial hyperplasia is established. Which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is defective in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a woman with endometrial hyperplasia and an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance of hereditary cancer syndromes (colonic and ovarian) narrows down the diagnosis to Lynch syndrome. It is characterized by defective mismatch repair.

Lynch syndrome, also known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is an autosomal dominant genetic condition that is associated with a high risk of colon cancer as well as other cancers, including endometrial cancer (second most common).

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

This syndrome is due to defects in DNA mismatch repair genes, with MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2.

HNPCC shows familial clustering of cancers at several sites, including the colorectum, endometrium, stomach, ovary, ureters, brain, small bowel, hepatobiliary tract, pancreas, and skin.

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

DNA damage repair type

Diseases

Defective Nonhomologous End Joining Repair (NHEJ)

Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID)

Radiation sensitive severe combined immunodeficiency disease(RS-SCID)

Defective Homologous Repair (HR)

AT-like disorder (ATLD)

Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS)

Bloom syndrome (BS)

Werner syndrome (WS)

Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS)

Breast cancer suspectibility 1 and 2 (BRCA1, BRCA2)

Defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP)

Cockayne syndrome (CS)

Trichothiodystrophy (TTD)

Defective DNA Base Excision Repair (BER)

MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP)

Defective DNA Mismatch Repair (MMR)

Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

Related Pearl: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

  • Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two
  • At least two successive generations affected
  • At least one case diagnosed before the age of 50 years
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded.
  • Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

All of the above must be applicable for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC to be made in a family.

 

 

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient presents with hearing loss and tinnitus for the last several years. The hearing loss has been worsening while the tinnitus is pulsatile. Otoscopy reveals the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with progressive hearing loss, pulsatile tinnitus for several weeks, and a red mass behind an intact tympanic membrane are suggestive of glomus tumor. 

Glomus tumors are the most common benign tumors of the middle ear. The tumors comprise paraganglionic cells and arise from glomus bodies which resemble carotid bodies. Glomus bodies are present in the dome of the jugular bulb and on the promontory along the course of the tympanic branch of the IXth cranial nerve. 

It follows the rule of 10s - 10% are familial, 10% are multicentric, and 10% are functional (secrete catecholamines). 

The presentation of glomus tumors is as follows:

  • Intratympanic presentation
    • Progressive hearing loss
    • Pulsatile tinnitus is synchronous with pulse and can be stopped by carotid pressure
    • Otoscopy: red reflex through the intact tympanic membrane
    • Rising sign when tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear
    • Pulsation or brown sign: when the ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel's speculum the tumor pulsates and blanches, this reverses when pressure is released
  • Polyp presentation
    • Profuse bleeding
    • Otorrhea if there is a secondary infection
    • Red vascular polyp filling the meatus that bleeds easily
  • Cranial nerve palsies
    • Dysphagia and hoarseness with unilateral paralysis of the soft palate, pharynx due to IX and X
    • Vocal cord paralysis due to X
    • Weakness of the trapezius and sternomastoid muscles XI
    • Atrophy of half of the tongue XII
  • Audible bruit over the mastoid

They can be diagnosed by CT scan, MRI, four-vessel angiography, brain perfusion and flow studies, embolization, and biopsy. 

It is treated by surgery, radiation, embolization, or a combination of them. 

The otoscopic image given below shows rising sun sign seen as seen the glomus tumor.

Other options:

Option A: Cholesteatomas are abnormal collections of keratinized squamous epithelium, usually in the middle ear and mastoid. A retraction pocket in the posterosuperior quadrant of the tympanic membrane is a hallmark feature.

Option B: Otitis media is an infection of the middle ear. It presents with otalgia and fever. It is associated with a bulging, red, opaque, and immobile tympanic membrane.

Option D: Meniere's disease is a disorder of the inner ear that is characterized by vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. There is no abnormality on otoscopy.

Related Pearl: Signs in Glomus Tumors

Sign
Seen on
What is seen
Rising sun
Otoscopy
Tumor arising from floor
Brown sign
Otoscopy
On increasing the ear canal pressure, tumor pulsates and then blanches
Phelp sign
CT
Loss of carotico-jugular crest

questions.text: During a murder trial, the suspect is accused of placing one lathi stick across the back of the victim's neck and another across the front. They then tied both ends of the lathi sticks with a rope and squeezed the victim to death. What is this type of strangulation called?
questions.solution:
The type of strangulation described in the above clinical scenario is Bansdola. 

In Bansdola, one strong bamboo or stick is placed across the back of the neck and another across the front. The victim is squeezed to death by tieing both ends of the stick with rope.

On examination, a bruise can be seen in the center of the neck across the windpipe corresponding to the width of the stick or the substance used. A similar mark can be seen on the back of the neck if two sticks are used. 

Sometimes two sticks are used across the back and front of the upper part of the chest and squeezed forcibly. This causes laceration of the muscles, rib fractures, and interferes with respiration. 

Other options:

Option A- Mugging is a type of strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the crook of the elbow. Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm. In mugging, the attack is usually made from behind.

The below image show strangulation by mugging.

Option B- Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown around the unaware victim’s neck and then tightened by twisting it with a lever such as a rod or stick within the ligature. Earlier in Spain, garrotting was an official method of judicial execution.

An image of the execution of a prisoner by garrotting is shown below.

Option D- Burking is a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter throws the victim to the ground and kneels or sits on the chest of the victim preventing the chest movements. He/she then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his/her hands. 

Below is the image showing burking.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for brain death, except:
questions.solution:
All the options are criteria for brain death, except absent deep tendon reflexes. Deep tendon reflexes/ spinal cord reflexes may be present in brain death as the spinal cord function below C1 is intact. 

Clinical criteria for brain death:

  • Coma- Deep, unresponsiveness to noxious stimuli
  • Absent motor activity- No decerebrate or decorticate posturing
  • Absence of brainstem reflexes- Pupillary, oculocephalic, corneal, gag reflex, etc.
  • Apnea- Absence of spontaneous respiration at  arterial pCO2 tension of at least 50–60 mmHg

Confirmatory test findings (not mandatory but may assist in diagnosis)

  • Isoelectric electroencephalogram
  • Absence of somatosensory evoked potentials and brainstem evoked potentials 
  • Absence of cerebral perfusion, as documented by angiographic, transcranial Doppler, or radioisotopic studies

questions.text: A woman presented to the emergency department one hour after the spillage of hot coffee on her hands. On examination, the following finding was seen on her right hand. The injuries were extremely painful when touched. The capillary refilling time and pinprick sensations were normal. Which degree of burns would this fall under?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of a second-degree superficial burn. The points that favor the diagnosis are the presence of blisters, tenderness over the injured skin, normal capillary refilling time, and normal pinprick sensations. The epidermis and papillary dermis (the upper part of the dermis) are involved in this case. These burns will heal without scarring in 2 weeks.

According to the depth and the extent of tissue damage, burn injuries can be classified as follows:

  • First-degree burns: In this, there is damage to the epidermis. These injuries are extremely painful but do not blister. They have a normal capillary refilling time.
  • Second-degree burns (Partial-thickness burns): In this, there is damage to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the extent of the dermal involvement, they can further be divided into superficial or deep.
    • Superficial: Involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis (papillary). These injuries are red, moist, and extremely painful and blisters are present. The capillary return is clearly visible when the injured skin is blanched. Sensations are normal. They heal without scarring.
    • Deep: Involve the epidermis and the deeper dermis. These injuries are less painful and sensation is reduced. The capillaries do not blanch on pressure. They can lead to hypertrophic scarring.
  • Third-degree burns:  In this degree, there is damage to the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue. The injuries have a hard leathery feel with the absence of sensation.
  • Fourth-degree burns: In this degree, there is damage to the underlying soft tissues as well.

Related Pearl: Wallace's rule of 9

questions.text: An elderly man suffered a  disc prolapse while lifting a heavy box, leading to nerve injury. This resulted in the development of lower limb muscle weakness. Which of the following features would be associated with this type of muscle weakness?
questions.solution:
Lumbar disc prolapse/ spondylolisthesis will result in a lower motor neuron type of muscle weakness in the distribution of the involved nerve root. Lower motor neuron weakness is associated with fasciculations in the affected muscles.

Lower motor neuron weakness (LMN)  refers to muscle weakness due to injury to either brain stem motor nuclei, anterior horn cells of the spinal cord, or peripheral motor neuron axons. When the motor unit is damaged, it can result in spontaneous firing of the nerve, leading to fasciculations in the muscles supplied by it. This presents as a muscle twitch that can be seen or palpated. LMN disease is also associated with flaccid paralysis and decreased muscle tone. There can also be significant wasting and atrophy of the muscles involved along with hyporeflexia. 

In contrast to this, upper motor neuron disease (UMN) will show spastic paralysis, hyperactive reflexes, and no signs of fasciculation. They may show some disuse atrophy over time, but this is not as significant as that seen in lower motor neuron disease.

Lumbar disc prolapse can result in damage to lumbar nerve roots. Since these arise from the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord, the muscle weakness involved will be an LMN type of weakness and will show the above-mentioned symptoms and signs.

Other options-

Option (A): Muscle hypertrophy will not be seen in any type of motor neuron injury. Significant atrophy can be seen in LMN lesions, while disuse atrophy over time can be seen with UMN lesions.

Option (C): Spasticity is seen in UMN lesions. It presents as an increase in muscle tone.

Option (D): Hyperreflexia is a feature of UMN nerve injury. There may be an acute decrease in reflexes, but this is normally followed by hyperreflexia. LMN lesions on the other hand will present with depressed reflexes.

Related Pearl: Features of Motor Neuron Lesions

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion

Upper motor neuron typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons

Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles

Little or no muscle wasting → weakness of relatively large group of muscles

Muscle atrophy → muscle weakness of an individual and specific muscle

Hypertonia

Hypotonia

Increased or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (hyperreflexia)

Hyporeflexia or areflexia

Spasticity

Flaccidity

Positive Babinski sign (abnormal plantar extensor reflex)

Fasciculations

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2. He says that he does not prefer injections. He had 1 episode of pancreatitis 3 years back and has a history of colon cancer in his family. He also has been diagnosed with heart failure and has been taking medications. Which of the following drugs can be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Glimepiride can be given to this patient. It belongs to the class called sulfonylureas.

Sulfonylureas act by closing the ATP-sensitive K channels in the beta-cells of the pancreas. This closure causes cell membrane depolarization and the release of insulin. They are readily absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and therefore can be given orally. Important sulfonylureas are glimepiride, glipizide, glyburide, etc.

Important adverse effects are hypoglycemia, vomiting, cholestatic jaundice, agranulocytosis, and aplastic and hemolytic anemias. They can also cause a disulfiram-like reaction. They should be used with caution in pregnancy, lactation, and significant hepatic or renal insufficiency (for the older forms).

Other options

Option A- Pioglitazone belongs to a class of thiazolidinediones. It activates the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPARγ) and increases insulin sensitivity. Apart from weight gain, it also causes edema and fluid retention. It increases the plasma volume and is therefore unsuitable for heart failure patients.

Option B- Exenatide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist. It stimulates insulin secretion, inhibits glucagon release, delays gastric emptying, reduces food intake, and normalizes fasting and postprandial insulin secretion. It is given subcutaneously. It can also cause pancreatitis, and therefore is not used in patients with a history or risk of developing pancreatitis.

Option D- Teduglutide is a glucagon-like peptide-2 (GLP-2) analog. It enhances the growth of intestinal mucosa. It is used in the treatment of short bowel syndrome and not diabetes mellitus. It is administered parenterally and discontinued in patients with active gastrointestinal malignancy.

questions.text: The principal site of absorption of Na + is_____

choices.text: Thick ascending limb of Loop of Henle

questions.solution:
The principal site of absorption of Na + is PCT. About 60-65% of filtered sodium is reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), coupled with the movement of H+, glucose, amino acids, organic acids, phosphate, and other electrolytes and substances.

% of filtered Na reabsorbed Part of nephron Main transporter involved
60 PCT Na+ –H+ exchanger
30 Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle Na+ –2Cl-–K cotransporter
7 DCT Na–Cl cotransporter
3 Collecting ducts ENaC channels (regulated by aldosterone to permit homeostatic adjustments)

All segments of nephron are involved in sodium reabsorption except thin descending loop of Henle.

questions.text: Which of the following is the leading cause of under-5 mortality in India?
questions.solution:
The leading cause of death under the age of 5 years in India is preterm birth complications. It constituted about 27.9% of all deaths among children under 5 years of age in India, in 2016.

Under-5 mortality is the number of deaths under the age of 5 years per 1000 live births. It measures the probability of dying between birth and exactly 5 years of age. UNICEF considers this as the best single indicator of social development and well-being as it reflects income, nutrition, health care, and basic education. 

On average, boys are expected to have a higher probability of dying before reaching age 5 years than girls. It is also higher in poorer households, rural areas, and children of uneducated mothers. 

Important causes of death among children under 5 years in India are:

  • Preterm birth-related complications  
  • Pneumonia
  • Diarrheal diseases
  • Other non-communicable diseases
  • Birth asphyxia & birth trauma

questions.text: Match the following mammogram images with their diagnoses.

choices.text: 1- Duct ectasia  2- Malignancy  3- Traumatic fat necrosis   4- Fibroadenoma
1- Traumatic fat necrosis   2- Fibroadenoma  3- Malignancy  4-Duct ectasia
1- Fibroadenoma   2- Traumatic fat necrosis   3- Duct ectasia   4- Malignancy
1- Malignancy  2- Duct ectasia  3- Fibroadenoma   4-Traumatic fat necrosis

questions.solution:
The correct match is:

1- Traumatic fat necrosis 
2- Fibroadenoma 
3- Malignancy
4- Duct ectasia

Egg-shell calcification or lead pipe calcification is seen in traumatic fat necrosis. Usually seen with a  previous history of surgery or trauma. There are egg-shell calcifications in the wall of an oil cyst or as coarse dystrophic calcifications with scarring. 


Popcorn calcification is seen in fibroadenoma. These are the most common benign masses of the breast. On mammograms, they present as rounded or oval masses with coarse calcifications (popcorn calcifications) as shown in the image below.


Breast malignancies appear as ill-defined spiculated masses with microcalcifications as shown in the image below.


Duct ectasias present with broken needle calcifications. This occurs due to the calcification of debris within dilated ducts. Most of the time, these are bilateral.

questions.text: Which of the following antihistaminics has a low propensity to block potassium channels and does not prolong QT interval?
questions.solution:
Among the given drugs, fexofenadine has a low propensity to block delayed potassium channels and does not prolong QT interval. Drugs that block potassium channels and prolongs QT increases arrhythmogenic potential. 

Other options:

Option A- Diphenhydramine is a first-generation antihistamine. It inhibits the potassium channel and causes QT prolongation.

Option B- Ebastine is a second-generation antihistamine and it prolongs QT interval. 

Option C- Astemizole is a second-generation antihistamine that block delayed potassium channels and prolong QT interval. 

Related Pearl: Etiology of Torsade De Pointes

Acquired prolongation of QT interval

Electrolyte abnormalities

  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypocalcemia

Drugs

  • Antiarrhythmic drugs
    • Class IA: Quinidine, disopyramide, procainamide
    • Class III: Sotalol, amiodarone (QT prolongation common but torsade ventricular tachycardia is rare), ibutilide, dofetilide, almokalant
  • Antibiotics
    • Macrolides: Erythromycin, clarithromycin, azithromycin
    • Fluoroquinolones: Levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, gatifloxacin
    • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
    • Clindamycin
    • Pentamidine
    • Chloroquine
    • Antifungals: Ketoconazole, itraconazole
    • Antivirals
    • Antipsychotics
    • Antihistamines

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulliparous woman presented with mild dyspareunia. Examination revealed a non-tender, mobile, fluctuant swelling on the vaginal wall. Ultrasound examination revealed a single cyst of size approximately 2 cm, independent from the bowel and bladder. The cyst arises from the part in the image labeled as A. Structure A is a remnant of what?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a case of a Gartner's duct cyst, which develops from the Gartner's duct (marked as A), a remnant of the mesonephric duct (Wolffian duct). 

The remnants of Wolffian ducts (Gartner's duct) in females are located in the broad ligament and vagina. It is an imperfect duct that runs below and parallel to the fallopian tube in the mesosalpinx. The duct passes downwards by the side of the uterus until the internal os, after which it passes into the cervix. It then runs forwards, reaching the anterolateral part of the vaginal wall.

Gartner's duct cysts are located in the vagina or broad ligament. They are usually asymptomatic and found within the lateral vaginal wall during a routine examination. Symptoms if present, might include dyspareunia, pain, and difficulty inserting tampons. Examination reveals a tense cyst, seen bulging from beneath the vaginal wall.

Differentials include epidermoid cysts, Bartholin's gland cyst, uterine prolapse, cystocele, rectocele, urethral diverticula.

Treatment is observation in most cases. Marsupialization or excision may be done if large and symptomatic.

questions.text: A patient with vomiting and abdominal pain reports to the hospital following consumption of food at a fast-food restaurant two days back. On examination, he has yellowish discoloration of the sclera. Hepatitis A virus particles are present in the feces. Identify the true statement about this condition.

choices.text: 1% sodium hypochlorite is an effective disinfectant for reservoirs
Sexual route is the major route of transmission

questions.solution:
The true statement about this condition is that it causes mild illness in children. The clinical vignette is indicative of a case of Hepatitis A. It is a viral infection that can be transmitted by the fecal-oral route, which is the commonest, parenteral route, and also by sexual transmission

The incubation period is between 10 to 50 days (usually 14-28 days). The onset of jaundice is preceded by gastrointestinal symptoms like nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and mild fever. Jaundice may appear within a few days of the prodromal period, but anicteric hepatitis is more common. 98 % of cases with Hepatitis A resolves completely but relapse of symptoms is noted in 3-20 % of cases.

Laboratory diagnosis of hepatitis A can be obtained by

  • Demonstration of HAV particles or specific viral antigens in the feces, bile, and blood.
  • Anti-HAV appears in the lgM fraction during the acute phase, peaking about 2 weeks after the elevation of liver enzymes. ELISA is the method of choice for measuring HAV antibodies.

Prevention and containment involves control of reservoir by use of 0.5 % sodium hypochlorite has been strongly recommended as an effective disinfectant, control of transmission by personal and community hygiene

Two types of hepatitis A vaccines are currently used, formaldehyde-inactivated vaccines and live attenuated vaccines.

The complete vaccination schedule consists of 2 dose administration into the deltoid muscle. The interval between the first (primary) dose and second (booster) dose is commonly 6-12 months. Following 2 doses of vaccine, the protective efficacy is about 94%.

questions.text: Which of the following chromatography techniques is correctly matched with its property used for separation?

choices.text: Hydrophobic interaction chromatography - selectivity for ligands
Ion exchange chromatography -  interactions with hydrophobic groups

questions.solution:
Gel filtration chromatography, also known as size exclusion chromatography separates proteins on the basis of their Stokes radii. Stokes radius is a measure of the effective volume a protein occupies in a free solution. It accounts for both the mass and the shape of the protein. 

The correctly matched chromatography techniques are:

  • Hydrophobic interaction chromatography - Interactions with hydrophobic groups
  • Gel filtration chromatography - Stokes radii
  • Ion exchange chromatography - Charge-charge interactions
  • Affinity chromatography - Selectivity for ligands 

Types of Chromatography:

1. Gel filtration chromatography: Proteins with large and small stokes radii are applied to the top of a gel filtration column. On entering the column, the small proteins enter pores in the stationary phase matrix (included proteins). During the mobile phase flowing down the column, they lag behind the large molecules, which get excluded (excluded proteins). Proteins thus emerge from a gel filtration column in descending order of their Stokes radii.

 

 2. Ion exchange chromatography: Proteins interact with the stationary phase by charge-charge interactions. Proteins with a net positive charge at a given pH will tightly adhere to negatively charged beads called cation exchangers. Proteins with a net negative charge will adhere to positively charged beads called anion exchangers. Nonadherent proteins flow through the matrix and are washed away.

Bound proteins are then selectively displaced by weakening charge-charge interactions. This is done by gradually raising the ionic strength of the mobile phase. It is shown in the image below.

3. Affinity chromatography is based on the high selectivity displayed by most proteins for their ligands. Enzymes are purified using immobilized substrates, products, coenzymes, or inhibitors. In theory, only proteins that interact with the immobilized ligand adhere. Bound proteins are then eluted either by competition with a free, soluble ligand or by disrupting protein-ligand interactions. It is shown in the image below.

4. Hydrophobic interaction chromatography separates proteins based on their tendency to associate with a stationary phase matrix coated with hydrophobic groups. Proteins with exposed hydrophobic surfaces adhere to the matrix via hydrophobic bonds that are enhanced by employing a mobile phase of high ionic strength. 

Related Pearl: Types of Chromatography

Chromatography types Property used for separation
Paper chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Thin layer chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Ion exchange chromatography Based on charge – charge interaction
Size exclusion chromatography Based on descending order of Stokes radius which is a function of molecular mass and shape
Affinity chromatography Based on specific ligand binding behaviour
Hydrophobic interaction chromatography Based on hydrophobic interaction

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents in her third month of pregnancy for an antenatal visit. Identify the correct dosage and duration of supplements to be taken according to the 'Anemia Mukt Bharat' scheme of the Government of India.

choices.text: 45 mg elemental iron + 400 μg folic acid, 6th month of pregnancy till 6 months after delivery
60 mg elemental iron + 500 μg folic acid, 4th month of pregnancy till 6 months after delivery
100 mg elemental iron + 500 μg folic acid, 6th month of pregnancy till 6 months after delivery
45 mg elemental iron + 400 μg folic acid, 4th month of pregnancy till 6 months after delivery

questions.solution:
The Anemia Mukt Bharat guideline recommends 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 μg of folic acid daily at least for 180 days, starting from the 4th month of pregnancy and continued throughout pregnancy. Ideally, this must also be followed for 180 days postpartum.

This patient should also be made aware of the color of the tablet which is red. This would help ensure she takes the correct tablet and does not end up taking a pink IFA tablet which is given for Children 5-9 years of age and contains only 45 mg elemental Iron + 400 mcg Folic Acid.

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Area marked A is Broca's area (area 44, 45) and is present in the inferior frontal gyrus
Area marked B is the visual association area (area 17, 18) and is present around the calcarine sulcus
Area marked C is the motor association area (area 5, 6) and is found in the superior parietal lobule
Area marked D is the frontal eye field (area 8) and is found in the middle frontal gyrus

questions.solution:
Area marked D is the frontal eye field (area 8) and is located in the posterior part of the middle frontal gyrus. It controls voluntary scanning movements of the eye. It is connected to the visual part of the occipital cortex through association fibres.

Lesions of the frontal eye field of one hemisphere cause the two eyes to deviate to the side of the lesion and an inability to turn the eyes to the opposite side. 

Other options:

Option A: The area marked A is Wernicke's area (area 22) and is present in the inferior parietal lobule of the dominant hemisphere and extends along the posterior aspect of the superior temporal gyrus. It is the sensory speech area. Lesions here cause sensory aphasia. 

Broca's or the Motor speech area (areas 44, 45) is present in the pars triangularis and pars opercularis in the inferior frontal gyrus. Lesions here cause motor aphasia. 

Option B: Area marked B is the visual association area (areas 18, and 19) and is present surrounding the striate area. It controls the correlation of visual impulses with memory, recognition of objects seen, and depth perception. Lesions here produce visual agnosia. 

Area 17 is the primary visual cortex or the visuosensory area, present around the post-calcarine sulcus. It is associated with the reception and perception of isolated visual impressions of colour, size form, motion, illumination, and transparency. Lesions here produce homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. 

Option C: The area marked C is the sensory association area (areas 5 and 7) and is found between the sensory and visual areas in the superior parietal lobule. It is responsible for stereognosis and sensory speech. Lesion here causes astereognosis and sensory aphasia.

*There is uncertainty about the extent of the Wernicke's area. Some authorities consider areas 39 and 40 as part of Wernicke's area in addition to area 22.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought with concerns of having ingested a foreign body. X-ray confirms the presence of a coin in the esophagus. The child is asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable. Which of the following is the appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Observe for 24 hours; if the foreign body is not passed in feces, then perform endoscopy.
Perform urgent endoscopy and removal of the foreign body.
Make the child eat bananas, and wait for passage of foreign body in stool.
Provide plenty of fluids orally for safe passage of the foreign body.

questions.solution:
Asymptomatic blunt objects and coins lodged in the esophagus can be observed for up to 24 hours in anticipation of passage into the stomach.

Urgent endoscopic removal is preferred for sharp objects, button batteries in the esophagus, and foreign bodies associated with respiratory symptoms.

Button batteries are very dangerous foreign bodies and must be expediently removed because they can cause

  • Mucosal injury in 1-hour contact time
  • Involve all layers of the esophagus in 4 hours

After suspecting a foreign body in either the trachea or esophagus, plain x-rays of the chest, neck, and abdomen are obtained. Anteroposterior and lateral views are helpful in localizing the objects.

A swallowed coin stuck in the esophagus will appear flat on the anteroposterior view, while the edge will be visible in the lateral view. In the case of coins in the trachea, the findings will be opposite- flat in the lateral view and edge in anteroposterior view. This is because of the difference in dimensions of the trachea and esophagus. 

A button can be differentiated from a coin based on the double-halo and step-off that can be seen in anteroposterior and lateral views.

questions.text: The hyperpigmentation associated with Addison's disease is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
The hyperpigmentation associated with Addison's disease is due to increased serum levels of POMC (pro-opiomelanocortin).

Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency in which the adrenal is unable to secrete adequate amounts of cortisol (glucocorticoid), aldosterone (mineralocorticoid), and sex hormones. The most common cause of Addison's disease is autoimmune adrenalitis. 

Inadequate adrenal hormone secretion will result in positive feedback to the pituitary, leading to increased ACTH (adrenocorticotropic releasing hormone) secretion. ACTH happens to be derived from a precursor compound known as POMC (pro-opiomelanocortin). POMC breaks down to form ACTH and MSH (melanocyte-stimulating hormone). This MSH is responsible for the hyperpigmentation of sun-exposed areas seen in Addison's disease.

The clinical features of Addison’s disease include:

Hormone

Clinical features
Hypoaldosteronism

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, salt craving
Dizziness, postural hypotension
AKI due to volume depletion
Hyponatremia
Hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis
Hypocortisolism Anorexia, weight loss, fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia
Fever (increased IL-1)
Depression
Postural hypotension
Hypoglycemia
Hyponatremia (loss of feedback inhibition of ADH)
Slightly increased TSH (loss of feedback inhibition)
Hypoandrogenism Loss of libido
  Loss of pubic and axillary hair
Elevated ACTH Hyperpigmentation

 

The image below shows a woman before (right) and after (left) developing Addison's disease. You can see how she has lost weight, become anorexic, and developed hyperpigmentation of the sun-exposed skin-

 

The diagnosis of primary adrenal insufficiency can be made with the short cosyntropin test. Elevated ACTH levels help to differentiate it from secondary causes, which would show low ACTH levels. Primary adrenal insufficiency will also have a compensatory elevation in renin levels due to decreased aldosterone in the body.

Treatment is with a combination of glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and sex hormone replacement depending on the patient's symptoms and requirement.

Other options-

Option (B): GnRH has no relation to ACTH or MSH production.

Option (C): Cortisol levels will be low in Addison's disease. This is the cause for feedback elevation in ACTH, not the cause for hyperpigmentation.

Option (D): Aldosterone does not cause hyperpigmentation. Similar to option (C), the low aldosterone causes feedback elevation in the ACTH levels.

Related Pearl: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Anatomical destruction of gland
  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)
  • Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)
  • Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi
  • Surgical removal
  • Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)
  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic agents – mitotane
  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole
  • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)
  • X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

  • Neoplasm
  • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
  • Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

  • By endogenous steroids from tumor
  • By exogenous steroids

Related Pearl: Basal Metabolic Rate
