questions.text: A patient who is a known asthmatic on low-dose inhalational corticosteroids comes to the OPD with complaints of acute exacerbations. On this visit, theophylline is added to his treatment regimen and shows better symptom control. He returns after a few days with complaints of nausea, headache, gastric discomfort, and excessive micturition. Which of his side effects is not due to phosphodiesterase-4  inhibition?
questions.solution:
The diuretic effect of theophylline is due to the blockade of adenosine (A1) receptors. All the other symptoms are caused by the inhibition of PDE4.

Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug that acts by:

  • Inhibition of phosphodiesterase enzyme (PDE). PDE3 inhibition causes relaxation of bronchial smooth muscle and PDE4 inhibition causes inhibition of the release of cytokines and chemokines which further leads to a decrease in immune cell migration and activation.
  • Blockade of adenosine receptors, which inhibits bronchoconstriction. However, blockade of A1 receptors in the glomerular afferent arteriole and PCT causes diuresis.
  • Activating enzyme histone deacetylase-2, which is responsible for its anti-inflammatory action

Adverse effects of theophylline are usually related to plasma concentration ( >15 mg/L). The most common side effects are headache, nausea, and vomiting, abdominal discomfort (due to inhibition of PDE4), and restlessness.

At high concentrations, cardiac arrhythmias may occur due to inhibition of cardiac PDE3 and antagonism of cardiac A1 receptors. At very high concentrations, seizures may occur due to central A1 receptor antagonism.

A targeted plasma concentration of 5-10mg/L is maintained to avoid adverse effects and drug interactions.

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • D: Digoxin
  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants
  • M: Methotrexate
  • C: Calcineurin inhibitors

questions.text: Identify the acid-fast stained organism shown in the below microbiology spotter?
questions.solution:
The image showing filamentous, branching acid-fast rods is suggestive of Nocardia.

Acid-fast bacteria are those that retain carbolfuchsin even after decolorization with hydrochloric acid in alcohol. They appear red, while non acidfast organisms take on the color of the counterstain.

Nocardia appears as filamentous organisms with extensive hyphae-like branching. They are gram-positive, catalase-positive, and produce urease. They have aerial filament fragments that break into coccobacillary cells.

They are weakly acid-fast because they stain with carbolfuchsin (routine acid-fast stain) and retain when decolorized with 1-4% sulfuric acid instead of the stronger acid-alcohol decolorant.

They cause nocardiosis, which is an opportunistic infection. The main clinical presentation is pulmonary nocardiosis with cough, shortness of breath, fever, cough, and weight loss. Inhalation is the primary route of bacterial exposure.

Other options:

Option B: Actinomyces are gram-positive filamentous non-acid-fast anaerobic organisms. The below image shows gram-positive filaments of Actinomyces.

Option C: Mycobacteria are non-branching, acid-fast bacilli. These findings are consistent with the staining characteristics of mycobacteria. The stain used is the Ziehl-Neelsen stain. 

The image below shows mycobacteria with a Ziehl-Neelsen stain.

Option D: Isospora Belli with modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain shows a large pink-colored acid-fast oocyst as shown below.

The procedure of Ziehl-Neelsen acid-fast stain:

  • Fix smear using heat
  • Cover with carbolfuchsin. Stain for 5 minutes over direct flame. Do not permit slides to boil or dry out.
  • Rinse with deionized water
  • Decolorize in 3.0% acid–alcohol (95% ethanol and 3% hydrochloric acid) until only a faint pink color remains
  • Rinse with water
  • Counterstain for 1 minute with Loffler’s methylene blue stain
  • Rinse with deionized water and let dry

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: You are a resident doctor in the anesthesia department. A 40-year-old obese male had come for pre-operative assessment for thyroid surgery. He is a known case of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) for the past 12 years on irregular treatment. He smokes cigarettes daily. Which of the following is not a risk factor for postoperative pulmonary complications in this patient?
questions.solution:
The age of this patient (40 years) is not a risk factor for the development of postoperative pulmonary complications.

Risk factors for postoperative pulmonary complications:

  • Potential patient-related risk factors: 
    • Advanced age
    • ASA-PS class 2 or more
    • Functionally dependent
    • Weight loss
    • Congestive heart failure
    • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
    • Impaired sensorium
    • Cigarette, alcohol use
    • Abnormal findings on chest examination
  • Potential procedure-related risk factors:
    • Aortic aneurysm repair
    • Thoracic surgery
    • Abdominal surgery
    • Neurosurgery
    • Head and neck surgery
    • Emergency surgery
    • Vascular surgery
    • General anesthesia
    • Perioperative transfusion
  • Potential laboratory test risk factor
    • Albumin concentration <35 g/L
    • Chest radiograph abnormalities
    • BUN concentration > 7.5 mmol/L (>21 mg/dL)

questions.text: Breathing systems use soda lime to absorb expired carbon dioxide during anesthesia. When the carbon dioxide absorption capacity of soda lime is exhausted, it changes color from white to purple. Which of the following is likely to have been used as an indicator in this soda-lime?
questions.solution:
As the color of soda-lime changes from white to purple, the indicator used is likely to be ethyl violet.

Breathing systems function by delivering oxygen and anesthetic gases to the patient and removing carbon dioxide. This can be done by washout with adequate gas flow or by using carbon dioxide absorbant media like soda lime. 

Ethyl violet has a critical pH of 10.3. It is added to soda-lime to assess the integrity of the absorbent. As CO2 is absorbed, the pH reduces below 10.3 resulting in the purple color, indicating that the absorptive capacity of the material has been consumed. 

Color change when different indicators are used 

Indicator Color when fresh Color when exhausted
Ethyl violet White Purple
Phenolphthalein White Pink
Mimosa 2 Red White
Clayton yellow Red Yellow
Ethyl orange Orange Yellow

The pH indicator changes color as a result of increasing hydrogen ion concentration and absorbent exhaustion. The absorbent should be replaced when 50-70% of color has been changed. If rested exhausted granules may revert to their original color but, no significant recovery of absorptive capacity occurs.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest as seen in the image. Wood's lamp examination shows pale yellow fluorescence. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows sharply demarcated hypopigmented macules coalescing into patches over the trunk and lesions showing a pale yellow fluorescence under Wood's lamp examination are pointing to a likely diagnosis of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor. 

Pityriasis versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales. Mechanism of hypopigmentation in P. versicolor: azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species. The site most commonly affected is the upper trunk, but there is often spread to the upper arms, neck, and abdomen (seborrheic areas). The term versicolor refers to the different colors of the scales from a pale ochre to medium brown.

Tinea versicolor is usually caused by the lipophilic fungi Malassezia globosa and possibly Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur. The characteristic appearance on KOH mount and microscopy has been likened to ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ or ‘bananas and grapes’. Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail): When the fine scales are not visible, an important diagnostic clue may be the loosening of barely perceptible scale with a fingernail, which is called as the scratch sign. Relapse is very common. 

Patients are treated with topical azoles or 1% terbinafine cream twice daily for 2 to 3 weeks or ketoconazole shampoo twice weekly for the same duration.

The image below shows hypopigmented macules and patches of Pityriasis versicolor-

 

Other options-

Option (A): Segmental vitiligo- Vitiligo is a common form of localized depigmentation. It is an acquired condition resulting from the progressive loss of melanocytes. It is characterized by milky‐white sharply demarcated macules which occur unilaterally in segmental type. (image given below). Wood's lamp examination shows ivory or milky white fluorescence. The presence of a family history of vitiligo, the Koebner phenomenon, leukotrichia, or associated autoimmune disorders such as thyroid disease can help to support a clinical diagnosis of vitiligo.

 

Option (C): Tinea corporis is a ringworm of the glabrous skin. It is caused by dermatophytes - Trichophyton rubrum, Epidermophyton floccosum, Microspora, etc. Characteristic lesions are circular, usually sharply marginated with a raised edge. Scaling and central resolution are also common. (image below)

 

Option (D): Nevus anemicus is a congenital vascular anomaly that presents clinically as a hypopigmented macule or patch. The lesional pallor is due to a localized hypersensitivity to catecholamines with resultant vasoconstriction. Hence, the pallor completely disappears under Wood’s light and the diascopy of adjacent skin reveals an identical color to that of the ‘depigmented’ area. Clinically, nevus anemicus is a circumscribed, rounded, oval, or linear pale macule or patch with irregular margins that may be surrounded by satellite macules. (image given below). Lesions typically are asymptomatic.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding central precocious puberty?

choices.text: Delayed closure of epiphyses leads to increased overall growth
Secondary sexual characteristics appear in females <8 years of age
Secondary sexual characteristics appear in males <9 years of age
Testicular volume >4mL before the age of 9 years in males

questions.solution:
In central precocious puberty, there will be an early closure of epiphyses, leading to decreased overall growth. Hence option (A) is incorrect. 

Precocious puberty refers to the appearance of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years in females and before the age of 9 years in males. Although there can be differences based on ethnic backgrounds, these are the standard ages accepted when making a clinical diagnosis. In females, it is defined as the early development of breasts, while in males it involves an early enlargement of the testes with a volume >4mL.

Central precocious puberty results from the early activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis. This results in early stimulation of the primary sex organs by higher than normal levels of sex hormones. The result is an early enlargement of breasts in females and an early increase in testicular volume in males.

The HGP axis stimulation results in rapid increases in height and weight but also causes the epiphyses of long bones to close early, resulting in stunted growth overall. The earlier the onset of puberty, the more stunted the growth will be. If left untreated, most of these people will achieve a height less than the 5th percentile.

Emotional and psychological development is usually normal, and the mental age usually corresponds with the chronological age.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument shown below?

choices.text: If used early reduces cardiac output
It is to be removed 48 hours after birth
Delayed clamping should be avoided in Rh- pregnancy
Increases iron stores in the baby

questions.solution:
The given image shows an umbilical cord clamp. It should be kept in place until it falls off with the detached stump of the umbilical cord.

It is made of plastic and supplied in a sterile pack. It occludes the umbilical vessels effectively. In preterm infants, delayed clamping may improve transitional circulation, establish better red blood cell volume, reduce the need for blood transfusion and reduce the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis and intraventricular haemorrhage. It should be delayed by 30-60 seconds after birth.

Other options:

Option A: If performed early reduces cardiac output owing to reduced preload to the left ventricle whereas if performed late permits sufficient aeration of the lung and improved / smoother transitioning to a better cardiac output.

Option C: Early cord clamping is advised in Rh-negative pregnancy, babies with asphyxia, or infants of diabetic mothers. Early clamping can also reduce the need for phototherapy due to hyperbilirubinemia. 

Option D: Delayed umbilical cord clamping in term infants will increase haemoglobin levels at birth and improve iron stores for the first few months. This may have a favourable effect on developmental outcomes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening pain, redness in the right eye for the last two days. She has a history of sarcoidosis. On examination, the right eye is inflamed around the cornea, the pupil is constricted, and reacts sluggishly to light. The iris appears muddy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with progressively worsening eye pain and redness, constricted pupil reacting sluggishly to light, muddy iris, and a history of sarcoidosis is likely to have anterior uveitis. 

Sarcoidosis is a systemic inflammatory disorder characterized by the formation of non-caseating granulomas. Anterior uveitis is often a presenting symptom of sarcoidosis.

Anterior uveitis presents with blurred vision, pain, photophobia, circumcorneal conjunctival injection (around the limbus) with an aqueous flare and keratin precipitates. The pupil is constricted and reacts sluggishly to light. The clear pattern of the iris is lost and it appears muddy.

Slit-lamp examination shows the following signs in anterior uveitis:

Corneal signs: 

  • Keratic precipitates

Anterior chamber signs: 

  • Hypopyon
  • Aqueous cells
  • Aqueous flare
  • Deep and irregular anterior chamber due to posterior synechiae

Iris signs: 

  • Loss of normal pattern
  • Change in color "muddy iris"
  • Posterior synechiae

Pupillary signs: 

  • Constricted pupil
  • Irregular pupil shape
  • Ectropion of uveal pigment
  • Occlusion pupillae - blocked pupil due to extensive exudate

Steroids and cycloplegics are the mainstay of management for uveitis.

Cycloplegics

  • atropine
  • Relieves spasm of iris sphincter and ciliary muscle
  • Prevents the formation of synechiae

Steroids reduce inflammation by their anti-inflammatory effect 

Systemic therapy 

  • Steroids
  • NSAIDs
  • Immunosuppressants
    • Used in severe cases

Other options:

Option A: Acute bacterial conjunctivitis presents with pain, irritation, photophobia with hyperemia (pink eye), and purulent exudate. There is a diffuse conjunctival injection which is less seen in the circum-corneal region (as opposed to anterior uveitis)

Option C: Endophthalmitis is the infection of the intra-ocular cavities which presents with severe pain, loss of vision, and lid edema. It is usually seen in post-operative cases of ocular trauma (exogenous) and patients hospitalized with severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections (endogenous).

Option D: Acute primary angle-closure glaucoma presents with severe unilateral eye pain, associated with headache and loss of vision. The examination shows a red congested eye, corneal edema with a shallow anterior chamber, and a mid-dilated pupil.

questions.text: A middle-aged man is posted for an open cholecystectomy. He has a medical history of hypercholesterolemia. The pre-anesthetic evaluation revealed abnormal liver function tests and mild hepatomegaly. Which of the following muscle relaxants can be safely used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Atracurium can be safely used in this patient with liver disease because of non-hepatic metabolism.

Atracurium and cis-atracurium undergo plasma ester hydrolysis and Hofmann elimination at physiological pH and temperature. Hofmann elimination is a spontaneous, non-enzymatic, chemical degradation. So, the clearance of atracurium and cis-atracurium is independent of liver or kidney function. Hence, they are the agents of choice in patients with liver disease and/or renal failure.

The metabolites of atracurium and cis-atracurium are monoquaternary acrylate and laudanosine.

Some of the adverse effects of atracurium are hypotension, tachycardia, and allergic reactions (bronchospasm) due to a dose-dependent histamine release. On the other hand, these adverse effects are not seen with cis-atracurium and so it is preferred over the former.

Pancuronium, rocuronium, and vecuronium are dependent on the liver for excretion.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

questions.text: A 38-year-old laborer presents to the district hospital with gradually progressive spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. It began as an abnormal gait with short jerky steps, and soon, he was dependent on crutches. His younger brother has developed a similar gait. They have been consuming an inexpensive dal that resembles red gram for the past 2 years. Which of the following compounds is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of neurolathyrism and beta-oxalyl amino-alanine (BOAA) is the toxic compound causing lathyrism.

It is due to the consumption of khesari dal (Lathyrus sativus). It has a characteristic triangular shape and grey color. When the husk is removed, it looks similar to red gram dal or Bengal gram dal.

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals.

In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system. It is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. In animals, it is referred to as osteolathyrism/odoratism because the pathological changes in the bones lead to skeletal deformities.

It usually affects young males aged 15-45 years, and it is manifested in stages: 

  • Latent stage
  • No-stick stage
  • One-stick stage
  • Two-stick stage
  • Crawler stage

BOAA is the toxic compound causing lathyrism. The water-soluble property of the toxin is used in removing it from the pulses by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soaked water. Although it is considered irreversible, vitamin C in doses of 500–1000 mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism.

The Prevention of Food Adulteration Act in India has banned Lathyrus sativus in all forms (whole/ split/ flour).

Disease   Food Substance/
Contaminant 		 Toxic Principle 
Neurolathyrism Lathyrus sativus/ Khesari dal  BOAA 
Epidemic
dropsy 		 Argemone oil  Sanguinarine 
Ergotism Bajra, wheat, sorghum, and rye get infested by ergot fungus Claviceps purpurea Ergot alkaloids
Endemic
ascites 		 Crotalaria/
Jhunjhunia 		 Pyrrolizidine alkaloids

questions.text: A woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency room with severe nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.  She has a fruity odor of breath and is hyperglycemic.  Urine Rothera's test is positive. Which of the following tissues cannot utilize the non-carbohydrate metabolic byproduct increased in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with a positive Rothera's test is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. The non-carbohydrate metabolic byproduct increased here is ketone bodies and the liver cannot utilize ketone bodies.

Type I diabetes mellitus is a low insulin state. There is an increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA which in turn leads to increased ketone body production. The presence of ketosis can be established by the detection of ketone bodies in urine by Rothera's test.

The ketone bodies synthesized in the liver mitochondria are transported in the blood to the peripheral tissues, where they are utilized by the following steps:

  • β-hydroxybutyrate is oxidized to acetoacetate by β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase producing NADH.
  • Acetoacetate is then activated to acetoacetyl CoA by transferring a CoA molecule from succinyl CoA by succinyl CoA-acetoacetate CoA transferase (thiophorase).
  • Acetoacetyl CoA is cleaved into two acetyl CoA molecules by thiolase and oxidized into CO2 by the TCA cycle.

Ketone bodies are utilized by extrahepatic tissue like the cardiac muscle and renal cortex (prefer the ketone bodies to glucose as fuel). Tissues like skeletal muscle and the brain can also utilize the ketone bodies as alternate sources of energy if glucose is not available.

RBCs cannot utilize ketone bodies as they lack mitochondria. The liver cannot utilize ketone bodies as it lacks the enzyme thiophorase.

Rothera's test:

  • Saturate 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulfate.
  • Add 3 drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside
  • Add 2 mL of liquor ammonia along the sides of the test tube.

Development of a purple ring at the junction of the two liquids (shown in the image below) indicates the presence of acetone or acetoacetic acid in urine. It is not answered by beta hydroxy butyrate. 

Related Pearl: Ketone body utilisation

1. 3-Hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase

2. CoA Transferase

3. Thiolase

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presented with cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis for a few days. He gives a history of consumption of undercooked crabs in the recent past. An adult egg-shaped worm was demonstrated from his sputum as shown below.  Which of the following parasite is implicated here?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image showing a reddish-brown egg-shaped adult worm are suggestive of Paragonimus westermani.

Paragonimus westermani is a trematode and is also known as oriental lung fluke. Adult worms live in the lungs as pairs in cystic spaces that communicate with bronchi. Their lifespan is up to 20 years in humans.

Man is a definitive host. The first intermediate host is a freshwater snail while the second intermediate hosts are freshwater crabs and crayfishes.  

The infective form is metacercariae encysted in crab and crayfish. Consumption of undercooked crabs and crayfishes containing metacercaria is the mode of infection. Patients usually present with cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. Sputum is bloody or rusty and contains eggs.

Inflammatory reactions to the worms and eggs result in peribronchial granulomatous lesions. Definitive diagnosis is by the demonstration of eggs in sputum or feces. Occasionally, the adult worm may also be detected in the sputum. Chest X-ray shows nodular, cystic, ring, infiltrative shadows in the middle and lower lobe. 

Praziquantel 25 mg/kg thrice a day for 1-2 days is the drug of choice. 

The below image shows the lifecycle of Paragonimus westermani.

Other options:

Option A- Clonorchis Sinensis is also known as Chinese liver fluke or oriental liver fluke. Adult worms have flat, transparent, spatulate bodies and they live in the biliary tract and pancreatic duct. Metacercaria larvae are the infective form and man acquires infection by consumption of undercooked fish carrying metacercaria larvae. Initially patients present with fever, epigastric pain, diarrhea, tender hepatomegaly which is followed by biliary colic and jaundice. Chronic infection results in calculus formation and is associated with cholangiocarcinoma. 

Option C- Fasciolopsis buski is also known as a giant intestinal fluke. They are the largest trematode infecting humans. Adult worms are large fleshy worms that live in the duodenum or jejunum. Encysted metacercaria on aquatic vegetation is the infective form. Initial symptoms are diarrhea and abdominal pain followed by partial bowel obstruction, protein-losing enteropathy, and impaired vitamin B-12 absorption. Demonstration of the egg in the feces aids in the diagnosis.

Option D- Metagonimus yokogawai is also an intestinal fluke. Definitive hosts like humans are infected by eating raw fish containing metacercariae. Infection with these trematodes causes mucus diarrhea, ectopic lesions in the myocardium, and central nervous system.

questions.text: Deriving sexual gratification using living or non-living objects is termed as
questions.solution:
Deriving sexual gratification using living or non-living objects is termed fetichism. 

An abnormal stimulus or object of sexual desire is called a fetish. Using such objects for sexual gratification is called fetichism. Examples of such objects are underclothing, stocking, shoes, etc. Fetichism is almost exclusively seen in males and it is harmless.

Other options:

Options B and C- Scoptophilia or voyeurism is a condition in which a person experiences recurrent, intense, sexual urges on observing a stranger who is in a process of disrobing or engaging in sexual activity. 

Option D- Frotteurism is a condition in which one person gets sexual satisfaction by rubbing his private parts against another person in crowds.

questions.text: A patient was brought in with a history of consumption of acid. His last meal was a few hours ago. After resuscitation, the team performs all necessary treatments but the patient, unfortunately, succumbs to death. If you were to perform the autopsy and resect the stomach, which of the following images would indicate the most likely area of injury to the gastric mucosa?
questions.solution:
The most likely area of injury to the gastric mucosa is denoted by image B.

The pathway that fluids (acid, alkali, water) take in a food-filled stomach is known as Magenstrasse. It is present along the lesser curvature of the stomach, and this is where the greatest damage to gastric mucosa takes place in corrosive injury. 

In an empty stomach, the maximum injury occurs to the lower half to two-thirds of the body, with sparing of the fundus. 

Magenstrasse refers to the pathway acidic agents follow in the stomach, a groove in the stomach along the lesser curvature that is the route food and liquids tend to take in moving toward the pylorus and that is a frequent site of peptic ulcer formation.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman comes for her antenatal check-up. She is in her third trimester now. She is a daily wage worker and reveals that she will continue working during the pregnancy. How much protein would you advise her to consume on a daily basis (RDA)?

RDA: Recommended dietary allowance
questions.solution:
The recommended dietary allowance of protein for a pregnant woman in the third trimester who is a heavy worker is 68 g/day.

According to the national institute of nutrition, the recommended RDA of protein is 46 g per day, regardless of the type of occupation and activity of the woman.

During pregnancy, the RDA of protein is increased in the second and third trimesters:

  • In the second trimester, it increases by 9.5 g. Therefore, the total protein requirement is 46+9.5 = 55.5 g/day per day.
  • In the third trimester, it increases by 22 g. Therefore, the total protein requirement is 46+22 = 68 g of protein per day.

questions.text: An elderly man with hepatocellular carcinoma is scheduled to undergo a left hepatectomy. Which of the following Couinaud's liver segments will be removed during this procedure?
questions.solution:
The surgical term left hepatectomy corresponds to the removal of Couinaud segments 2, 3, and 4.

The Couinaud classification is a system used to categorize the liver into two primary functional lobes: the left and right lobes. The lobes are further divided into eight functional segments, based on hepatic portal venous branches. Each of these segments is supported by a biliary triad comprising branches from the hepatic artery, portal vein, and bile duct. 

The given image shows Couinauds segments corresponding to various procedures:

Other options:

Option A - Segments 6, 7 correspond to right posterior sectionectomy.

Option B - Segments 5, 6, 7, 8 corresponds to right hepatectomy or right hemihepatectomy.

Option C - Segments 2, 3 corresponds to left lateral sectionectomy.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: A pharmacologist is conducting a study on non-microsomal phase 2 reactions involved in drug metabolism. His experiments are not likely to include which of the following conjugation reactions?
questions.solution:
All of the above conjugation reactions are catalyzed by non-microsomal enzymes except glucuronide conjugation.

Glucuronide conjugation is the only phase II metabolic reaction that is carried out by microsomal enzymes. 

Drug metabolizing enzymes are primarily of two types:

  1. Microsomal enzymes are located in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum in the liver, kidney, intestinal mucosa, and lungs. They include the cytochrome P450 system, monooxygenases, etc. These enzymes can be induced by drugs and certain nutrients. These enzymes are involved in oxidation, reduction, hydrolysis, and glucuronide conjugation reactions.
  2. Non-microsomal enzymes are located in the cytoplasm and mitochondria of hepatic cells, plasma and other tissues. They include esterases, amidases and most conjugases. These enzymes catalyze all conjugation reactions except glucuronidation. Phase II reactions carried out by non-microsomal enzymes are:
  • Glycine conjugation
  • Glutathione conjugation
  • Sulfate conjugation
  • Methylation
  • Acetylation

Related Pearl: Phases of drug metabolism

Phase I reactions: They attach functional groups to the drugs. This usually leads to the inactivation of the drug. 

Examples:

  • Oxidation
  • Reduction
  • Hydrolysis
  • Cyclisation
  • Deamination

Phase II reactions: They attach conjugates to the drugs. This facilitates drug elimination from the tissue. 

Examples:

  • Glucuronide conjugation
  • Sulfate conjugation
  • Glycine conjugation
  • Glutathione conjugation
  • Acetylation
  • Methylation

All phase II reactions are mainly conducted by the non-microsomal enzymes except glucuronidation.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male patient is being evaluated for sweating, palpitations, and pallor that occur a few times a day. He was diagnosed with pheochromocytoma and planned for surgery. Choose the incorrect statement regarding anesthesia for this patient.

choices.text: Ketamine may exacerbate the effects of his condition
Halothane can be used safely in this patient
Vecuronium is safe to use in this patient

questions.solution:
Halothane should not be used in the patient as it sensitizes the heart to the arrhythmogenic effects of epinephrine.

Pheochromocytoma is a condition where the chromaffin tissue, most commonly in the adrenal medulla, produces excessive norepinephrine and epinephrine. 

Other anaesthetic drugs to be avoided in a pheochromocytoma patient are:

  • Succinylcholine - can cause fasciculations which lead to raised intraabdominal pressure and catecholamine release from the tumor
  • Ketamine - as it is sympathomimetic and might exacerbate the effects of adrenergic agonists
  • Anticholinergics and Pancuronium – vagal blockade leading to tachycardia
  • Atracurium – due to histamine release which may provoke catecholamine release. The safest options for these patients would be vecuronium and rocuronium

Other considerations in patients with pheochromocytoma:

  • Phenoxybenzamine, an alpha1-antagonist, which can be administered orally, is often given preoperatively to reverse the vasoconstriction. This results in a drop in arterial blood pressure and a drop in hematocrit
  • Phentolamine is used intraoperatively to control hypertensive episodes
  • A major regional block such as spinal/epidural could block sensory and sympathetic discharge in the area of the surgical field. But catecholamines released from the pheochromocytoma could still bind to receptors all over the body.

questions.text: You are an intern evaluating a newborn. The newborn has acute respiratory distress and cyanosis that is relieved with crying. He has feeding difficulty. A laryngeal mirror placed under the nostrils reveals an absence of fogging and a suction catheter cannot be passed through either nostril. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient with respiratory distress and cyanosis that is relieved by crying, feeding difficulty, who has an absence of fogging, and in whom a suction catheter cannot be passed through either nostril is likely to have bilateral choanal atresia. 

Choanal atresia is a congenital condition in which the nasal choana is occluded by soft tissue, bone, or both. It is due to failed recanalization during development. It is part of CHARGE syndrome characterized by coloboma, heart disease, atresia choanae, growth, and mental retardation, genital hypoplasia, and ear anomalies. 

It can be unilateral or bilateral. Unilateral choanal atresia is more common and some patients with this condition are undiagnosed until adulthood. Patients with bilateral atresia present with respiratory obstruction. This is because newborns are obligate nose breathers and cannot breathe from the mouth. 

Evaluation of newborns with choanal atresia involves the following: 

  • Placing a laryngeal mirror under the nostrils to look for fogging
  • Inserting a suction catheter through each nostril and oral cavity to look for patency
  • Inserting a flexible nasal endoscope
  • CT scan to delineate the extent of the malformation and differentiating from other causes of nasal obstruction

Unilateral choanal atresia does not require immediate correction. Surgery can be performed when the child has reached school-age provided they are monitored for breathing issues.

Bilateral choanal atresia should be treated immediately with endotracheal intubation or a McGovern nipple (an intraoral nipple with a large opening secured in the mouth with ties around the occiput). This is followed by perforation of the atresia plate.

Other options: 

Option A - Turbinate hypertrophy is seen in conditions like chronic rhinitis or hypertrophic rhinitis. It occurs due to recurrent nasal infections and chronic irritation. It is unlikely to be seen in newborns. 

Option B - Antrochonal polyps arise from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum. It is seen in children and young adults and may occur due to nasal allergy with a sinus infection. It is visible as a globular mass on posterior rhinoscopy or nasal endoscopy.

Option C - Deviated nasal septum can occur due to errors in development or trauma. It would also present with nasal obstruction. However, acute respiratory distress with cyanosis is unlikely to be present. 

Related Pearl: Choanal atresia

It is due to the persistence of bucconasal membrane which separates primitive oropharynx from the primitive nasopharynx. It has the following features:

  • Bony obstruction is more common than membranous
  • Unilateral > bilateral
  • Unilateral cases may be asymptomatic and present in adult life
  • Bilateral cases are life-threatening and present with respiratory distress
  • Associated with CHARGE syndrome
    • C- Coloboma of the eye
    • H- Heart defects
    • A- Atresia of choana
    • R- Retarded growth and development
    • G- Genital anomalies
    • E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss.

CT scan is the investigation of choice

Image: Membranous, bilateral choanal atresia in a newborn

Immediate management involves placing a feeding nipple with a large hole at the mouth to force the baby to mouth-breathe - McGoverns technique.

Definitive treatment consists of correction of atresia by a trans-nasal or trans-palatal approach.

questions.text: An elderly man presented with weight loss, easy fatiguability, and bone pain for 6 months duration. A bone marrow aspirate showed characteristic cells as in the image below. Cytogenetic studies revealed the presence of t(15:17). Which of the following drugs can be highly effective for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of an elderly man presenting with constitutional symptoms, bone marrow aspirate showing faggot cells, and cytogenetic studies demonstrating the presence of translocation (15:17) is suggestive of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). Among the given drugs tretinoin (All-trans-retinoic acid) is highly effective for the treatment of (APL).

Faggot cells are cells with multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell that resemble a bundle of sticks or twigs.

APL is associated with the production of a fusion gene PML-RARα due to the above-mentioned translocation. Tretinoin binds to the RARα-RXR dimer. It thus prevents the formation of the PML-RARα fusion gene dimerization and also degrades the already formed PML-RARα fusion genes. This leads to blockade of myeloid precursor cell differentiation into cells of different lineage.

Tretinoin alone can induce temporary remission but induction therapy with tretinoin and daunorubicin/doxorubicin produces complete remission. 

The most serious adverse effect of the treatment of tretinoin is 'retinoic acid syndrome'. It comprises breathlessness, fever, pleural/pericardial effusion, and pulmonary infiltrates. The occurrence of this can be prevented by pretreatment with dexamethasone.  

Other options:

Option B- Gemcitabine is a difluoro cytidine analog. It is mainly indicated in patients with nonresectable or metastatic pancreatic tumors, nonsquamous,  non-small cell lung tumors, ovarian and bladder cancer. 

Option C- Idarubicin is an anthracyline that can be used along with tretinoin in induction therapy for APL. It is indicated with cytarabine for the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia. 

Option D- Imatinib is a BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor expressed by chronic myeloid leukemia. 

Related Pearl: Important Translocations in AML

Translocation t(8,21)

(most common)

Fusion gene

RUNX1-RUNX1T1

 PML-RARα CBF-β (Core binding factor)
FAB classification

Blasts with maturation/M2

Prognosis Good Very good Good

Related Pearl: Morphological Characteristics of Blasts Cells in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia vs. Acute Myeloid Leukemia

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman came with complaints of dull-aching pain in her hips and back. She was diagnosed with bilateral mixed conductive and a sensorineural hearing loss last month. A blood workup revealed normal calcium and phosphate levels. X-ray of her lower limbs showed flame-shaped osteolytic lesion and cortical thickening. Which of the following is the best among the given treatment options?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of Paget's disease of the bone. It is also known as osteitis deformans. The most appropriate treatment for this patient with Paget's disease is IV Zoledronate- a bisphosphonate. 

It is characterized by an increased bone turnover due to a disorganized, alternating, and increased rate of osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. It may be monostotic or polyostotic. 

Clinically, it is seen more commonly in people over the age of 50. A majority of the patients are asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients present with bone pain, which is constant and dull aching and mostly involves the long bones of the lower limbs, back, and hips. They may have deformities such as bowing of bones, the tibia bending anteriorly and the femur bending anterolaterally. Skull bones may be enlarged and the base of the skull may be flattened. Disorganized and increased bone deposition may lead to stenosis of various canals and foramina resulting in compression of cranial nerves, spinal cord, and nerve roots (due to spinal stenosis). Hearing loss is a fairly common feature, due to compression of the cranial nerve and otosclerosis resulting in mixed sensorineural and conductive hearing loss. Pathological fractures of the long bones may be seen. One of the most baleful complications, however, is the increased risk of developing osteosarcoma. 

Other complications include osteoarthritis, high-output cardiac failure, and hypercalcemia. 

Laboratory investigations reveal-

  • Normal calcium and phosphate levels
  • Increased bone-specific alkaline phosphatase due to increased osteoblastic activity
  • Increased serum levels of collagen crosslinked peptides such as CTX (C-telopeptide) due to bone resorption
  • Increased urinary markers such as hydroxyproline, deoxypyridinoline, C-telopeptide, and N-telopeptide.

X-ray findings in Paget's disease reveal both sclerotic and osteolytic lesions. Characteristic radiographic findings include-

  • Brim sign- Seen in Paget's disease of the pelvis due to a thickened iliopectineal line.
  • Flame-shaped lesions- Seen in long bones due to localized osteolysis/osteopenia. 
  • Picture-frame appearance may be seen in vertebral bodies due to enlarged coarse trabeculae surrounded by a prominent radiodense periphery.
  • Ivory vertebra sign may be seen due to diffuse and homogeneous increase in opacity of a vertebral body.
  • Osteogenesis circumscripta describes circumscribed patches of radiolucency due to osteoporosis in the skull.

The aim of the treatment of Paget disease is to limit excessive bone remodeling and to reduce pain. The mainstay of treatment is therefore bisphosphonates as they inhibit osteoclastic activity, limiting bone resorption and disease progression. IV zoledronate is the preferred bisphosphonate. It is administered as a single IV dose of 4-5 mg and has the most sustained response. It is, however, contraindicated in renal insufficiency. 

Therapeutic uses of bisphosphonates- 

  • Osteoporosis including postmenopausal and steroid-induced
  • Paget disease 
  • Tumor-associated osteolysis 
  • Hypercalcemia. 

The arrow mark in the image given below depicts the 'blade of grass'/Flame shaped lesion.

 

The image given below depicts the Ivory vertebra sign.

 

The image given below depicts the Picture-frame appearance seen in vertebral bodies.

questions.text: After a trial, the court declared a witness as hostile. Under which Indian Evidence Act (IEA) this hostile witness can be cross-examined by the same side lawyer?
questions.solution:
Under the Indian Evidence Act (IEA) 154, the presiding officer of the court grants permission to put any questions during the cross-examination. 

A hostile witness is one who has some interest or motive for concealing part of the truth or for giving completely false evidence. There must be some evidence to prove that the witness has retracted from his earlier statement or is not desirous of disclosing the truth, or has exhibited an element of hostility. 

Other options:

Option B- IEA 45 defines expert witness. A person who has been trained or is skilled or has the knowledge, experience, or education in a technical or scientific subject, and is capable of drawing opinions and conclusions from the observed facts observed is termed an expert witness. Examples include doctors, firearm or fingerprints, or handwriting experts.

Option C- IEA 32 (1) defines dying declarations. A statement made by a person as to the cause of his/her death or as to any of the circumstances
of the transaction that resulted in his/her death in cases in which the cause of that person’s death comes into question. Such a statement made by the person is a dying declaration. 

Option D- IEA 3 defines evidence. Evidence refers to statements that the court permits or requires to be made before it by witnesses. This is in relation to matters of fact under inquiry, and documents produced for the inspection of the court.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic man who sustained trauma to the scrotal area a few days back came to the hospital with sudden onset of pain in the perineal and scrotal area, with blackening of the scrotum, as shown in the image. Which of the following statement is false with respect to this condition?

choices.text: It is usually not a surgical emergency.
Alcoholism is a predisposing factor for this condition.
It occurs due to a mixed infection with aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

questions.solution:
The clinical features and image showing black, necrotic skin over an inflamed scrotum indicate that the patient has Fournier's gangrene, and it is a surgical emergency. 

Fournier's gangrene is characterized by a polymicrobial infection of the soft tissue of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. It is necrotizing fasciitis with rapid onset gangrene, which leads to the exposure of the scrotal contents.

Concurrent illnesses that diminish the host defense, especially diabetes mellitus, and alcoholism, predispose patients to the development of Fournier's gangrene. It may occur after minor injuries or procedures done in the perineal region.

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene are as follows: a mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene formation

It presents with sudden pain, pyrexia, and prostration. There may be a foul-smelling exudate and crepitus may be present. The testes are usually not affected. Cellulitis spreads and involves the skin and coverings of the scrotum, and penis. This may get sloughed and expose the testes, which remain healthy. It is also referred to as "shameful exposure of the testis." 

It is a surgical emergency.

  • Initial management is by intravenous (IV) fluid resuscitation and the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Urgent wide surgical excision of dead and infected tissue is essential.

Despite the best therapy, mortality rates have been reported to be as high as 50%.

questions.text: The enzyme pyruvate carboxylase is allosterically activated and inhibited by:
questions.solution:
The enzyme pyruvate carboxylase is allosterically activated by Acetyl CoA and inhibited by ADP.

An allosteric enzyme is one that has one catalytic site for the substrate to bind and another allosteric site where the modifier binds

The binding of the regulatory molecule can either enhance the activity of the enzyme, called allosteric activation, or inhibit the activity of the enzyme, called allosteric inhibition. In allosteric activation, the regulatory molecule is known as the positive modifier and in allosteric inhibition, it is known as the negative modifier.

Pyruvate carboxylase catalyses the conversion of Pyruvate to Oxaloacetate under allosteric activation of Acetyl CoA. So, Acetyl CoA can determine the amount of oxaloacetate formed from Pyruvate, that is formed via Glycolysis. 

ADP, AMP and adenosine acts as allosteric inhibitor to prevent further conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate as they compete fro ATP (ATP and Biotin acts as coenzymes for Carboxylase enzymes)

Other options:

Option A: Acetyl CoA-carboxylase is allosterically activated by citrate and inhibited by Acyl CoA and catalyses the conversion of Acetyl CoA to Malonyl CoA

Option C: Phosphofructokinase is activated by AMP and inhibited by ATP. It catalyses the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate during glycolysis.

Option D: Aspartate transcarbamoylase is the catalyst for the first step in the synthesis of pyrimidines, the formation of carbamoyl aspartic acid from carbamoyl phosphate and aspartic acid. It is allosterically activated by ATP and inhibited by CTP

questions.text: A 38-year-old G3P2L2 presents at 9 weeks of amenorrhea. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 6 months ago. You inform her about the importance of blood sugar control and about the fetal anomalies that can occur due to diabetes. Which of the following is true about this disease?

choices.text: Poor glycemic control can cause spontaneous abortions in 1st trimester
Diabetic complications cannot be avoided by better glycemic control
Neonatal hypoglycemia is not seen in these cases
Microsomia incidence increases when blood glucose is elevated

questions.solution:
This patient who was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus 6 months before her pregnancy has pregestational diabetes mellitus. Poor glycemic control can lead to 1st-trimester abortions. Women with HbA1c >12% and/or fasting blood sugars of >120mg/dl have an elevated risk of early pregnancy loss.   

Overt diabetes in pregnancy is defined as hyperglycemia that was first recognized during pregnancy that meets the thresholds of diabetes in non-pregnant adults. Pregestational diabetes is diagnosed when women are known to have diabetes before pregnancy. Gestational diabetes is when women are diagnosed to have diabetes during pregnancy that is not clearly overt. 

Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus during pregnancy can lead to complications in the fetus and mother. These include: 

  • Fetal effects: 
    • Spontaneous abortions
    • Preterm delivery
    • Malformations
    • Altered fetal growth
    • Unexplained fetal demise
    • Hydramnios
  • Neonatal effects: 
    • Respiratory distress syndrome
    • Hypoglycemia
    • Hypocalcemia
    • Hyperbilirubinemia and polycythemia
    • Cardiomyopathy
    • Long term cognitive development
    • Increased risk to develop diabetes
  • Maternal effects: 
    • Preeclampsia
    • Diabetic nephropathy
    • Diabetic retinopathy
    • Diabetic neuropathy
    • Diabetic ketoacidosis
    • Infections

Many complications of pregestational diabetes that occur in pregnancy can be prevented by periconceptional glycemic control. It is advisable to get the blood sugars under control before planning pregnancy as the risk of complications can be markedly reduced.  The complication risk is also related to the degree of underlying cardiac and renal disease.   

Poorly controlled overt diabetes, preconceptionally and during early pregnancy, is responsible for elevated fetal malformation risk. This risk is higher than in gestational diabetes which causes high sugars later in the pregnancy. Fetal macrosomia is seen with gestational diabetes, risk of malformations is quite low.

Neonatal hypoglycemia is seen in both overt and gestational diabetes mellitus. Chronic maternal hyperglycemia can cause hyperplasia of fetal beta-islet cells causing hyperinsulinemia and hypoglycemia.  

Note: Macrosomia is seen in infants of diabetic mothers, not microsomia.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs given for diabetes reversibly inhibits the α-glucosidase enzyme?
questions.solution:
Voglibose reversibly inhibits the α-glucosidase enzyme and is used in the treatment of diabetes mellitus. 

Voglibose is an α glucosidase inhibitor with similar properties to acarbose. α-glucosidase is the final enzyme for the digestion of carbohydrates in the brush border of the small intestine mucosa. α glucosidase inhibitors slow down and decrease digestion and absorption of polysaccharides and sucrose. It also promotes the release of GLP-l which adds to its hypoglycemic effect. It is usually preferred in obese patients as a mild antihyperglycemic agent that can be used adjuvant to diet with or without metformin. 

Other options:

Option B: Pioglitazone belongs to the thiazolidinediones class of hypoglycemic drugs that stimulate the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR-γ) in muscle, fat, and liver, and reduce insulin resistance. The most common adverse effect include weight gain and edema due to an increase in adiposity and fluid retention. They can increase the incidence of heart failure and the risk of fractures.

Option C: Teneligliptin is a new dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It exerts a long-lasting effect (>24 hours) on DPP-4 inhibition and antihyperglycemic effects. 

Option D: Repaglinide is a D-phenylalanine/meglitinide analog that blocks ATP-sensitized potassium channels and in turn helps in the release of insulin. It is primarily metabolized by the liver (CYP3A4) into inactive products. It is mainly indicated only in selected type 2 diabetics who suffer pronounced post­ prandial hyperglycemia, or to supplement metformin/long­acting insulin. It is contraindicated in liver disease.

questions.text: A male baby was brought to the pediatrician in the 5th week of life with complaints of non-bilious vomiting after feeding. A mass could be palpated in the right upper quadrant. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows the following. Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing thickened pylorus, with cervix sign and nipple sign on ultrasound is suggestive of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The acid-base abnormality seen in this condition is hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, hence the ABG which shows a pH: 7.48, pCO2: 47, HCO3: 30 is the answer.

A pH >7.40, with increased HCO3, and increased pCO2 indicate metabolic alkalosis.

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis most presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 2 and 8 weeks of age. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. Male infants are at a higher risk.

Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right across the abdomen.

Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality- hypochloraemic hypokalaemic metabolic alkalosis. Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).

Diagnosis:

Ultrasound examination is the Investigation of choice for this condition. Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm. The cervix sign and nipple sign are signs seen on USG.

  • Nipple sign- Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach
  • Cervix sign- The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix 

Management:

  • The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected before proceeding to surgery.
  • The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy remains the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A 35-year-old soccer player presents with pain, swelling, and redness of the left ear following trauma to the ear a few days back. On examination, his left ear feels warm, slightly tender to touch, and firm.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette along with the image depicting a red pinna is suggestive of perichondritis.

A common cause of perichondritis is trauma either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or noniatrogenic (laceration, hematoma). It can also be due to the extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of the meatus. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an organism commonly implicated.

Initially, the pinna is red, hot, painful, and stiff. In the later stages, an abscess may form between the cartilage and perichondrium with necrosis of cartilage as the cartilage survives only on the blood supply from its perichondrium.

Treatment in the early stages consists of:

  • Systemic antibiotics
  • 4% aluminum acetate compresses
  • Prompt drainage of the abscess and culture and sensitivity of the pus.
  • Occasionally, a catheter is placed in the abscess with a continuous drip of antibiotics

Other options:

Option A- Cauliflower ear is also known as perichondrial hematoma or boxer's ear. It is a deformity of the ear caused by trauma that occurs due to the collection of blood between the auricular cartilage and the perichondrium. It may get infected leading to severe perichondritis. It is treated by aspirating the hematoma and application of a pressure dressing. Prophylactic antibiotics should be given. 

Cauliflower ear is shown in the image below.


Option C- Chondrodermatitis chronica helicis refers to small, nodular, tender lesions occurring on the helix of the ear. Treatment involves the excision of the nodule with its skin and cartilage.


Option D - Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is an inflammatory condition seen in elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs due to pseudomonal infection. It is an infective condition and not a malignant condition. It mimics diffuse otitis externa associated with excruciating pain, discharge, and granulations on the floor of EAC.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman was shifted to the observation room after a surgery in which a certain topical anesthetic was used. An hour later, the patient was found to be cyanotic and diaphoretic, with a room air oxygen saturation of 89%. Despite the use of a non-rebreathing face mask, the patient remained hypoxic, with oxygen saturation of around 86%. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be the cause of the patient's condition?

ABG shows:

pH- 7.35

pCO2- 37 mm Hg

HCO3- 24 mEq/L

pO2- 33.6 mm Hg
questions.solution:
The above clinical history is suggestive of methemoglobinemia, which is a common side effect of prilocaine.

The possible diagnosis of methemoglobinemia can be made because the patient is cyanosed, the cyanosis is unresponsive to ventilation, there is no prior history of respiratory problems, and the patient is exposed to a topical anesthetic during the procedure that is known to cause methemoglobinemia. The hepatic metabolism of prilocaine generates O-toluidine, which oxidizes hemoglobin to methemoglobin. Methemoglobinemia risk is directly associated with the total dose administered, usually appearing when doses exceed 8 mg/kg.

Pulse oximetry is used as an important assessment of oxygenation. It uses plethysmography and light absorbance measurements at two wavelengths to estimate oxygen saturation. It is inaccurate when more than two types of hemoglobin are present. This is because abnormal hemoglobin (methemoglobin) is not picked up by pulse oximetry. Pulse oximetry data (SpO2) should therefore be used with caution in patients with methemoglobinemia. Pulse oximetry with low levels of methemoglobinemia shows low levels of O2 saturation, and at high levels of methemoglobinemia shows high levels of O2 saturation.

Methemoglobinemia causes cyanosis, which does not respond to oxygen administration. Methemoglobin level assay is the best way to diagnose this condition. Levels >15% cause cerebral ischemia, whilst 60% blood level may cause fatality. Oxygen saturation in pulse oximetry in methemoglobinemia plateaus at 85%

Intravenous administration of methylene blue is the treatment for methemoglobinemia.

Benzocaine can also cause methemoglobinemia, similar to prilocaine. The risk of methemoglobinemia due to Procaine, Bupivacaine, and Ropivacaine is significantly lower as compared to Prilocaine and Benzocaine.

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine: 

  • Naturally occurring
  • Vasoconstrictor
  • 1st local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine: Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine: 

  • Safest
  • Causes maximum methemoglobinemia
  • Suitable for Bier’s IV block
  • EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

  • Long-acting
  • Most cardiotoxic
  • Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia
  • Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretylium(for VT), vasopressors (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

  • LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia
  • 1st synthetic LA
  • Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

questions.text: A clinical study is conducted on the prevalence of lactose intolerance. All of the subjects from this study were of Northern European descent. From the study, it was estimated that only 5% of the human population is lactose intolerant. In reality, 65% of the world population is estimated to have lactose intolerance. What type of bias was present in the study?
questions.solution:
The type of bias involved is a selection bias.

In the given scenario, the study subjects being of Northern European descent were not representative of the total human population. In reality, it is estimated that 65% of the human population has lactose intolerance, being most prevalent in people of East Asian, West African, Arab, Jewish, Greek, and Italian descent. Since the characteristics of the study population were not representative of the general population, this is a selection bias. 

Bias refers to any systematic error in determining the association between exposure and disease. In a selection bias, the cases and controls selected may not be representative of cases and controls in the general population, due to systematic differences in characteristics between cases and controls. It is also called sampling bias.

Other options:

Option A: Recall bias occurs as a result of the cases being more likely able to recall the existence of certain events or factors than the controls. For example, patients who have had a stroke would be more likely to remember and recall certain habits or events that led to the episode than those who have not.

Option B: Berksonian bias applies to hospital cases and controls. It occurs because of the difference in rates of admission to hospitals for people with different diseases.

Option C: Interviewer's bias occurs when the person conducting the case-control study knows the hypothesis and who the cases are. This may lead to the interviewer questioning the cases more thoroughly than controls regarding the history of the causal factor.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: A female patient with fatigue and weight loss had the following upper gastrointestinal endoscopy findings. She was diagnosed with gastric carcinoma involving the mucosa and submucosa without lymph node involvement. Which of the following features of the tumor would not favor an endoscopic resection for her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of early gastric cancer. Early gastric cancer having ulceration would not favour performing endoscopic mucosal resection.

The general guidelines for endoscopic resection of early gastric cancer are as follows:

  • Tumour smaller than 2 cm
  • Tumour limited to the mucosa
  • No lymphovascular invasion
  • No ulceration
  • Well or moderately well-differentiated histopathology

If any of these is not fulfilled, gastrectomy with lymph node dissection is indicated.

Gastric carcinoma can be classified as early gastric cancer and advanced gastric cancer.

  • Early gastric cancer involves mucosa, submucosa with or without lymph node involvement. Early gastric cancer can be further classified using the Japanese classification.
  • Advanced gastric cancer involves the muscularis layer, with or without adjacent structures. Its macroscopic appearances have been classified using Bormann classification.

The given image shows the pathological types of early gastric cancer as per Japanese system.

The other classifications and risk factors for the development of gastric carcinoma are enlisted in the pearls attached below.

Related Pearl: Borrmann’s classification of stomach cancer

Related Pearl: Risk factors for carcinoma stomach

Risk factors for carcinoma stomach:

  • Dietary
    • Low fat or protein consumption
    • Consumption of salted meat or fish with high nitrate content
    • High complex carbohydrate consumption
    • Smoking, alcohol consumption
    • Spicy food, high salt diet
    • Lack of fresh fruits and vegetables
    • Dietary anti-oxidant deficiency
  • Genetic and familial
    • E cadherin – hereditary diffuse type of gastric cancer
    • Blood group A
    • FAP
    • Li-Fraumeni syndrome
    • HNPCC
    • BRCA 2 mutation
  • Premalignant lesions
    • Chronic atrophic gastritis
    • Adenomatous polyp (FAP)
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Intestinal metaplasia (H. pylori)
    • Menetrier’s disease
    • Stump carcinoma from stomach remnants in Billroth II GJ or vagotomy GJ
  • Others
    • Low socioeconomic status
    • Male gender
    • Rubber and coal workers
    • EBV infection

Related Pearl: Types of Gastric Adenocarcinoma

Intestinal type

Diffuse type

Male-to-female ratio, 2:1

Equal frequency in males and females

Bulky masses

Diffusely infiltrative growth

Glandular structures

Signet-ring cells

Loss of E-cadherin

Precursor lesions are flat dysplasia and adenomas.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument shown below?

choices.text: It is the safest in procedures close to vital structures
It can be used for coagulation
It can be used for cutting
There is more thermal dissipation of current

questions.solution:
From the single-tipped electrode in the cautery image shown below, we can identify the instrument is a unipolar cautery. The false statement is option A. Due to a high thermal spread in unipolar cautery, it is not the safest instrument during procedures close to vital structures. The vitals structures are at risk of thermal injury with this instrument. 

Electrosurgery is the use of high-frequency currents to cut or coagulate tissue during surgery. It can be performed using:

  • Monopolar or unipolar cautery: consists of a single electrode tip
  • Bipolar cautery: consists of two electrode tips in the form of scissors, graspers, etc. 

Other options

Option B: It is true that unipolar cautery can be used for coagulating tissue. The two main settings in unipolar and bipolar cautery are:

  • Coagulation mode: Blue button in the image above.
  • Cutting mode: Yellow button in the image above

In the coagulation mode, a high-voltage current is produced that spreads over a greater surface area. This helps to produce a dehydration effect on the tissues and is very useful when trying to stop the bleeding from nicked vessels during surgery. 

Option C: It is true, as mentioned above that unipolar cautery can be used for cutting tissue. Cutting mode produces a low voltage current that acts on a smaller surface area. This makes it more effective in heating the tissue than in the coagulation mode. The thermal spread will also be less than the coagulation mode, making it safer. 

Option D: It is true that monopolar cautery produces more thermal dissipation of current. 

The image below shows the unipolar and bipolar cautery-
