Features Monopolar Bipolar
Flow of current

Cautery pencil –> tissue –> cautery pad –> machine/ground

Hence more chance of burns

Only between tips of the instrument

Hence less chance of burns
Modes

Cutting – Low voltage, high amplitude, continuous waveforms

Coagulation – Alternate waveforms (Bursts)

Dessication – Low power

Fulguration – High power

 Only coagulation
Dissipation

More thermal dissipation of current

Hence can cause damage to nerves and other vital structures

Less lateral dissipation of current

Hence safer in procedures closer to vital structures

questions.text: A baby was brought with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. There were no neurological signs and no palpable mass. During her pregnancy, the mother did not have an elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein level. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of a tuft of hair over the lower back in a baby, along with the absence of neurological signs, palpable mass, and serum alpha-fetoprotein within the normal range during pregnancy suggests a likely diagnosis of spinal bifida occulta. 

Spina bifida occulta refers to fusion defects of the posterior part of the vertebral body. There is no associated protrusion of the spinal cord or meninges. These neonates are usually asymptomatic, without any neurological signs. They present only with a tuft of hair over the lower back. 

Elevated maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein level during pregnancy suggests an open neural tube defect, such as meningocele, meningomyelocele, and encephalocele (Option A, B, and C).

Meningocele involves the midline protrusion of the meninges. A fluctuant midline mass that may transilluminate is present in the lower back along the vertebral column. Meningomyelocele involves the protrusion of the spinal cord with the meningeal covering. Neurological dysfunction is more common in these open defects.

The image below shows (from left to right) spina bifida occulta, meningocele, and meningomyelocele.

 

Encephalocele refers to the protrusion of intracranial tissue through a midline bony defect.

The two images below show babies with encephalocele, i.e. midline neural tube defects of the cranial end.

Related Pearl: Conditions Associated with Abnormal MSAFP

Elevated levels

  • Underestimated gestational age
  • Multifetal gestations
  • Fetal death
  • Neural tube defects
  • Gastroschisis
  • Omphalocele
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Esophageal or intestinal obstruction
  • Liver necrosis
  • Renal anomalies
  • Cloacal exstrophy
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Congenital skin abnormality
  • Pilonidal cyst
  • Chorioangioma of placenta
  • Placenta intervillous thrombosis
  • Placental abruption
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Preeclampsia
  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Maternal hepatoma or teratoma
 Low levels 
  • Obesity
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Trisomies 21 or 18
  • Gestational trophoblastic disease
  • Overestimated gestational age

questions.text: A  veterinarian presented to the clinic with fever, malaise, and headache. On examination, a lesion is seen on his arm as shown in the below image. Later the patient developed sepsis. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing black, central, necrotic eschar surrounded by edematous skin in a veterinarian is strongly suggestive of cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis where the toxin acts by the increase in cAMP.

Bacillus anthracis is a large, gram-positive bacillus. It is non-motile and capsulated with a characteristic polypeptide capsule made of poly-γ-d-glutamic acid. 

Bacillus anthracis may cause:

  • Cutaneous anthrax: It is caused by contact with infected animal/ animal products. It is seen in tanners and hide-porters. At the site of entry of organism or spores, a papule develops which further develops into a vesicle. It later breaks down into an ulcer with a black, central, necrotic eschar surrounded by edematous skin. The lesion is also called a 'malignant pustule'. A majority of the patients tend to recover spontaneously. However, some patients may succumb to septicemia or meningitis.
  • Pulmonary anthrax (Wool sorter’s disease): It is caused by inhaling spores. It is seen in wool sorters. The infection from the lung spreads to the mediastinal lymph nodes and causes hemorrhagic mediastinitis and sepsis. 
  • Gastrointestinal anthrax: It is caused rarely, by ingesting infected animals. 

Virulence factors of Bacillus anthracis include:

  • Polypeptide capsule which is anti-phagocytic.
  • Toxins that are made of three proteins-
    • Protective antigen (PA)- Binds to specific cell receptors and mediates entry of edema factor and lethal factor into the cell.
    • Edema factor (EF)- Is an adenylate cyclase, which is activated only inside the target cells, leading to intracellular accumulation of cyclic AMP and causing tissue edema.
    • Lethal factor (LF)- Causes tissue death.

Other options : 

Option A: Diptheria toxin and Pseudomonas acts by inhibition of elongation factor-2 (EF-2).

Option C: Shiga toxin inhibits protein synthesis by inhibition of 60S ribosomal subunit.

Option D: Some strains of Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) produce a heat-stable toxin that acts by an increase in cGMP.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

Related Pearl: Culture media used for Vibrio cholerae

The following are various culture media used for Vibrio cholerae: 

Transport Media

  • Venkatraman-Ramakrishnan (VR) medium
  • Cary-Blair medium
  • Autoclaved sea water

Enrichment Media

  • Alkaline peptone water (APW)
  • Monsur’s taurocholate tellurite peptone water

Selective Media

  • Alkaline bile salt agar (BSA)
  • Monsur’s gelatin taurocholate trypticase tellurite agar (GTTA)
  • Thiosulphate citrate bile sucrose (TCBS) agar -
    • Yellow colonies- Vibrio cholerae
    • Green colonies- Vibrio parahemolyticus

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presented with a 1-year history of worsening headaches and one episode of focal seizures recently. Imaging reveals a cortical calcified mass in the left cerebral hemisphere. The histopathological image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

IDH- Isocitrate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario presence of cortical calcified mass in the left cerebral hemisphere with histopathology revealing a chicken-wire pattern and fried egg appearance is suggestive of oligodendroglioma.

In the given histopathological image there are regular sheets of tumor cells with spherical nuclei surrounded by a perinuclear halo termed fried egg appearance. The network of thin branched capillary-sized vessels shows a "chicken-wire" pattern in appearance. The cells that infiltrate the brain may collect around the neurons. This is called perineural satellitosis.

Oligodendroglioma is an infiltrating glioma composed of cells resembling oligodendrocytes. It is associated with mutations in IDH and deletion of chromosomes 1p and 19q.

Most commonly oligodendrogliomas are detected in the fourth and fifth decades of life. Patients may have had several years of antecedent neurologic complaints, often including seizures. The lesions are found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, with a pre­dilection for white matter. The imaging may show the presence of cortical mass with calcifications.

Management includes a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy.

Related Pearl: Most commons of Brain tumours

Most common tumor of the brain - Metastasis secondary to lungs > breast

Most common primary CNS tumor - glioma > meningioma

Most common primary CNS tumor in children - pilocytic astrocytoma

Most common primary CNS tumor in adults - astrocytoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in children - medulloblastoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in adults - glioblastoma

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: In your university practical exams, the external examiner displays the following retractors on the desk and asks you to pick the Deaver's retractor. What would you pick?
questions.solution:
If you were asked to pick Deaver's retractor you would pick the instrument labeled '1'.

The given image shows

1 - Deaver's retractor

2 - Doyen's retractor

3 - Morris retractor

4 - Czerny's retractor

Deaver’s retractor: It is used to retract the liver, spleen, and other abdominal viscera. It is atraumatic and gives adequate exposure of the surgical field.

 

Doyen's retractor: It is used in pelvic surgeries.

 

Morris retractor: It is used to retract the abdominal wall.

 

Czerny's retractor: It is used in surgeries like hernia, and laparotomy, especially during closure.

questions.text: Infertility in Klinefelter's syndrome is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Infertility in Klinefelter’s syndrome is due to azoospermia i.e. a complete absence of sperm in the semen.

Klinefelter's syndrome is a genetic disorder that results from a 47, XXY karyotype. These patients are phenotypically male and present with infertility due to hyalinization of the seminiferous tubules and no spermatogenesis. Hence, the present with testes of small volume. They have manifestations of androgen deficiency such as average stature, sparse body hair, low libido, etc. Relatively elevated estradiol levels result in gynecomastia. Other features include possible thromboses, varicose veins, osteoporosis, etc. These patients are advised to undergo frequent mammography screening due to the increased breast cancer risk.

The most important treatment measure is with supplementation of testosterone. Dosage is decided on an individualized basis depending on the patient's current levels. 

Fertility can be achieved using the artificial reproductive technique of intracytoplasmic sperm injection from the patient into the egg of the partner. 

Other options-

Option (A): Asthenospermia is the cause of infertility in Kartagener’s syndrome, also known as primary ciliary dyskinesia. It presents with the classical triad of situs inversus, bronchiectasis, and chronic sinusitis. Asthenospermia is the decreased motility of spermatozoa due to abnormal ciliary motility seen in this syndrome. It occurs due to defects in the dynein arm of cilia. Ciliary motility is not affected in Klinefelter's syndrome.

Option (C): Undescended testes are not seen in patients with Klinefelter's syndrome.

Option (D): Epididymis obstruction can cause infertility due to sexually transmitted infections and congenital malformations. The most common organisms responsible for the infective etiology are C. trachomatis and N. gonorrheae. Coliform organisms can also be causative in men who have sex with men. This is not the cause of infertility in Klinefelter's syndrome.

questions.text: A patient presents with persistent nasal congestion for the last four weeks. He has been using intranasal decongestants for the last three weeks which initially provided relief. However, his symptoms recurred after two weeks of treatment. What is the next step in management for this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with recurrent symptoms of nasal congestion after initial improvement with intranasal decongestants is likely to have rhinitis medicamentosa. The next step in management for this condition is stopping the use of intranasal decongestants. 

Rhinitis medicamentosa is also known as rebound congestion. It occurs due to overuse of topical nasal decongestants which leads to inflammation of the nasal mucosa. It occurs when decongestants are used for more than 7-10 days. The exact etiology is not known. 

Patients usually present with severe nasal congestion and nasal mucosa swelling that has an erythematous and granular appearance. 

It is treated by discontinuing the decongestant. This may lead to an initial worsening of symptoms which can be relieved by using intranasal corticosteroids. Some may also prescribe short-course oral corticosteroids, oral antihistamines, and inferior turbinate steroid injections but are not frequently recommended.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman came with fever, headache, and vomiting for 3 days. On examination, her temperature is 101 F, pulse rate is 108 bpm, and BP is 80/60 mm of Hg. A maculopapular rash is seen over the trunk and extremities. She has neck stiffness and flexion of the neck causes flexion of the hips and knees. Which of the following media is used as transport media for the causative organism?

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination:

  • Reduced glucose
  • Increased protein
  • Increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with fever, maculopapular rash, and signs of meningeal irritation (nuchal rigidity, Brudzinski's sign) with CSF showing reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes levels is a typical presentation of bacterial meningitis. Among the given options Stuart's medium is recommended for the preservation and transportation of Neisseria species and other fastidious organisms from the clinic to the laboratory.

A nasopharyngeal swab from the patient is held in a Stuart transport medium till it is plated.

Composition of Stuart Medium:

  • Sodium glycerophosphate
  • Sodium thioglycollate
  • Calcium chloride
  • Methylene blue
  • Agar

Characteristics of Stuart medium:

  • This medium is a chemically defined, semisolid, non-nutrient medium that prevents microbial proliferation.
  • Because of this composition, the medium ensures that microorganisms present are able to survive for a sufficiently long period of time.
  • Sodium thioglycollate produces a reduced environment so as to improve the recovery of anaerobes.
  • Methylene blue acts as an oxidation-reduction indicator.
  • Calcium chloride maintains the permeability of bacterial cells and sodium glycerophosphate maintains the pH of the medium.
  • The medium appears colorless in the reduced state and blue in the oxidized state.

Meningococcal meningitis commonly presents with non-specific symptoms like fever, vomiting, headache, and irritability. Other features of bacterial meningitis include neck stiffness, photophobia, decreased consciousness, seizures, and focal neurologic signs. A non-blanching rash (petechial or purpuric) develops in >80% of cases.

Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial hemorrhages. 

Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.

  Guidelines for prophylaxis:

  • All patients admitted to the hospital with meningitis should be placed on standard precautions.
  • Droplet precautions are recommended for patients with Neisseria meningitidis and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) meningitis until they have received 24 hours of effective therapy. 
  • Chemoprophylaxis is indicated for the household and close contacts. The preferred antibiotics are rifampin, ciprofloxacin, and ceftriaxone.
  • Monovalent, polyvalent, and conjugate vaccines are availbale.

Other options:

Options A, B, D- Cary Blair medium, Venkatraman Ramakrishnan medium, and autoclaved seawater are used as the transport mediums for Vibrio cholerae

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic patient presented with complaints of fever, cough, and hemoptysis for a few weeks. On staining his sputum, gram-negative bacilli with the typical safety pin appearance were identified. Culture on Ashdown medium showed wrinkled, purple colonies. Which of the following could be the possible causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of the patient, detection of gram-negative bacilli with safety pin appearance, and formation of wrinkled, purple colonies on culture are together suggestive of Whitmore's disease or melioidosis caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei.

Infection with B. pseudomallei is acquired by contamination of abrasion wounds with soil and water containing the bacilli. Patients with underlying diseases like diabetes mellitus have an increased risk of acquiring the infection.

Melioidosis can be of two types:

  • Acute - It causes acute pneumonia with upper lobe infiltrates or severe necrotizing disease. It can also mimic tuberculosis with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. It may lead to septicemia. Acute cases have a high case fatality rate. 
  • Chronic - It can lead to the development of multiple caseous or suppurative foci, with skin and subcutaneous abscesses. These can lead to lymphangitis and lymphadenopathy. It may involve bones and other internal organs.

On microscopy, small, irregularly staining gram-negative bacilli can be demonstrated for diagnosis. Methylene blue stain shows a typical bipolar safety pin appearance. ELISA for IgM and IgG antibodies and indirect hemagglutination can be also used for diagnosis. 

Treatment is divided into two stages: an intensive phase of 2 weeks of therapy with ceftazidime (drug of choice) or a carbapenem, followed by 12 weeks of oral cotrimoxazole to eradicate the organism and prevent relapse.

The image below shows dry purple wrinkled colonies of B. pseudomallei cultured in Ashdown medium. 

Option B: Burkholderia mallei causes glanders disease. It is a gram-negative, irregularly staining bacillus with a beaded appearance. It is usually an equine infection. Human infection is possible and is usually occupational, found among veterinarians and persons working with/caring for horses. Acute infection presents with fever, mucopurulent nasal discharge, and severe prostration.

Option C: Burkholderia cepacia is an opportunist pathogen, usually seen in cases of cystic fibrosis or chronic granulomatous disease. It causes a rapidly fatal syndrome of respiratory distress and septicemia (cepacia syndrome) in cystic fibrosis patients.

Option D: Paraburkholderia species do not cause human infection. They are beneficial to plants.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient presents with recurrent bouts of vomiting and abdominal cramps over the past three hours. He gives a history of consumption of fried rice at a restaurant 5 hours back. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette showing food poisoning within 2 hours of consumption of fried rice/ Chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (serotypes 1, 3, 5) food poisoning.

Two mechanisms of action have been described for the enterotoxin of B. cereus: one involves the stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system and the other is independent of it.

Food poisoning after eating food contaminated with B. cereus is of two types:

Bacillus cereus Diarrheal type Emetic type
Incubation period 8–16 hours 1–5 hours
Toxin Secreted in intestine Preformed
Heat Heat labile Heat stable
Food items Meat Rice
Clinical feature Diarrhea, abdominal cramps Vomiting, abdominal cramps

B. cereus produces lecithinase and ferments glucose but not mannitol. The presence of 1,00,000 or more bacteria per gram of stool is diagnostic. Anything less than that may be present as normal flora in the gut. Both types of illnesses are mild and self-limiting, requiring no specific treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Food poisoning by Clostridium perfringens is usually caused by the consumption of cold or warmed-up meat dishes. After an incubation period of 8-24 hours, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and vomiting set in. Isolating heat-resistant C. perfringens type A from feces and food is used for the diagnosis.

Option B: Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli is endemic in developing countries of the tropics, seen in all age groups. Its severity varies from mild watery diarrhea to a fatal disease indistinguishable from cholera. It has an incubation period of >16 hours. Demonstration of the enterotoxins is helpful to establish the diagnosis. It causes traveler's diarrhea in people from non-endemic areas visiting endemic areas.

Option C: Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxin is responsible for staphylococcal food poisoning. It presents with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea after 2–6 hours of consuming contaminated food. Meat, fish, milk, and milk products that are cooked and left at room temperature after contamination with Staphylococci, for a long enough time for the toxin to accumulate, are usually responsible. The source of infection is usually a food handler who is a carrier.

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

Organism Symptoms Common food source

Bacillus cereus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Fried rice

>16 hrs incubation period

questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient presents with the findings shown below, which he says occur recurrently. He also has similar lesions on his scrotum and complains of redness and pain in his eyes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this young man with recurrent oral and genital ulcers, as well as eye involvement, is Behcet's syndrome.

Behcet's syndrome is a vasculitic disorder that presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcerations and ocular involvement. It is a multisystem inflammatory disorder with a known association with HLA B*51. 

This syndrome commonly presents in young people, with males having more severe disease. These patients present with recurrent oral aphthous ulcers that are usually small and painful, painful genital ulcers, skin lesions (folliculitis, erythema nodosum, positive pathergy test, etc.), uveitis, arthritis/arthralgia, deep vein thromboses, etc.

To diagnose a patient with this condition, they must present with recurrent oral ulceration in addition to 2 of the following - genital ulcers/ocular involvement/skin lesions/positive pathergy test.

Topical glucocorticoids can be used to manage oral and skin lesions, but ocular involvement can often only be managed with intravenous steroids, azathioprine, and cyclosporine. 

Other options-

Option (A): Cogan's syndrome characteristically presents with interstitial keratitis and hearing loss. Hence, eye involvement is common, but oral and genital ulceration are not usually seen.

Option (B): Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that occurs due to the infiltration of lymphocytes into exocrine glands. This results in dry eyes and a dry gritty sensation in the mouth. However, recurrent oral and genital ulceration is not a common feature of this disease. 

Option (D): SAPHO syndrome is characterized by synovitis, acne, pustulosis, hyperostosis, and osteitis (SAPHO) and can present with various skin and musculoskeletal manifestations. Oral and genital ulceration is uncommon.

Related Pearl: HLA association with diseases

Hyperthyroidism (Japanese) B35

questions.text:
A 22-year-old male patient develops the following lesions 3 months after having unprotected sexual intercourse. They are mildly itchy.
Which of these is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows typical target lesions, characteristically seen in erythema multiforme. It is most commonly associated with a preceding herpes simplex virus infection or a mycoplasma infection. 

Erythema multiforme can occur at any age but is seen more often in neonates or young children. It usually starts as an eruption developing over a few days and resolving in 2–3 weeks. Repeated attacks associated with recurrent herpes simplex are frequent.

Erythema multiforme can be present in 3 forms:

Erythema multiforme minor - This presents as macular, papular, or urticarial lesions, as well as the classic iris or target lesions. These are less than 3 cm in diameter, rounded, and have three zones: a central area of dusky erythema or purpura, a middle paler zone of edema and an outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge. Atypical target lesions with only 2 zones may be seen in Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). 

Localized vesiculobullous form. This form is moderate in severity. The skin lesions are erythematous macules or plaques, often with a central bulla and a marginal ring of vesicles. Mucous membranes are mostly involved.

Erythema multiforme major - This is a severe illness associated with more extensive target lesions and mucous membrane involvement. It also has a much faster onset.

Often only symptomatic treatment is sufficient in the limited papular and localized bullous forms. For more severe cases, initial treatment is started with prednisolone tapered over 1-4 weeks.

 Other options-

Option (A): Human papillomavirus (HPV) is not associated with erythema multiforme. It is well known for being the cause of cervical cancer in women, anogenital carcinoma in men, and warts in both men and women. It is most commonly spread through sexual contact or via direct contact with the lesion.

Option (C): Infectious mononucleosis (IM) is a febrile illness in which the patient would present with a sore throat and cervical lymph node enlargement. It can be a trigger for erythema multiforme, but it is not the most common cause. 

Option (D): Lymphogranuloma venereum is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis that produces genital ulceration. Inguinal lymph nodes may enlarge and coalesce in later stages to form the classical buboes in the inguinal region. It can be associated with erythema multiforme, but it is also not the most common trigger for this condition.

Related Pearl: Glossary of important skin lesions

Glossary of Important Skin Lesions

Lesion

Description

Alopecia

Absence of hair from a normally hairy area

Aphtha

A small ulcer of the mucosa

Atrophy

Loss of tissue from one or more of the epidermis, dermis or subcutaneous tissues

Burrow

A small tunnel in the skin that houses a parasite, such as the scabies acarus

Callus

A localized hyperplasia of the stratum corneum

Cellulitis

An inflammation of cellular tissue, particularly purulent inflammation of the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue

Comedo

A plug of keratin and sebum in a dilated pilosebaceous orifice

Crusts (scabs)

Crusts consist of dried serum and other exudates

Cyst

Any closed cavity or sac (normal or abnormal) with an epithelial, endothelial or membranous lining and containing fluid or semi‐solid material

Ecchymosis

A macular area of hemorrhage more than 1 cm (bruise) in diameter

Erosion

A loss of epidermis, which heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister.

Erythema

Redness of the skin produced by vascular congestion or increased perfusion

Excoriation

Loss of skin substance, specifically produced by scratching

Exfoliation

The splitting off of the epidermal keratin in scales or sheets

Fibrosis

The formation of excessive fibrous tissue

Fissure

Any linear gap or slit in the skin surface

Fistula

An abnormal passage from a deep structure, such as a hollow viscus, to the skin surface or between two structures

Gangrene

Death of tissue, usually due to loss of blood supply

Guttate lesions

Small round or oval lesions distributed as a ‘shower’ of droplets. Usually applied to a form of psoriasis

Hematoma

A localized tumor‐like collection of blood

Keratoderma

A horny thickening of the skin

Lichenification

Thickening of the epidermis (and to some extent also of the dermis) in response to prolonged rubbing

Macule

A flat circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion that differs in color from the surrounding skin. It can be of any color or shape. A macule is <1 cm in diameter, larger lesions are a patch.

Maculopapular

Rash consisting of both macules and papules

Milium

A tiny white cyst containing lamellated keratin

Nodule*

A solid palpable lesion in the dermis or subcutis, which can be observed as an elevation or can be palpated. It is >0.5 cm in diameter.

Papule

An elevated solid lesion that is <1 cm in diameter.

Petechia

A punctate hemorrhagic spot, approximately 1–2 mm in diameter.

Plaque

An elevated circumscribed lesion >1 cm diameter; its surface is usually flat. Plaques may form from coalesced papules.

Poikiloderma

The association of cutaneous pigmentation, and telangiectasia.

Pustule

A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. 

Pyoderma

Any purulent skin disease

Scale

Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated of stratum corneum.

Scar

Replacement by fibrous tissue of another tissue that has been destroyed by injury or disease

An atrophic scar is thin and wrinkled.

A hypertrophic scar is elevated, with excessive growth of fibrous tissue.

Sclerosis

Diffuse or circumscribed induration of the subcutaneous tissues. It may also involve the dermis, when the overlying epidermis may be atrophic. It is characteristically seen in scleroderma.

Sinus

A cavity or track with a blind ending

Target lesions

These are <3 cm in diameter and have three or more zones, usually a central area of dusky erythema or purpura, a middle paler zone of edema, and an outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Tumor

Literally a swelling; the term is used to imply enlargement of the tissues by normal or pathological material, or cells that form a mass. 

Ulcer (of skin)

A loss of dermis and epidermis, often with loss of the underlying tissues
Vesicles and Bullae

 A vesicle is a circumscribed elevation <1 cm in diameter that contains fluid

Bullae are >1 cm in diameter
Wheal  A transient elevation of the skin due to dermal and hypodermal, often pale centrally with an erythematous rim; it is the characteristic lesion of urticaria.

 *While Rook's textbook of Dermatology,9th edition mention nodule as >0.5 cm. Some authors define nodules as >1 cm.

questions.text: An infant presented with anemia. A blood test was performed where 0.36% saline was added to the blood sample. The control and test results are shown below. What is this test used for?

choices.text: Testing spheroidal red cell in spherocytosis
Red cell lysis for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

questions.solution:
The given image shows NESTROFT i.e. Naked eye single tube red cell osmotic fragility test. It is a very useful screening tool for thalassemia, particularly in poor resource settings.

The principle is based on the decreased osmotic fragility of red cells in thalassemia. The normal red blood cells lyse in a test tube with 0.36% saline solution. If this test tube is held against a white paper with a thin black line, the line will be visible. However, in the beta-thalassemia trait, due to decreased osmotic fragility, the cells do not lyse in 0.36% saline solution. Therefore, if this test tube is held against a white paper with a thin black line, the line will not be visible.

NESTROFT Inference Reason
Lines visible (negative) Normal Hemolysis has occurred
Lines not seen (positive) Thalassemia Stable RBC, unable to lyse

The image given below shows the NESTROFT.

Thalassemia is a group of hereditary disorders in which there is a reduced synthesis of one or more of the globin polypeptide chains.

The hematological findings in thalassemia are:

  • microcytic hypochromic anemia
  • raised unconjugated bilirubin
  • reticulocytosis
  • reduced MCV, MCH, and MCHC
  • decreased osmotic fragility
  • hemoglobin electrophoresis will show increased levels of HbF and HbA2 with markedly decreased levels of normal hemoglobin.

Other options:

Option A- Demonstration of sickling in sickle cell trait is done under reduced oxygen tension by sodium metabisulfite which is an oxygen-consuming reagent. The patients with sickle cell trait have no anemia and have normal-appearing red cells. They develop sickle cell crises in hypoxic conditions. 

Option C- Osmotic fragility test is helpful in testing the spheroidal nature of red cells in hereditary spherocytosis. In hereditary spherocytosis, osmotic fragility is increased since spheroidal red cells lyse more readily in solutions of low salt concentrations. 

Option D- Red cell lysis in acidic pH of Ham's test is to demonstrate the presence of increased sensitivity of red blood cells, leucocytes, and platelets to complement in PNH. 

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Alpha or beta thalassemia Anemia of Chronic Disease
Serum Iron <60 µg/dL Normal/Increased Decreased
Serum Ferritin <20 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased
MCV Decreased  Decreased Normal/Decreased
RBC count Decreased Normal/Increased Normal/Increased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity 

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

The table below describes the features of typical thalassemia syndromes:

"-" denotes deletion of an alpha gene and "α" denotes normal alpha gene and "α* " refers to a mutant alpha chain gene.

β0 refers to no beta-globin production; β+ refers to decreased beta-globin production.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old primigravida comes to the clinic at 31-weeks gestation with complaints of intolerable pruritus at night, particularly in her palms and soles. She also has right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and poor appetite. Her laboratory investigations are shown below. Which of the following is the appropriate management for her condition?
Liver Function Tests Values
Bilirubin (mg/dL) 4
Aspartate aminotransferase (U/L) 180
Alanine aminotransferase (U/L) 200
Alkaline phosphatase (U/L) 250
Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (U/L) 60
Albumin (g/dL) 3
Prothrombin time (s) 11

An infectious disease panel is negative.
questions.solution:
This patient at 31 weeks gestation with intolerable pruritus over her palms and soles at night, right upper quadrant pain, nausea, poor appetite, and abnormal liver function tests is likely to have intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy. 

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is also known as recurrent jaundice of pregnancy, icterus gravidarum, or cholestatic hepatosis. It occurs during the late 2nd and early 3rd trimesters. The etiology is not well understood but is thought to be due to a relation between the cholestatic properties of reproductive hormones in genetically susceptible women. 

It usually presents with intense pruritus after 30 weeks of gestation over the palms and soles and is worse at night. Other symptoms include anorexia, nausea, fatigue, right upper quadrant pain, dark urine, and pale stool. 

Hyperbilirubinemia results from retention of conjugated pigment, but total plasma concentrations rarely exceed 4 to 5 mg/dL. Serum transaminase levels are normal to moderately elevated and may occasionally reach levels up to 1000 mg/dL. Alkaline phosphatase levels are usually elevated. Liver biopsy shows mild cholestasis with bile plugs in the hepatocytes and canaliculi of the centrilobular region.

Management:

  • Antihistamines and topical emollients 
  • Cholestyramine
  • Ursodeoxycholic acid

Disorder

 AST (SGOT) U/L Bilirubin (mg/dL)
Cholestasis of pregnancy Upto 200 usually but may be higher in certain cases 1–5
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy 200–800 4–10
Hepatitis 2000+ 5–20

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhea. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history along with the moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

Symptomatic intrauterine adhesions (also termed uterine synechiae) are known as Asherman syndrome. This condition occurs when the uterine cavity is obliterated by scarring due to filmy adhesions, dense bands. Endometrial damage can occur after curettage, infection due to an intrauterine device, uterine surgery, or rarely tuberculous endometritis. 

In Asherman syndrome, oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, dysmenorrhea, abortion, and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae.

Treatment involves hysteroscopic lysis of the adhesions.

questions.text:
Match the following hormones present in column A with their mechanism of action present in column B.
Hormones Mechanism of action
1. Follicle-stimulating hormone a. Nuclear receptors
2. Oxytocin b. GPCR mediated activation of adenylyl cyclase
3. Thyroid hormone c. Tyrosine kinase signaling
4. Growth hormone d. GPCR mediated activation of phospholipase C
  e. Ion channel linked receptors

(GPCR- G protein coupled receptors)
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c.

Hormones can exert their action by:

Binding to ion channels- Eg acetylcholine, norepinephrine

Binding to G-protein coupled receptors- Hormones binding to GPCRs can act either by adenylyl cyclase–cAMP second messenger system. Examples are:

  • Angiotensin II (epithelial cells)
  • Catecholamines (beta receptors)
  • Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)
  • Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
  • Luteinizing hormone (LH)
  • Calcitonin
  • Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)
  • Vasopressin (V2 receptor)

or by activating phospholipase C. Examples are

  • Angiotensin II (vascular smooth muscle)
  • Catecholamines (α receptors)
  • Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH)
  • Oxytocin
  • Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH)
  • Vasopressin (V1 receptor)

or by activating Calmodulin, Calcium dependant kinases:

  • Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)
  • Glucagon
  • Parathyroid hormone (PTH)
  • PTHrp
  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH)
  • Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH)
  • Melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH)

Tyrosine kinase receptor signalling

  • Growth hormone
  • Insulin
  • Insulin-like growth factor-1
  • Leptin
  • Prolactin

Binding to cytoplasmic receptors- Steroid hormones

Binding to nuclear receptors- Thyroid hormones

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens

Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP
