GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Oxytocin
Acetylcholine (M1, M3, M5)
cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
Nitric oxide
2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: A male baby born to a non-consanguineous couple was brought to you with the complaints of severe blistering formed after minor mechanical traumas. You suspect epidermolysis bullosa simplex in this child. Which of the following keratin heterodimers will be affected due to mutation in the genes leading to this condition?
questions.solution:
The mutations in the genes for keratin 5 and 14 are associated with epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS).

Keratin is a complex protein produced by keratinocytes. It is a major component of our hair and nails, and also the stratum corneum of the skin.

Keratin filaments exist as combinations of one acidic and one basic filament.

Note:

Keratin Heterodimer Site
K5/14 Stratum Basale
K1/10 Stratum Spinosum
K3/K12 Cornea- Eye
K4/K13 Buccal Mucosa
K8/18 Simple Epithelium

 

Note: Epidermolysis bullosa is a disorder in which blisters develop in areas of minor trauma. It results from the congenital absence of proteins that help to maintain the structure of the epidermis and also those that connect the dermis and epidermis. There are three types of epidermolysis bullosa-

  • Epidermolysis bullosa simplex - where the defect is in K5/K14
  • Junctional epidermolysis bullosa - where the defect is in Laminin
  • Dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa - where the defect is in Collagen-7

Related Pearl: Dermoepidermal Junction/Basement Membrane Zone

  • The junction between epidermis and dermis is called the basement membrane zone or dermoepidermal junction and consists of a number of extracellular macromolecules.
  • As many of these components are glycoproteins, the BMZ can be recognized histologically by staining with PAS stain.
  • Ultrastructural examination by electron microscopy shows 2 different layers with different optical densities
    • Lamina Lucida - upper, less electron dense layer
    • Lamina Densa - lower, more electron dense layer
  • This zone is composed of 3 components : 1. Hemidesmosome 2. Anchoring Filaments 3. Anchoring Fibrils.

1.HEMIDESMOSOME

  • Hemidesmosomes are multiprotein complexes that facilitate the stable adhesion of basal epithelial cells to the underlying basement membrane.
  • The intermediate keratin filaments K5/K14 present within the basal keratinocytes attach to the hemidesmosomes at the base of the cell.
  • The major hemidesmosomal Protein is Bullous Pemphigoid Antigen-1 (BPAg1 or BP230) and this attaches to the transmembrane component protein BPAg2 (BP180) below.
  • The other hemidesmosomal protein Plectin is attached to the transmembrane component protein called as α6β4 integrin below.

2.ANCHORING FILAMENTS/Lamina Lucida and Lamina Densa

  • The anchoring filaments form the Lamina Lucida layer.
  • Anchoring filaments consist of Laminin5/332 proteins that connect BPAg2 and α6β4 integrin above to Lamina Densa below.
  • Lamina Densa consists mainly of type IV Collagen and other proteins like Nidogen.  

3.ANCHORING FIBRILS

  • These are ultrastructurally U shaped structures that attach the Lamina Densa above to the underlying connective tissue below in dermis.
  • Type VII Collagen is the major protein in anchoring fibrils.

Blistering disorders in the DEJ/BMZ arise due to defects or antibodies against any of the above mentioned proteins.

Image: Gene/protein systems within the cutaneous basement membrane zone that can harbour mutations and result in blistering of the skin in different forms of epidermolysis bullosa (EB). BP, bullous pemphigoid

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented with watering, pain, and photophobia in his left eye for the past 6 weeks. He reported having similar episodes in the past. The results of fluorescein staining of his left eye are shown in the image below. Which of the following is not true regarding the patient's condition?

choices.text: It is caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV).
Antivirals are the first line of therapy.
It is a linear branching ulcer with tapered ends.

questions.solution:
The above image shows a dendritic corneal ulcer, which is an irregular, zigzag linear branching ulcer with knobbed ends (not tapered ends) as seen in the image as well.

A dendritic corneal ulcer is pathognomonic of the herpes simplex infection.

Herpetic simplex keratitis, also known as herpetic keratoconjunctivitis and herpes viral keratitis, is a form of keratitis caused by recurrent herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection in the cornea. (Option A)

Signs & Symptoms:

  • The classic herpetic lesion consists of a linear branching corneal ulcer (dendritic ulcer). The ulcer is initially superficial and spreads in all directions as grey striae, which extend and increase in length. 
  • Patients with epithelial keratitis complain of foreign-body sensation, light sensitivity, redness, and blurred vision associated with focal or diffuse reduction in corneal sensation. (Option B)
  • In patients who are immunocompromised due to pre-existing disease or using corticosteroids, the ulcer may become large; in such cases, the lesion is called a geographic ulcer.
  • Stromal keratitis manifests as a disc-shaped area of corneal edema.

Treatment:

Topical antivirals are the first-line treatment. (Option C)

  • Trifluorothymidine 1% drops four times a day for 5 days, acyclovir 3% ointment five times a day for 21 days, or 3% vidarabine ointment five times a day for 2 weeks
  • Systemic antivirals in cases of increased severity or recurrence
  • Topical antibiotics to prevent secondary bacterial infection

Related Pearl: Ocular lesions of Herpes Simplex

Primary herpes:

  • Cornea
    • Fine epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Coarse epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
  • Conjunctiva: acute follicular conjunctivitis
  • Skin lesions

Recurrent herpes:

  • Active epithelial keratitis
    • Punctate epithelial keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
    • Geographical ulcer
  • Stromal keratitis
  • Disciform keratitis
  • Diffuse stromal necrotic keratitis
  • Trophic keratitis (meta-herpetic)
  • Herpetic iridocyclitis

questions.text: Activation of which of the following caspases occurs in pyroptosis?
questions.solution:
Pyroptosis is a form of apoptosis that occurs due to the activation of caspase 1.

Pyroptosis occurs due to the release of fever-inducing cytokine interleukin-1 (IL-1). Cytoplasmic innate immune receptors recognize microbial products that entered the infected cells and activate the multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. Inflammasome activates caspase 1 and helps in the release of the biologically activated forms of IL-1. Along with caspase 1, caspases 4 and 5 also induce cell death. Unlike classical apoptosis, pyroptosis is characterized by the release of inflammatory mediators. 

Apoptosis- The intrinsic mitochondrial and extrinsic death receptor-initiated pathways converge to activate a caspase cascade that mediates the final phase of apoptosis. The intrinsic pathway activates caspase 9 whereas the extrinsic pathway activates caspases 8 and 10. These caspases then activate caspase 3, and caspase 6. Activated caspases cause DNA degradation and nuclei fragmentation.

Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent distinct pathway of cell death induced by lipid peroxidation. The widespread peroxidation disrupts membrane function which leads to the loss of plasma membrane permeability and results in cell death resembling necrosis. 

Necroptosis, as the name suggests has features similar to necrosis and apoptosis. Like necrosis, it is characterized by loss of ATP, cellular and organelle swelling, the release of lysosomal enzymes, and rupture of the plasma membrane. However, like apoptosis, this is programmed cell death. Ligation of TNFR1 initiates necroptosis. This is a caspase-independent programmed cell death.

questions.text: A toddler has been consuming excessive amounts of vitamin A-containing foods in the diet. The child has dry-flaky skin, frequent headaches,  episodic vomiting, and splenomegaly. Which of the following findings would likely be seen on taking an X-ray of the long bones?
questions.solution:
The history of excessive vitamin A consumption along with scaly, itchy skin, headache, vomiting (suggestive of pseudotumor cerebri), and splenomegaly, all point towards a diagnosis of hypervitaminosis A. In this condition, x-ray of the long bones would most likely show hyperostosis.

Hypervitaminosis A refers to the excessive consumption of vitamin A. Amounts greater than 6,000 micrograms per day in children can be toxic (>15,000 micrograms in adults). Since there is no way to degrade the excess vitamin A, it gets stored in the liver and various other tissues. This stored vitamin will continue to exert toxic effects on the body, even if consumption is stopped. In young children, hypervitaminosis A can present with headache, vomiting, and even bulging fontanelles. Pseudotumor cerebri (with elevated intracranial pressure), can present with diplopia and even papilledema. There can also be patches of itchy, desquamating skin. Abdominal examination may reveal hepatosplenomegaly.

Bones may show hyperostosis on x-ray. This is an overgrowth of bone, commonly along the middle part of the shafts of long bones. 

Stopping further consumption is the only way to manage this condition.

The image below depicts hyperostosis-

 

Other options-

Option (A): Salt and pepper sign is seen in the skull in primary hyperparathyroidism. This disorder causes demineralization and resorption of bone, resulting in pathological fractures, bone erosions, etc. 

The image below shows the salt and paper appearance of the skull-

 

Option (C): Bone cysts can be simple or aneurysmal. They are usually incidental findings on radiographs. Sometimes these cysts can present with pain due to recurrent bleeding or pathological fractures. Bones cysts can sometimes be seen in hyperparathyroidism as well.

The image below depicts a bone cyst in the humerus-

 

Option (D): Decreased bone density can be seen most commonly in osteoporosis. The most common causes for this decreased bone mineral density are- vitamin D deficiency, gonadal sex steroid deficiency, hyperparathyroidism, decreased bone formation with age, etc. Hypervitaminosis A causes the opposite in the form of hyperostosis.

The image below demonstrates decreased bone density in osteoporosis-

Related Pearl: Hypervitaminosis A

Hypervitaminosis A:

  • Vitamin A excess can present as two forms: vitamin A toxicity and carotenaemia.
  •  Hypervitaminosis A results from overconsumption of non‐prescription nutritional supplements, prescription medications containing vitamin A derivatives and foods high in vitamin A.
  • Carotenaemia is a benign disorder caused by excessive β‐carotene intake.
  • In carotenaemia, carotenes are excreted from sebaceous glands and sweat glands, and ultimately deposit in the stratum corneum. This results in carotenoderma.
  • Acute vitamin A toxicity manifests with headaches, vision changes, fatigue, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, myalgias and arthralgias. Weight loss can be observed with chronic intoxication.
  • Individuals with chronic hypervitaminosis A have dry and scaly skin, desquamation, cheilitis, alopecia, follicular hyperkeratosis and hyperpigmentation, associated pseudotumor cerebri and skeletal changes (premature closure of the epiphyses and pathological bone fractures).
  • Prognosis:
    • Vitamin A toxicity: discontinuation of vitamin A leads to resolution of almost all symptoms of vitamin A toxicity, with the exception of cirrhosis and sequelae related to pseudotumour cerebri.
    • Carotenaemia: Excellent prognosis with no clear long‐term adverse effects. Pigmentary changes resolve within weeks to months of decreasing β‐carotene intake.

questions.text: Identify the instrument in the given image that is used in spinal fusion surgery.
questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image, used in spinal fusion surgery is a polyaxial pedicle screw. 

Pedicle screws are used in a spinal fusion to add extra support and strength to the fusion while it heals. They are placed above and below the vertebrae that were fused. Rods are used to connect the screws which prevent the movement and allows the bone to heal. The Xray below shows a pedicle screw 

Other options: 

Option A- Herbert screw is a headless screw often used for the fixation of unstable scaphoid fractures. It is cannulated and threaded at both ends.  The proximal portion has a wider pitch to its thread. This screw is used where a standard screw would impinge on adjacent tissues. It is designed to fix fractures of small articular bones such as the carpals and the scaphoid.

Option B: The Kuntscher's cloverleaf intra-medullary nail (K-nail) is used for internal fixation of femoral fractures. The eye at the end of the nail is useful during its removal and the cloverleaf shape on the cross-section provides good rotational stability.

Option D: Acutrax screw is used for the treatment of most scaphoid fractures.  It is a cannulated, headless, and fully threaded screw.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient presented with features of quadriparesis for one year he now presents with dysarthria. On examination,  the deep tendon reflexes were absent. His sensory perceptions and the autonomic system are intact.  Which of the following is the only drug known to improve survival in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The only known drug to have a positive impact on survival in ALS patients is riluzole.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is the most common progressive motor neuron disease. It occurs due to the death of the affected corticospinal upper motor neurons(UMN) of the motor cortex, lower motor neurons(LMN) of the anterior horn of the spine, and cranial nerves innervating the bulbar muscles.

 Clinically, the patient presents with :

  • LMN findings: fasciculations, muscle cramps, asymmetric distal weakness, atrophy of the muscles 
  • UMN findings: spasticity, increased reflexes.
  • Cranial nerve findings: Difficulty in speaking, chewing, swallowing, breathing, and slurred speech
  • Pseudobulbar affect: degeneration of corticobulbar projections manifested as inappropriate laughing, crying, or yawning which is often mood incongruent or may be triggered by stimuli that would not have elicited such a response.

Interestingly, even during the late stages sensory, bowel and bladder, ocular motility, and cognitive functions are preserved.

Treatment of ALS:

  1. Riluzole (100mg/day) reduces excitotoxicity by diminishing glutamate release and improving survival.
  2. Edaravone is a newer drug approved by the FDA that has the capability of slowing down ALS progression and improving survival.

Other options:

Option A: IV immunoglobulin is the recommended initial therapy for patients in the treatment of Guillain-Barre syndrome(GBS).

Option C: Memantine is used in Alzheimer's disease.

Option D: Ropinirole is a dopaminergic agonist approved for Parkinson's disease and restless leg syndrome.

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presented with severe jaundice. On examination, he had a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant. Investigations revealed cholestatic jaundice, elevated liver enzymes, and imaging findings as shown below. According to the Todani classification used in this disease, which type opens into the duodenum?
questions.solution:
The clinical history, as well as the imaging findings shown above, suggest a diagnosis of choledochal cyst. According to the Todani classification, it is the type III cyst that opens as a choledochocele into the duodenum.

The clinical picture of cholestatic jaundice and liver dysfunction, with a right upper quadrant palpable mass in a young infant, suggests a possible diagnosis of choledochal cyst. The MRCP (magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatoicography) images shown above in coronal (a) and transverse (b) sections depict type Ia saccular choledochal cysts. The classification system used is called the Todani classification. It is as follows-

Todani classification:

  • Type I- saccular dilatation of the whole (Ia) or a segment (Ib) of the common bile duct (CBD)
  • Type II- diverticulum from the CBD
  • Type III- choledochocele that opens into the duodenum
  • Type IV- multiple cysts (both intrahepatic and extrahepatic)
  • Type V- multiple cysts that are only intrahepatic (Caroli's disease)

Based on this classification, we can see that type III would be the right answer in this case i.e. the type that opens into the duodenum.

The diagnosis is made initially with a right upper quadrant ultrasound, following which a confirmatory MRCP can be carried out to help in pre-operative planning. 

Treatment is usually surgical with a Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy with radical resection of all the biliary tissue. There is a risk of malignant transformation in long-standing disease, so surgical removal is usually recommended.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: A research fellow in biochemistry is studying the lac operon concept of gene regulation. He cultures E. coli. in a glucose-deficient and lactose-containing medium. Which of the following genes expressed in this condition helps convert lactose to galactose and glucose?
questions.solution:
The gene marked as 2 is the lac Z gene, which codes for β-galactosidase. This enzyme converts lactose to galactose and glucose.

Lac operon concept

Jacob and Monod studied the Lac operon model, which is the regulation of lactose metabolism by the intestinal bacterium Escherichia coli. It is switched on when the bacteria have to utilize lactose for utilization. Otherwise, it is switched off. It contains the following genes:

  • lac I- it codes for the repressor protein
  • cAMP response element (CRE)- It is activated by binding the cyclic AMP activator protein (CAP). When activated, it increases the binding of RNA polymerase and increases gene expression.
  • Promoter site- It is the site where RNA polymerase binds the gene for transcription. 
  • Operator site- It is the site where repressor protein binds.
  • lac Z gene- It codes for β-Galactosidase that hydrolyzes lactose to galactose and glucose. 
  • lac Y- It encodes for lactose permease, which increases the permeability of lactose into the cells.
  • lac A- It encodes for thiogalactoside transacetylase. 

For the working of Lac operon, the operator site should be free and the CRE site should be activated.

1. When glucose is present and lactose is absent- The bacteria utilize glucose. The lac I gene produces repressor protein, which binds to the operator site. Repressor-operator binding prevents the binding of RNA polymerase and, consequently, prevents transcription of the lacZ, lacY, and lacA structural genes into a polycistronic mRNA. 

In addition to this, excess glucose inhibits adenylyl cyclase. Therefore, the production of cAMP is reduced. Less cAMP means less cyclic AMP activator protein (CAP) binding to CRE. CRE is not activated, and lac operon is switched off.

2. When glucose is absent and lactose is present- Bacteria utilize lactose. The lactose inactivates the repressor protein. This prevents the binding of repressor protein to the operator site. The operator site is now free and RNA polymerase can start with the transcription. The low glucose level causes an increase in the adenylyl cyclase activity, and increases the cAMP levels. This increases the binding of CAP to CRE, which in turn activates the transcription of the lacZ, lacY, and lacA structural genes into polycistronic mRNA. 

3. When both glucose and lactose are present- The bacteria utilize glucose. The unused lactose binds to the repressor protein and renders it inactive. The operator site is free. However, the increased glucose level inhibits adenylyl cyclase and decreases the cAMP levels. Therefore, even though the operator site is free, CRE is not activated, which leads to the switching off of the lac operon.

Related Pearl: Difference between Lac & tryptophan operon

Lac Operon

Tryptophan Operon

Inducible gene complex

Repressible gene complex

Catabolic system

Anabolic system

Contain 3 structural genes

Contains 5 structural gene

Produce 3 inducible enzymes

Produce 5 Repressible enzymes

Repressor protein is active

Repressor protein is inactive

High lactose turn transcription on , in low glucose level

High tryptophan transcription off

Lactose act as inducer

Tryptophan act as co-repressor

Has only 1 type of gene regulation-Negative  control

Has only 1 type of gene regulation-Negative control

Usually OFF, Get activated under certain conditions

Usually ON, inactive at high level of tryptophan.

cAMP is necessary for CAP to switch transcription on

cAMP is not  necessary

questions.text: An 89-year-old woman was seen dead at home. Her bloodstained clothes were sent for examination to your forensic laboratory. On adding a reagent, feathery crystals of hemochromogen arranged in clusters appeared in 5 minutes.  What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The test done in the above scenario is the Takayama test.

The Takayama test or hemochromogen crystal test is a microchemical test used to detect bloodstains. The stain used is Takayama reagent. If bloodstain is present, pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen or reduced alkaline hematin appear in a few minutes. The test is negative if the crystals are not formed in 30 minutes. This test is more reliable and gives positive results with old stains.

Other options:

Option B: The Teichmann test or hemin crystal test is also a test used to detect bloodstains. The stain used glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride. If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of hemin or hematin chloride appear. When hydrogen peroxide is added, the hematin crystals give bubbles of gas.

Option C: The Barberio test is used to detect seminal fluid. When a saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Option D: The Florence test is used to detect the presence of semen. The stain used is 10% hydrochloric acid and Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water). If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: An ophthalmology resident while presenting the seminar on staphyloma presents the following image showing different types of staphyloma. The type of staphyloma occurring at point A, at the limbus, is known as :
questions.solution:
The type of staphyloma occurring at point A is known as intercalary staphyloma. It is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior-most part of the ciliary body.

The patient usually has defective vision due to marked corneal astigmatism. The treatment consists of localised staphylectomy under heavy doses of oral steroids.

In the above image:

A: Intercalary staphyloma
B: Ciliary staphyloma
C: Equatorial staphyloma
D: Posterior staphyloma

Staphyloma:

It is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera.

  • It is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.
  • Types of Staphyloma:
    • Anterior staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of the pseudo-cornea, which occurs after the total sloughing of the cornea. It is lined internally by the iris and externally by the newly formed epithelium.
    • Intercalary staphyloma: This is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior-most part of the ciliary body
    • Ciliary staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone, which includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus.
    • Equatorial staphyloma: This occurs at the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye.
    • Posterior staphyloma: This affects the posterior pole of the eye.
  • Note :
    • The most common cause of anterior staphyloma is a sloughing corneal ulcer.
    • The most common cause of posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.

The image given below shows the various anatomical types of staphyloma.

questions.text: One of your relatives brought his friend's liver test report to get your opinion, as you recently completed your MBBS. The report, amongst other things, mentions the presence of Mallory-Denk inclusion bodies. You would suspect all of the following conditions, except?
questions.solution:
Mallory-Denk inclusion bodies are not seen in acute viral hepatitis but Councilman bodies are seen.

Mallory-Denk bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies due to the aggregation of cytoskeletal intermediate filaments. They appear as clumped, amorphous, eosinophilic material within ballooned hepatocytes. They are seen in,

  • Alcoholic liver disease
  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease
  • Wilson disease
  • Chronic biliary tract diseases.

Note: 

A councilman body, also known as the councilman hyaline body or apoptotic body, is an acidophilic (eosinophilic) globule of cells that represents a dying hepatocyte often surrounded by normal parenchyma.

Related Pearl: Mallory Bodies vs. Councilman Bodies

Mallory bodies Councilman bodies
Intra-cytoplasmic inclusions  Acidophilic apoptotic bodies
Due to aggregation of cytoskeletal intermediate filament  Due to hepatocyte apoptosis  

Appears as clumped, amorphous, eosinophilic material within ballooned hepatocytes.

 Entire hepatocyte shrinks and appears as intense eosinophilic stained bodies

Seen in

  • Alcoholic hepatitis
  • Primary biliary cholangitis 
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
  • Indian childhood cirrhosis
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma 

Seen in  

  • Acute viral hepatitis
  • Yellow fever

Mallory bodies seen as clumped, amorphous eosinophilic material within ballooned hepatocytes

Councilman bodies where the entire cell is shrunken into intense eosinophilic apoptotic body

questions.text: A young woman developed sudden onset congestive heart failure. Her condition rapidly deteriorated and she died after a few days. Autopsy of the heart showed patchy interstitial infiltrates composed mainly of lymphocytes, some of which surrounded individual myocytes. What is the most common cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the autopsy showed patchy interstitial infiltrates composed mainly of lymphocytes is suggestive of viral myocarditis.

Viral myocarditis is the most common cause of inflammation of the myocardium. The most common viral causes are coxsackieviruses A and B, echovirus, and influenza virus. Most patients recover from acute myocarditis, but a few may die from congestive heart failure or arrhythmias.

On gross examination, the heart appears normal or dilated. Sections of the heart show interstitial inflammatory infiltrate with focal myocyte necrosis. There is a predominant lymphocytic infiltration. 

Other options:

Option A-  Giant cell myocarditis is characterized by granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells (fused macrophages) interspersed with lymphocytes, eosinophils, plasma cells, and macrophages.

Option B- Protozoal myocarditis occurs in Chagas disease (Trypanosoma cruzi), toxoplasmosis, etc. Histopathology will show the presence of parasites in the myofibers along with infiltrates of neutrophils, lymphocytes, and macrophages. 

Option C- Hypersensitivity myocarditis is caused due to hypersensitivity reactions to several drugs. The inflammatory infiltrate includes many eosinophils, and the infiltrate is principally perivascular.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man who is a shop owner earns Rs. 19,000/- month. He is the only one in his family with income. He has attained his middle school certificate. According to Kuppuswamy's modified socioeconomic status scale, the total score was 12. In which of the socio-economic class he belong to?
questions.solution:
Based on the modified Kuppuswamy socioeconomic status scale, a total score of 12 belongs to the lower-middle socio-economic class or class III.

Socio-economic status has been defined as the position that an individual or family occupies with reference to the prevailing average standards of cultural and material possessions, income, and participation in any group activity of the community.

The modified version of Kuppuswamy's socioeconomic status scale for 2019 helps to measure an individual's socioeconomic status and class.

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamy’s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Scale

Used for:

BG Prasad scale

Urban and rural areas

Kuppuswamy scale

Urban and peri-urban areas

Uday Pareek

Rural areas

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

Modified Kuppuswamy scale(2019):

questions.text: A woman presents with a high fever, vomiting, and one episode of seizures. She appears confused. She is a known case of Graves' disease with medication non-compliance.  For the past few days, she has been feeling feverish and had a cough. On examination, she has warm, moist skin, and tremors. The cardiac monitor shows some arrhythmias. Which of the following is not part of the treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient who has Graves' disease and an acute infection, now presents with high-grade fever, vomiting, one episode of seizure, and confusion. This is suggestive of a thyroid storm or thyrotoxic crisis. Management will not include Liothyronine. The patient is already in a state of thyrotoxicosis, in such cases, the addition of the most active form of thyroid hormone will be detrimental.

L3/ Liothyronine has a rapid onset of action and is indicated only in conditions where rapid action is preferred like rare cases of myxedema coma.

A thyroid storm is a rare but severe life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism. It is an acute hypermetabolic state induced by the release of excessive thyroid hormones. Crisis can be due to surgical or medical causes.

Causes:

  • Thyroidectomy
  • Stress
  • Infection
  • Trauma
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Emergency surgery
  • Drugs like anticholinergics or antiadrenergic or NSAIDs or chemotherapy

Features: They present 12–24 hours after surgery, but can occur on the table also.

  • General: Hyperpyrexia (> 41°C), severe dehydration
  • Cardiovascular: Circulatory collapse, hypotension, palpitations, tachycardia, cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac failure
  • Respiratory: Tachypnoea, hyperventilation
  • GI symptoms: vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice.
  • Neurological symptoms: restlessness, irritability, delirium, tremor, convulsions, and coma 
  • Bailey’s symptom complex of thyroid storm is – insomnia, anorexia, diarrhoea, vomiting, sweating, emotional instability, fever, tachycardia, aggravated toxic features, multiorgan dysfunction.

Differential diagnoses are—malignant hyperpyrexia, septic shock, anxious status, cardiac disorders.

Investigations:

  • Raised T3, T4, suppressed TSH
  • Raised serum calcium
  • ECG and echocardiography show arrhythmias 
  • Raised total count
  • Altered liver function tests
  • Arterial blood gas (ABG) shows acid-base imbalance 

Treatment:

  • Supportive measures –
    • rehydration by proper fluid therapy, tepid sponging, cooling blankets
    • Antipyretics like a paracetamol IV infusion
    • Glucocorticoids (Hydrocortisone 500 mg IV or dexamethasone injections)
    • IV dextrose infusion as there is more metabolic demand
    • Correction of electrolytes
    • Treating cardiac arrhythmias in the ICU care with ventilator support.
    • Central line, CVP monitor, nasogastric tube, the urinary catheter should be placed.
  • Antiadrenergic drugs – Propranolol is used to reduce tachycardia and other adrenergic manifestations. It also reduces the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. If propranolol is contraindicated, atenolol or metoprolol can be used
  • Thionamides – propylthiouracil (PTU) or methimazole or carbimazole is used.
  • Iodide compounds – Lugol’s iodide or potassium iodide is given one hour after intake of thionamides. Potassium iodide inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis by Wolff- Chaikoff effect. Large doses of iodide inhibit organic binding of the iodide and hence decrease thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • Bile acid suppressants to prevent reabsorption of thyroid hormone from the gut – cholestyramine. Iodinated radiocontrast dyes like iopanoic acid is also beneficial. Lithium carbonate 300 mg 6th hourly is also useful.
  • Digitoxin, cardiac monitoring is crucial.
  • Treating specific causes 
  • Other measures—Hemodialysis, plasmapheresis, exchange transfusion, charcoal plasma perfusion are other methods used to control the storm.

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

Treatment of thyroid storm:

Treatment modality Effect
IV Fluids, ice packs Rehydration and external cooling
Propylthiouracil
(DOC)

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Propranolol

Block adrenergic effects

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Corticosteroids

Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland
Digoxin Controls the associated atrial fibrillation
Diuretics and administration of oxygen

To manage cardiac failure

Related Pearl: Radioiodine uptake of thyroid gland

Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scans are interpreted as follows:

  • High (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone. Therefore, there is increased hormone synthesis
  • Low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates:
    • Inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of the preformed hormone into the circulation
    • Extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone

Conditions with high and low RAIU are given below:

High RAIU Low RAIU
  • Graves’ disease
  • Toxic multinodular goiter
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Thyroid cancer
  • Hydatidiform mole
  • TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma

 

 

 
  • Acute phase of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
  • Drug-induced— iodine, amiodarone-induced thyroiditis
  • Subacute/ Dequervain thyroiditis
  • Radiation thyroiditis
  • Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
  • Factitious (iatrogenic) thyrotoxicosis
  • Struma ovarii (extrathyroid source)
  • Hamburger thyrotoxicosis (exogenous source)

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with difficulty swallowing, excessive tiredness, and loss of weight over the last few months. After further blood investigations and imaging, a diagnosis of Plummer-Vinson syndrome was made. Which of the following findings is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
An esophageal web is likely to be seen in a patient with Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

Plummer-Vinson syndrome is also known as Paterson-Brown-Kelly syndrome. It is typically seen in women over 40 years of age. It includes the following features:

  • Dysphagia 
  • Iron-deficiency anemia
  • Glossitis
  • Angular stomatitis
  • Koilonychia
  • Achlorhydria

The esophageal webs refer to esophageal constrictions caused by an atrophic mucosal membrane projecting into the lumen formed due to subepithelial fibrosis. They are usually seen in the cervical esophagus near post cricoid region.

Plummer-Vinson syndrome is a known risk factor for post-cricoid hypopharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma.  

Other options-

Option A:  Achalasia cardia is characterized by the absence of peristalsis in the body of the esophagus and high resting pressure in the lower esophagus sphincter (LES). The LES does not relax when the patient swallows. This leads to dysphagia more to liquids than solids and regurgitation of food at night. A barium swallow will reveal a dilated esophagus with narrowed rat tail lower end called bird beak appearance. The barium swallow findings are seen in the image below. 

Option B: Diffuse esophageal spasm is a motility disorder of the esophagus. It is seen as a corkscrew appearance on a barium swallow. Esophageal manometry will show normal relaxation of the sphincter on swallowing. A barium swallow image of diffuse esophageal spasm is shown below-

Option C: Esophageal leiomyoma is a common benign tumor of the esophagus. On a barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium. A barium study with the classic semilunar filling defect in esophageal leiomyoma is shown below-

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male patient presented with a 3-week history of yellow skin and sclerae but is otherwise asymptomatic. There is a history of similar episodes 2 years back. Occasionally, he has noticed dark-colored urine. LFT is given below. A liver biopsy, stained with Fontana-Masson stain is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Serum bilirubin - 4.4 mg/dL (Predominantly conjugated)

Serum AST, ALT- Normal
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the liver biopsy showing characteristic deposition of pigment are suggestive of Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and brown-black melanin-like pigment deposition in the liver which can lead to a gross black appearance of the liver. The disease is caused by the mutation in the multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP-2) gene in hepatocytes, which is required for the transport of non-bile salt organic anions at the canalicular membranes.

Total bilirubin concentrations are typically between 2 and 5 mg/dL and can fluctuate widely in patients. Hyper-bilirubinemia may be increased by current illness, oral contraceptive use, and pregnancy. Aside from elevated serum bilirubin levels, other routine laboratory tests (eg Liver Function tests) are normal. 

Other options:

Option A: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is a type of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that occurs due to a decrease in UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UDPGT) activity. Type 1 has absent/trace UDPGT enzyme activity and type 2 has <10% of the normal UDPGT enzyme activity.

Option C: Budd Chiari syndrome is characterized by obstruction of hepatic venous outflow. It is a clinical complex characterized by hepatomegaly, ascites and abdominal pain.

Option D: Gilbert syndrome is a type of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that occurs due to reduced UDPGT enzyme activity (10-33% of Normal).

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with growth retardation and a history of recurrent attacks of hypoglycemia. On examination, you notice doll-like facies with relatively thin extremities and massive hepatomegaly. Blood examination reveals increased lactic acid, triglyceride, and uric acid levels. All of the following complications can be expected in this child except:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this clinical scenario is von Gierke’s disease. Cardiomyopathy is not a complication of von Gierke’s disease. On the contrary, cardiomyopathy is associated with Pompe's disease.

Enzyme deficient in von Gierke’s disease is glucose-6-phosphatase (common to both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis). Inheritance is autosomal recessive. 

Glycogen accumulation occurs in the liver and renal tubular cells. Clinical features include:

  • Severe hypoglycemia
  • Ketosis
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperuricemia

A definitive diagnosis is made using a liver biopsy. Fructose and galactose restriction in the diet is advised.

Complications of von Gierke's disease includes polycystic ovaries, osteopenia, hepatic adenoma, pulmonary hypertension, pancreatitis and renal failure.

questions.text: You were asked to conduct an autopsy of a 32-year-old man who succumbed to death due to poisoning. His organs can be preserved in rectified spirit in poisoning due to any of the following agents except?
questions.solution:
The organs can be preserved in rectified spirit, except in cases of suspected poisoning by kerosene.

Rectified spirit can be used to preserve tissue and organs in most cases of suspected poisoning. In suspected poisoning with the following, preservation with rectified spirit should be avoided:

  • Alcohol
  • Kerosene
  • Chloroform, ether
  • Chloral hydrate
  • Formic acid, Formaldehyde
  • Acetic acid
  • Phenol
  • Phosphorus, and
  • Paraldehyde

Other preservatives used in toxicology postmortem include:

  • Saturated NaCl solution: Avoided in poisoning from corrosive acids, alkalis, corrosive sublimate, and aconite.
  • 10 mg/ml of sodium or potassium fluoride and potassium oxalate (anti-coagulant) to preserve blood.
  • Fluoride should be added to urine, CSF, and vitreous humor if alcohol estimation is required and if analysis for cocaine, cyanide, and CO is being done.

A preservative is not necessary if :

  • The viscera can be analyzed in 24 hours
  • If the sample can be stored in a refrigerator or icebox
  • Bone, hair, nails specimens
  • Lung for inhaled poisons

The viscera should not be preserved in formaldehyde because extraction of non-volatile poisons becomes difficult.

In cases of chronic poisoning with heavy metals such as lead, arsenic, mercury, antimony, copper, etc., the shaft of a long bone, strands of scalp hair, fingernails or toenails, and a wedge of the quadriceps muscle should also be taken for sampling.

questions.text: You are an intern performing clinical rounds in the casualty. The casualty receives a call asking for arrangements to receive the patients of a road traffic accident that occurred nearby. The trauma PG wants you to assess the severity of the patients, taking the mechanism of injury into account. Which of the following scoring systems will you use?
questions.solution:
The Trauma and Injury Severity Score takes into consideration the "injury mechanism" to calculate the severity of the patient.

The components of TRISS include:

  • Injury Severity Score (ISS)
  • Revised Trauma Score (RTS)
  • Age
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)

Other options :

Injury Severity Score (ISS):

The Injury Severity Score (ISS) is calculated by summing the squares of the Abbreviated Injury Scale (AIS) severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions. The ISS ranges from 1 to 75, with severity groupings being defined as minor injury (ISS less than 9), moderate injury (ISS between 9 and 16), serious injury (ISS between 16 and 25), and severe injury (ISS more than 25). 

Revised Trauma Score (RTS):

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a well-studied physiologic scoring system that characterizes the injured patient’s condition by incorporating the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate. These scores have been of value for research purposes and have been successfully used to make triage decisions.

Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS):

The Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) is the most widely validated classification system. It takes into consideration the following,

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

A score of 7 or higher consistently predicted the need for amputation, whereas all limbs with initial scores of 6 or less remained viable in the long term.

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: Identify the false statement about tests of eustachian tube function:

choices.text: Failure of Valsalva test proves that the tube is blocked
Politzer's test is done in children unable to perform Valsava test
Tympanometry causes both positive and negative pressure

questions.solution:
Failure of the Valsalva test does not prove that the tube is blocked because only 65% of people can successfully perform this test. 

The Eustachian tube connects the nasopharynx with the tympanic cavity. The tympanic end is bony and is present in the anterior wall of the middle ear. The pharyngeal end is cartilaginous. It is raised at this end and is called a torus tubaris. It is present in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx behind the posterior end of the inferior turbinate. 

The eustachian tube performs the following functions: 

  • Ventilation and regulation of middle ear pressure
  • Protection against nasopharyngeal sound pressure and reflux of nasopharyngeal secretions
  • Clearance of middle ear secretions. 

The eustachian tube function can be assessed with the following tests: 

Valsalva test: This test builds positive pressure in the nasopharynx so the air enters the Eustachian tube. The patient pinches their nose, closes their mouth, and tries to blow air into their ears. If the air enters the middle ear, the tympanic membrane will move outwards which can be seen with the help of an otoscope or microscope. Failure of this test does not prove blockage because only 65% of people can successfully perform this test. 

It should be avoided in patients who have an atrophic scar or an active infection. 

Politzer's test is done in children who are unable to perform Valsalva's test. Here, an olive-shaped tip of the Politzer's bag is introduced into the patient's nostril on the side that is being tested. The other nostril is closed while the bag is compressed at the same time that the patient swallows. The examiner should hear a hissing sound through the auscultation tube if the tube is patent. 

Toynbee's test causes negative pressure. The patient is asked to swallow while the nose has been pinched. This maneuver draws air from the middle ear into the nasopharynx and causes inward movement of the tympanic membrane. The membrane movement is verified with an otoscope or microscope. 

Tympanometry or inflation-deflation test creates both positive and negative pressure in the external ear canal. The patient swallows repeatedly in this test. The ability of the tube to equilibrate positive and negative pressure to ambient pressure indicates normal tube function. It can be performed in patients with perforated or intact tympanic membranes. 

Other tests include catheterization, radiological test, saccharine or methylene blue test, and sonotubometry. 

Related Pearl: Measurements of EAC and ET

 

External Auditory Canal

Eustachian tube

Total length

24 mm

36 mm

Bony (close to the middle ear)

16 mm (2/3)

12 mm (1/3)

Cartilaginous

8 mm (1/3)

24 mm (2/3)

Isthmus (narrowest part)

In the bony part

At the junction

questions.text:
An elderly man presents with fatigue and weight loss. Physical examination revealed pallor and splenomegaly. Lab reports and peripheral smear is given below. Which of the following is the most likely chromosomal translocation seen in this patient?

Hb: 10 g/dL

Total leucocyte count: 1,50,000/mm3

Platelet count: 5,00,000/mm3

LAP (leucocyte alkaline phosphatase) score: low
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of fatigue, significant weight loss, splenomegaly, a TLC of 1.5 lakh/mm3, and a low LAP score all point toward the diagnosis of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). The peripheral smear showing increased white blood cells at various stages of maturation, such as myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band forms further helps to confirm the diagnosis. The chromosome translocation seen in CML is t (9;22). 

CML is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder that is common in males 55-65 years of age. It occurs due to the translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, forming the Philadelphia chromosome. This results in the activation of tyrosine kinase, which causes abnormal cellular proliferation. Common presenting features are fatigue, malaise, weight loss, and splenomegaly. 

Blood investigations show anemia, leucocytosis, and thrombocytosis. It has decreased levels of leucocyte alkaline phosphatase due to a relative increase in abnormal myeloid cells. The emergence of tyrosine kinase inhibitors as first-line therapy has dramatically improved survival for these patients. Imatinib is the most commonly used tyrosine kinase inhibitor used for CML.

Related Pearl: Leucocyte Alkaline Phosphatase Score

Alkaline phosphatase activity is found predominantly in mature segmented neutrophils. LAP score is obtained by assessing the staining intensity in 100 consecutive neutrophils, with each neutrophil scored on a scale of 1–4. 

Conditions that result in an increase in leukocytes in all stages of maturity will reflect a corresponding increase in LAP.

questions.text: A  patient with elevated blood pressure even after the medical intervention is found to have a solitary adrenal adenoma on imaging studies. A tissue sample of the adenoma taken during laparoscopic adrenalectomy is sent to the laboratory for you to examine. The histopathological picture is as shown below. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: More common in men than women
The image is showing spironolactone bodies

questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of eosinophilic, laminated cytoplasmic inclusions, known as spironolactone bodies which are found after treatment with spironolactone and the presence of a solitary adenoma is indicative of Conn syndrome. This is more common in females than males. 

Hyperaldosteronism is the increased secretion of aldosterone. It can be primary or secondary. Primary hyperaldosteronism is autonomous overproduction of aldosterone, with suppression of the renin-angiotensin system and decreased plasma renin activity. The two primary causes of primary hyperaldosteronism are adrenocortical adenoma and bilateral adrenal hyperplasia. 

When primary hyperaldosteronism is caused by a solitary aldosterone-secreting adenoma, the condition is referred to as Conn syndrome. This occurs most frequently in mid-adult life. Up to half of the cases have somatic mutations of KCNJ5 which encodes a potassium channel protein.

Pateints with primary hyperadlosteronism primarily present with hypertension and hypokalemia. The diagnosis of primary hyperaldosteronism is confirmed by elevated ratios of plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity.

Aldosterone-producing adenomas show the presence of eosinophilic, laminated cytoplasmic inclusions, known as spironolactone bodies. These spironolactone bodies are found after treatment with the antihypertensive drug spironolactone.

questions.text: You are assisting your first case of open abdominal surgery. The senior professor asked you to make the incision first. The nurse hands over a fresh set of sterilized instruments with various Bard-Parker blades. Which blade would you choose generally for making an abdominal incision?
questions.solution:
The 22-blade is often used for abdominal incisions. Essentially a larger version of the number 10, it has a flat, unsharpened back edge and a short, curved cutting edge. These blades are best for creating large incisions, often through thick skin.

Other options-

Option (A): 11-blade is used for skin incisions (eg. incision and drainage) and arteriotomy. This is also known as a stab knife. 

Option (C): 15-blade for minor surgical procedures 

Uses of 15-scalpel blade:

  • To make precise skin incisions in dermatosurgery
  • Minor surgical procedures
  • Select ocular procedures (15C blade)
  • Select plastic surgery procedures (15C blade)

Option (D): 12-blade is a small, pointed, crescent-shaped blade used typically as a suture cutter. It is most sharp on the inside edge of its curve.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
The area marked by an arrow in the given image is pterion and the artery that passes in close proximity to this area is the middle meningeal artery.

The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone.

It is an important structure as it overlies the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere. The bone in this area is thin and any injury to this area may lead to rupture of the middle meningeal artery leading to extradural hematoma.

questions.text: In the following left ventricle (LV) pressure-volume loop diagram, the aortic valve will open at point ________.
questions.solution:
The aortic valve will open at point 3.

  • 1 - Mitral valve opens
  • 2 - Mitral valve closes
  • 3 - Aortic valve opens
  • 4 - Aortic valve closes

Pressure-volume diagram during the cardiac cycle:

The pressure-volume diagram plots the changes in the pressure and volume in the left ventricle that occur during the cardiac cycle. The X-axis shows the changes in ventricular volume, while the Y-axis shows the changes in ventricular pressure.

 

It has the following phases.

Phase I- This phase is called the period of filling and extends between points A and B. Point A is at the end of systole when the ventricular volume is about 50 mL. This volume is called end-systolic volume. The pressure at this point is about 2 to 3 mmHg. The volume and pressure go on increasing as the blood from the atrium flows to the ventricle during diastole. At the end of diastole, marked by point B, the ventricle will have a volume of around 120 mL. This volume is called end-diastolic volume. The pressure is slightly raised to 5-7 mmHg. 

Phase II- It is the phase of isovolumetric contraction, and extends between points B and C. At the end of diastole (point B), a slight increase in the ventricular pressure closes the mitral valve, and contraction starts. The ventricle contracts while both mitral and aortic valves are closed. Therefore, the pressure within the ventricle slowly rises without any changes in the volume. 

Phase III- It is the phase of ejection and extends between point C and point D. Point C is the place where the aortic valve opens. The pressure within the left ventricle rises slowly during isovolumetric contraction until it is sufficient to open the aortic valve. Once the aortic valve opens, blood within the left ventricle is ejected into the aorta. This decreases the volume of the left ventricle, while increasing the pressure within the ventricle.

Phase IV- It is the period of isovolumetric relaxation. It extends between points D and A. At the end of the ejection (Point D), the aortic valve closes. However, the ventricular relaxation continues despite closed aortic and mitral valves. Therefore, the ventricular pressure continues to fall while the volume remains the same. The ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 mL of blood left in the ventricle and pressure of about 2 to 3 mmHg.

End-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESPVR)

ESPVR is the maximum pressure that can be developed by the ventricle at the end-systolic volume. It is determined by the line intersecting the upper left corners of the loops. This line can be extended down to the x-axis. The slope of this line is called as ESPVR slope.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a primary skin lesion?
questions.solution:
Image 2 depicting crusts (scabs) are not a primary lesion.

Crusts are secondary skin lesions. They consists of dried serum and other exudates.

 
Image 1

Papule is a primary skin lesion. It is an elevated solid lesion that is less than 1 cm in diameter. The only distinction between a papule and a nodule is the size (nodule >1cm).

 

Image 3

Pustule is a primary skin lesion. A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. It may occur within a pilosebaceous follicle or a sweat duct or, less often, on glabrous skin. Most commonly due to infections, but some eruptions typically cause sterile pustules.

 

Image 4

Purpura presents as a papule which is a primary skin lesion.

Purpura occurs due to small bleeds from blood vessels into the surrounding skin or mucus membranes. These lesions are bright red to begin with and later progress to purple and finally yellow-brown before disappearing.

Related Pearl: Primary and Secondary Lesions of Skin

Primary lesions of the skin include:

  • Papule
  • Plaque
  • Wheal
  • Vesicle
  • Bulla
  • Nodule
  • Macule
  • Patch
  • Purpura
  • Pustule

For mnemonic lovers, the following mnemonic might help!

'Predatory Poisonous Wasps Viciously Bit on the Nose of My Patient causing Purulent Pus'

 

Secondary lesions of the skin include:

Mnemonic- 'LEAF SUCKS water'

  • L — Lichenification
  • E — Erosion / Excoriation
  • A — Atrophy
  • F — Fissure
  • S — Scale
  • U — Ulcer
  • C — Crust
  • K — Kind-of-hard to feel (Induration)
  • S — Scar

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with severe Alzheimer's disease has been prescribed a medication that acts against the NMDA receptors in the brain. Which of the following drug belongs to this category?
questions.solution:
Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist that is used in the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease.

It is used as an adjunct or an alternative to first-line therapy. Memantine delays clinical deterioration in patients with moderate to severe Alzheimer’s disease. Adverse effects are mild headache or dizziness. It is excreted by the kidneys and the dosage should be reduced in patients with severe renal impairment.

Other options:

Option A: Galantamine is a natural alkaloid that selectively inhibits cerebral acetylcholinesterase and has some direct agonistic action on nicotinic receptors as well. It has produced cognitive and behavioral benefits in patients with Alzheimer’s disease.

Option B: Piracetam is a cyclic GABA derivative used in Alzheimer's disease. It improves the efficiency of higher telencephalic integrative activities.

Option C: Donepezil is a reversible anti-AChE that produces measurable improvement in several cognitive as well as non-cognitive (activities of daily living) scores in AD.

 

 

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: Which of the following would not favor a diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension?

choices.text: Palpable second heart sound at the left sternal border

questions.solution:
Increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) will not favor a diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). Increased PCWP will be seen in post-capillary pulmonary hypertension (PH).

Pulmonary hypertension is broadly classified into:

  • Pre-capillary PH or PAH
    • Involves the pulmonary arterial system
  • Post-capillary PH
    • Involves the pulmonary venous system
    • PCWP ≥ 15 mmHg and
    • Pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) < 3 Wood units.

Signs and symptoms of PAH

  • Dyspnoea and/or fatigue
  • Elevated JVP
  • Loud P2 (second heart sound), palpable in left second intercostal space
  • Right-sided S3 or S4
  • Murmurs in PAH
    • Tricuspid regurgitation - Holosystolic murmur
    • Pulmonary stenosis - Ejection systolic murmur
    • Pulmonary regurgitation - End diastolic murmur (Graham-Steel murmur) in severe PAH
  • Right heart failure in severe PAH - Peripheral edema, ascites, hepatomegaly.

Investigations in PAH

  • Chest X-ray
    • Enlargement of central pulmonary arteries
    • Rapid tapering of vessels known as vascular pruning
    • Right ventricular enlargement.
  • ECG
    • Features of RV strain such as right axis deviation and right ventricular hypertrophy.
  • Pulmonary function tests
    • Reduction in DLCO
    • Normal FEV1 and FVC if no underlying lung disease.
  • Definitive diagnosis of PAH is by cardiac catheterisation and will have all of the following:
    • Mean pulmonary arterial pressure, mPAP > 25mmHg (or >20 mmHg at rest)
    • PVR ≥ 3 Wood units
    • PCWP ≤ 15 mmHg. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Pulmonary Hypertension & its Causes

Based on underlying mechanisms, the World Health Organization has classified pulmonary hypertension into five groups.

Classification

Causes

Group 1

Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH)

Idiopathic PAH

questions.text: Premature ejaculation is a disorder of which phase of the normal sexual cycle?
questions.solution:
Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase of the normal sexual cycle.

Premature ejaculation is when ejaculation occurs before the completion of satisfactory sexual activity. In severe cases, it is characterized by ejaculation either before penile entry into the vagina or soon after penetration. The causes can be biological or psychological, like performance anxiety.

Related Pearl: Sexual disorders

Phase
Characteristics
Disorder
Treatment
Desire
Focuses on the patient's drives, motivation, and desires
Hypoactive sexual desire: Patients have a decrease or absence of sexual fantasies, desires, etc
 
Sexual aversion: A complete aversion to all sexual contact
Address issues like feelings of guilt, poor self-esteem, homosexual impulses, etc
 
Couples therapy may be indicated if due to marital conflict
Arousal
Consists of a sense of sexual pleasure with accompanying physiologic changes
Female sexual arousal disorder: Persistent failure to achieve or maintain sufficient sexual interest or arousal during the sexual act
 
Impotence: Persistent or recurrent inability to attain or maintain an adequate erection until completion of the sexual act
Address issues like guilt, anxiety, and fear
 
Check for use of medications that cause vaginal dryness, like antihistamines or anticholinergics
 
Relaxation techniques.
 
Determine if organic or psychological.
 
Consider plethysmography or postage stamp test
Orgasm
Physiologic state in which sexual tension is released and contractions are produced in various organs
Female orgasmic disorder and delayed ejaculation: Recurrent or persistent inability to achieve orgasm either through masturbation or sexual intercourse
 
Premature ejaculation: Ejaculation before the man wishes to do so, before penetration or just after penetration

Address issues of guilt, fear of impregnation, etc

Use vibrators, education, and fantasy

Behavioral techniques such as squeeze and stop-and-go

Address issues of anxiety about the sexual act

SSRIs to delay ejaculation
Pain
Subjective sense of pain associated with the sexual act. Most likely due to dynamic factors
Genito-pelvic pain disorder: Pain associated with sexual intercourse in either male or female. Not diagnosed when the organic cause has been found or if due to vaginal lubrication.
 
Penetration disorder: Involuntary constriction of the outer one-third of the vagina that interferes with the sexual act.

Help with issues of anxiety and tension about the sexual act

Behavioral techniques, such as the use of dilators and relaxation

Address issues of fear of impregnation, strict upbringing, religion, etc

questions.text: A patient with radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy develops nephrotic-range proteinuria. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to a secondary cause (reflux nephropathy). Secondary nephrotic syndrome in adults is most likely due to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS).

FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells and effacement of foot processes. Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis are seen due to the entrapment of plasma proteins and increased extracellular matrix deposition.

FSGS is classified as follows:

  • Primary
    • Idiopathic FSGS
  • Secondary
    • HIV associated
    • Heroin addiction
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Obesity
    • Hypertensive nephropathy
    • Renal conditions
      • Focal glomerulonephritis (e.g. IgA nephropathy)
      • Renal ablation
      • Unilateral renal agenesis or renal dysplasia
      • Reflux nephropathy
  • Inherited
    • Mutated proteins of the slit diaphragm - podocin, alpha-actinin 4, TRPC6

Electron microscopy of FSGS shows: 

  • Diffuse effacement of the podocyte foot processes
  • Focal detachment and degeneration of the epithelial cells
  • Absence of electron-dense deposits

questions.text: You notice the senior resident in the surgery outpatient department advising a patient to use the following treatment option for his condition. Which of the following conditions is the patient likely to have?
questions.solution:
The given image shows elastic compression stockings. Among the given options, varicose veins is the condition the patient is most likely to have. 

Elastic compression stockings are commonly prescribed for the treatment of chronic venous insufficiency manifesting as venous ulcers or varicose veins. The principal cause of venous insufficiency is venous hypertension. This venous hypertension can be decreased by compression stockings. It helps to push the blood from superficial engorged veins into the deep veins, thus improving the blood-pumping function of the calf muscle. Hence, it decreases edema and improves tissue oxygenation. 

Complications of this therapy include skin excoriation, dryness, skin maceration, and infection. 

Varicose veins are tortuous dilatation of veins due to venous insufficiency. It commonly presents as lower limb swelling with a sensation of heaviness, burning, and aching over the affected area or whole limb. Diagnosis is majorly done using duplex ultrasound and very rarely involves MR venography or intravenous ultrasound (IVUS). 

Treatment is achieved using modalities such as compression, laser ablation, endothermal ablation, radiofrequency ablation, endovenous glue, ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy, and open surgery.

Other options-

Option A: Raynaud's disease refers to an abnormal sensitivity in the arteriolar response to cold. These vessels constrict and the digits (usually the fingers) turn white and become incapable of fine movements. The capillaries then dilate and fill with slowly flowing deoxygenated blood. Compression will have no effect on these symptoms. Protection from cold can help. 

Option B: Diabetic foot also occurs as a result of peripheral neuropathy and atherosclerosis of small arteries in the legs and feet. Hence, improving venous circulation with compression stockings will have no benefit in this condition. 

Option C: Buerger's disease or thromboangiitis obliterans involves occlusive disease of small- and medium-sized arteries, thrombophlebitis of the superficial or deep veins, and Raynaud’s syndrome. It occurs in male smokers, usually under the age of 30 years. It is an arterial occlusive disorder, so compression stockings will have no therapeutic effect.

 

 

The image attached below sums up the therapeutic principle behind compression therapy for venous insufficiency-
