  • The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.
  • Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
  • Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm
  • Varicose veins refer to dilated tortuous veins >3 mm in diameter

questions.text: A young woman presents to your clinic with complaints of palpitations. Her vitals are normal. On auscultation, you hear a mid-systolic click after the first heart sound at the apex of the heart, which softens on lying down and amplifies on standing up. Which of the following is not true about her condition?

choices.text: Caused by myxomatous degeneration of the valve

questions.solution:
The statement that the murmur reduces during the Valsalva maneuver is not true. This young woman with palpitations, a mid-systolic click heard at the apex which exacerbates when standing up and improves on lying down, most probably has a diagnosis of mitral valve prolapse.

Mitral valve prolapse is a valvular heart defect in which the mitral valve leaflets are floppy and prolapse into the left atrium during ventricular contraction, making it the most common cause of primary mitral valve regurgitation. It is seen most commonly in young women and can be inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion with incomplete penetrance. 

This produces the classic mid-systolic click which is heard at the apex of the heart. The intensity of this click sound changes depending on the left ventricular (LV) volume. When LV volume increases, the floppy valve is able to maintain tension, and the degree of prolapse is reduced. Thus the intensity of the murmur reduces. On the other hand, when the LV volume is low, the mitral valve leaflets remain floppy and produce a louder click sound.

By this logic, when the patient stands up, the venous return reduces and so the LV volume decrease. This causes the murmur to become louder. On lying down, venous return increases, leading to increased LV volume and a softer murmur. On performing the Valsalva maneuver, intrathoracic pressure increases. This reduces venous return, and hence the murmur becomes louder because of reduced LV volume. 

Option A - Mitral valve prolapse is also called Barlow's syndrome or floppy valve disease.

Option B -  It is associated with connective tissue disorders like Marfan's syndrome, Ehler's Danlos syndrome, and osteogenesis imperfecta.

Option C - The valve becomes floppy due to myxomatous degeneration of the valve.

The diagnosis can be made with a combination of clinical examination and transthoracic or transesophageal echocardiography. 

Treatment of these patients involves the usage of beta-blockers for palpitations. If the patient has severe symptoms due to mitral regurgitation, surgical repair is advisable. In case of prior history of endocarditis, prophylaxis for infective endocarditis should be prescribed.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect

Inspiration

(↑venous return to right atrium)
  • ↑ intensity of right-sided sounds

Handgrip

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

Valsalva-Phase II, standing up

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

Rapid squatting

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

questions.text: A 60-year-old man suffered a stroke a month ago and has since been recumbent. The following findings are seen on his physical examination over the sacrum. Which of the following interventions is not helpful to prevent the occurrence of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a recumbent man with examination findings as shown is representative of pressure ulcers. Massaging of bony prominences is avoided as it contributes to pressure ulcer formation.

Pressure-induced skin and soft tissue injuries are localized areas of damage to the skin and/or underlying tissue usually over a bony prominence. Commonly occurs over the ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, heel, malleolus, and occiput.

Prevention of pressure ulcers - 

  • Pressure redistribution - achieved by appropriate use of pressure-reducing devices and surfaces such as air-fluidized beds and proper patient positioning
  • Improve mobility
  • Improving skin perfusion - involves treatment of hypotension, limiting vasoconstrictive agents, improving cardiac contractility, or revascularization for some patients with severe peripheral artery disease
  • Providing skincare to optimize skin temperature, color, turgor, moisture status, and integrity.
  • Correct malnutrition
  • Multilayer foam dressings
  • Bedside pressure mapping

Related Pearl: Staging of Pressure Sores

 

Stage

Description
1 Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
2

Partial thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
3

Full thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
4 Full thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon or joint

questions.text:
A 15-month baby was brought to the pediatrics department with diarrhea. The baby weighed 10 kg. On examination, you notice signs of dehydration and decide to start on oral rehydration therapy. The amount of ORS solution to be given in the first 4 hours is

ORS: Oral rehydration salt
questions.solution:
According to the guidelines for oral rehydration therapy, a child weighing between 8-10.9 Kgs or between 1-2 years, with signs of dehydration has to be treated with 600-800 ml of ORS solution within the first 4 hours.

Guidelines for oral rehydration therapy (for all ages) during the first four hours:

Age* Weight(kg) ORS solution(ml)
Under 4 months Under 5 200-400
4-11 months 5-7.9 400-600
1-2 years 8-10.9 600-800
2-4 years 11-15.9 800-1200
5-14 years 16-29.9 1200-2200
15 years or over 30 or over 2200-4000

* Age should only be used if weight is not known. The approximate amount of ORS required in mL can also be calculated by multiplying the patient's weight in kg by 75.

Related Pearl: Comparison between low-osmolar oral rehydration solution and ReSoMal

Sodium  75  45
Potassium  20  40

questions.text: As an intern, you see the obstetric index on the file of one of the patients admitted to your unit. The obstetric index is G2P1 and she is in her 35th week of pregnancy. All of the following can be possible case scenarios in this aspect, except ______.

choices.text: She had twins in her previous pregancy and this is her second pregnancy.
She has one living child and this is her second pregnancy
After a spontaneous miscarriage at 12 weeks, this is her second pregnancy
After a stillbirth, this is her second pregnancy

questions.solution:
Option C is the answer. If this is her second pregnancy after a spontaneous miscarriage at 12 weeks, her obstetric index would be G2P0, as her first pregnancy did not cross the period of viability (28 weeks).

The term gravida refers to a woman who currently is pregnant or has been in the past, irrespective of the pregnancy outcome. As part of the obstetric index, it refers to the number of times she has been pregnant, irrespective of whether it crossed the period of viability. A current pregnancy, if any, is included in this count.

With her first pregnancy, she is a primi­ gravida, and with successive pregnancies, a multigravida. Nulligravida is a woman who currently is not pregnant and has never been pregnant.

Parity is determined by the number of pregnancies reaching a period of viability. It is not increased to a higher number if multiples (twins/triplets) are delivered in a given pregnancy and still counts as 'one birth'. Moreover, stillbirth does not lower this number. Para indicates the number of viable births. A current pregnancy, if any, is not included in this count.

Nullipara refers to a woman who has never completed a pregnancy beyond 28 weeks gestation. She may never have been preg­nant or may have had a spontaneous or elective abortion(s) or an ectopic pregnancy.

Primipara refers to a woman who has delivered a baby only once- alive or dead, with a gestation period of 28 or more weeks.

Both parity and gravida refer to the pregnancy and not the fetuses.

Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic was brought to the emergency room after a fall. He appeared malnourished and confused. On neurological examination, he had an ataxic gait, dysarthria, and tremors. He underwent a brain MRI which showed the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiological findings shown above suggest a likely diagnosis of Marchiafava-Bignami disease.

Marchiafava-Bignami disease refers to the degeneration of the corpus callosum that occurs in chronic alcoholics. Classically, this was seen in Italian red wine drinkers. The MRI image above shows a degenerating corpus callosum with the classic sandwich sign. There is a central hypointensity surrounded by a hyperintense rim. This presentation is due to the gradual degeneration of the corpus callosum. Patients present with dementia, seizures, hypertonia, coma, and death. 

The arrows in the image below are pointing to the site of corpus callosal degeneration with the classic "sandwich sign"-

 

Other options-

Option A: Arnold-Chiari II malformation is a congenital malformation of the hindbrain. These patients have small posterior fossa with inferiorly displaced cerebellum, pons, medulla, and cervical spinal cord. Myelomeningocele is also very commonly seen in such patients. The flax cerebri can also be fenestrated and show herniation of gyri on CT scan. They usually present in infancy or early childhood with apneic spells, stridor, dysphagia, etc. Chronic alcoholism is not related to its pathogenesis. 

 

Option B: Aicardi syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder that mostly affects females. It presents with the triad of agenesis of the corpus callosum, chorioretinal lacunae, and infantile spasms. They present with seizures, visual impairment, and motor dysfunction. MRI can also show corpus callosal degeneration, which is usually complete.

Option D: Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome which presents with ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and confusion, is the closest differential diagnosis to this disease. However, it can be differentiated based on the MRI findings. MRI of patients with Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome will show involvement of the mamillary bodies and medial thalamus, and not the above-mentioned findings seen in Marchiafava-Bignami disease. 

The MRI below shows areas of hyperintensity in the medial thalami, typical of Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome-

 

Related Pearl: Corpus Callosum

Parts of the corpus callosum:

  • Rostrum: connects frontal lobes (eg: orbitofrontal cortex)
  • Genu: connects frontal lobes. It is the anterior-most part.
  • Trunk or Body: connects temporal lobes.
  • Splenium: connects the two occipital lobes. It is the thickest part.

Note: Isthmus is a part which separates the body from splenium, some books mention it as a part.

  • The fibers of the genu curve forward into frontal lobes and form forceps minor.
  • The fibers of the trunk extend laterally as radiation of corpus callosum.
  • The fibers from the trunk and the splenium which form the lateral wall of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle constitute the tapetum.
  • The fibers from the splenium arching backwards into the occipital lobe form forceps major.

questions.text: A 22-year-old boy is brought by his parents after using a kitchen knife to inflict cuts across his thigh himself. He admits that he is feeling bad about not qualifying for the entrance exam, but has no intention of killing himself. His inflicting of painful, injurious wounds on himself without an intent to die is called:
questions.solution:
Inflicting of painful, injurious wounds on themselves without an intent to die is called deliberate self-harm.

Deliberate self-harm refers to an act of causing physical injury to oneself without wanting to die. This includes cutting (with a knife or razor), scratching or hitting oneself, and intentional drug overdose. They may also include limiting food intake and other risk-taking behaviors such as driving at high speeds, having unsafe sex.

These acts are often gratifying and cause minor to moderate harm. Although deliberate self-harm is done without lethal intent, it could lead to fatality.

The risk factors for the same include:

  1. Low self-esteem
  2. Being impulsive
  3. Low distress tolerance
  4. Non-heterosexual orientation
  5. Dysfunctional family
  6. History of violence or forensic problems

When a patient with a history as mentioned in this case is brought for further evaluation, the following steps can be taken:

  • Assess for self-harm behavior and other psychiatric conditions
  • Encourage patient to talk by providing emphatic listening
  • Provide parental education and brief problem-solving advice
  • A referral for hospitalization is indicated for patients presenting with strong suicidal intent or plan, a recent suicide attempt, severe psychiatric conditions such as psychosis, and high frequency, intensity, and lethality of self-harm acts.

Other options:

Option A: Aborted suicide attempt is when a person had planned to execute self-injurious behavior with an intention to die but stopped the attempt before the physical damage occurred.

Option B: Suicidal intent is to harbor a desire to commit a self-destructive act resulting in death.

Option D: A suicide attempt is when a person indulges in self-injurious behavior with an actual intention to die but the act results in a non-fatal outcome.

questions.text: A child with bilateral cataracts was brought to the ophthalmology department. Systemic examination reveals hearing loss, a congenital heart defect along with the following lesions that have been present since birth. All of the following are the ocular findings associated with this condition except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing blueberry muffin lesions is suggestive of Congenital rubella syndrome and microphthalmos is seen in this condition (not megalophthalmos).

Congenital rubella cataract may occur alone or as part of the classical rubella syndrome which consists of:

  • Ocular defects: Congenital cataract, salt and pepper chorioretinopathy, microphthalmos, Glaucoma, and anterior uveitis
  • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Heart defects: Patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary stenosis, and ventricular septal defects.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A patient comes with productive cough with yellow sputum and high-grade fever with chills for the past 4 days. He has increased tactile fremitus, dull notes on percussion of the right side, and crackles. A chest radiograph was performed and is shown below. The doctor uses a criteria to find out if the patient needs hospitalization or not. All of the following are the components of this criteria except:
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of fever, productive cough, increased tactile fremitus with crackles in the lung fields, and the radiograph indicates a diagnosis of lobar pneumonia. The need for hospitalization in this patient is assessed using the CURB 65 criteria. Consolidation is not a parameter included in this criteria.

CURB 65 scores for community-acquired pneumonia:

Clinical factor Points
Confusion  1
Blood urea nitrogen > 19 mg per dL 1
Respiratory rate ≥ 30 breaths per minute 1
Systolic blood pressure < 90 mm Hg or Diastolic blood pressure ≤ 60 mm Hg 1
Age ≥ 65 years 1 

Interpretation:

  • Scores 0-1 are considered as low risk and home treatment can be considered
  • Score 2 will require short inpatient hospitalization or closely supervised outpatient treatment
  • Scores 3-5 are severe pneumonia. It will require hospitalization and admission to intensive care

Another similar criteria used in the assessment of the severity of pneumonia is CRB-65. Here the urea levels in the blood are not considered. The rest of the parameters are the same as those used in CURB-65. In this,

  • Score 0 has a low risk of death and does not require hospitalization
  • Score 1 and 2 have an increased risk of death and hospitalization is considered.
  • Score 3 and 4 have a high risk of death and require urgent hospitalization.

Related Pearl: CURB-65 Criteria

This is a score to determine the severity of pneumonia.

The CURB-65 criteria include five variables(1 point for each variable):

  • Confusion 
  • Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) >7 mmol/L
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min 
  • Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg 
  • Age ≥65 years.

Management:

0 point: Treat as an outpatient

1 to 2 points: Admitted to the hospital

≥3 points: ICU admission

Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia 

Score - 0: The drug of choice is macrolides.

                     Azithromycin 500mg OD

                                  or

                   Clarithromycin  500mg BD

                                  or

                   Doxycycline  100mg BD.

Score - 1: Treated with azithromycin  500mg OD + ceftriaxone 2gm OD.

               Respiratory quinolones (Levofloxacin) are not preferred.

Score - >2: Azithromycin 500mg OD + Ceftriaxone 2gm IV OD and specific management.

NOTE:- In a modified version of the CURB-65, the criteria of blood urea nitrogen has been removed.

           This elimination removes the need for lab testing.

Related Pearl: Empirical Antibiotic Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP)

Situation  Treatment Regimen
 Outpatient

 Macrolide / Doxycycline

Comorbidities:

Respiratory Fluoroquinolone 

      Or       

β-lactam + Macrolide / Doxycycline

Respiratory Fluoroquinolone 

Or

+

+

+

If CA-MRSA

+

Note:

Macrolide - Azithromycin / Clarithromycin

Fluoroquinolones :

  • Respiratory Fluoroquinolone - Levofloxacin* / Moxifloxacin / (Gemifloxacin - only outpatient) 
  • Ciprofloxacin*

β-lactam :

  • Outpatient with comorbidities 
    • PO - Amoxicillin (+/- clavulanate)/ Cefpodoxime / Cefuroxime 
    • IV - Ceftriaxone
  • Inpatient, Non-ICU (IV) 
    • Ampicillin / Ceftriaxone / Cefotaxime / Ertapenem
  • Inpatient, ICU (IV) 
    • Ampicillin-Sulbactam / Ceftriaxone / Cefotaxime
  • Anti-pseudomonal β-lactam (IV) 
    • Piperacillin-Tazobactam / Cefepime / Imipenem / Meropenem 

Aminoglycoside - Amikacin / Tobramycin

questions.text: A primigravida woman with monochorionic twin pregnancy presents for an antenatal checkup in the third trimester.  The ultrasound reveal twin to twin transfusion syndrome. Subsequently, one of the twins is found to have hydrops fetalis. According to Quintero staging, you will classify this as:
questions.solution:
Quintero staging is used in the grading of twin to twin transfusion syndrome. Hydrops fetalis of either of the twins is classified as stage IV in Quintero staging.

The Quintero staging is as follows:  

  • Stage I—Amniotic fluid discordant + Urine visible in donor's bladder.
  • Stage II—Stage I +Urine not visible in donor's bladder.
  • Stage III— Stage II + abnormal Doppler studies of the umbilical artery, ductus venosus, or umbilical vein.
  • Stage IV— frank ascites or hydrops in either twin.
  • Stage V—the demise of either fetus.

Twin to twin transfusion syndrome is a condition that affects multifetal pregnancies where there are shared placentas. It occurs due to arteriovenous anastomoses occurring within the placenta. Unidirectional flow leads to shunting of blood away from one twin and towards the other. 

The donor twin may have anemia, growth restriction, oliguria, oligohydramnios, and pallor. The recipient twin may have polycythemia, heart failure, circulatory overload (hydrops), plethoric appearance, severe hypervolemia, hyperviscosity, severe hyperbilirubinemia, and kernicterus.

The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy. Lambda sign is seen in the image below: 

 

"T sign" is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. It refers to the lack of chorion extending between the layers of the intertwin membrane.

Note:

The donor twin is also known as pump twin / stuck twin, and the manifestation is termed as polyhydramnios -oligohydramnios syndrome or poly-oli syndrome.

Related Pearl: Twinning

Related Pearl: Important radiological signs in OBG

Sign
Significance
Bagel sign
Gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring.
USG sign in tubal ectopic.
Ball Sign
X-ray shows a crumpled up spine of the fetus.
Radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death.
Banana Sign
Abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum due to the associated Arnold-Chiari malformation.
USG sign in open spina bifida.
Double decidual sac Sign
Two concentric echogenic rings separated by a hyperechoic space.
Normal USG appearance of an intrauterine gestational sac.
Lambda Sign
The chorionic tissue in between the two layers of the membrane between the twins.
USG sign seen in di-chorionic pregnancies.
‘T’ Sign
USG sign seen in monochorionic twins. As the intertwin membrane does not have any chorionic tissue it gives rise to ‘T’ sign in ultrasound.
Bunch of grapes sign
USG appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.
Butterfly sign
Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the marked incision shown below?

choices.text: The rectus abdominis muscles are transected
Follows Langer lines of skin tension
Lower incidence of incisional hernias as compared to vertical incisions
Location is 3 cm above the pubic symphysis

questions.solution:
The incision marked is the Pfannenstiel incision where the rectus muscles are not transected. The rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

Pfannenstiel incision is the most common incision made in cesarean delivery.It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

Compared to vertical incisions, the Pfannenstiel incision offers superior cosmesis and lower incisional hernia rates.

The Maylard incision (the unmarked incision in the image) differs mainly from the Pfannenstiel in that the bellies of the rectus abdominis muscles are transected horizontally to widen the operating space.

Related Pearl: Transvere and vertical incisions in Cesarean section

Transverse incisions:

Advantages-

  • Follows Langer lines of skin tension, so superior cosmetic results
  • Less postoperative pain
  • Less fascial wound dehiscence
  • Low incidence of incisional hernias

Disadvantages-

  • High infection risks
  • Narrow operating space
  • Injury to neurovascular bundles
  • Reentry during repeat C-section is difficult due to scarring

Vertical incisions:

Advantages-

  • Quick entry
  • Minimal blood loss
  • Superior access to the upper
    abdomen
  • Wide operating space
  • Flexibility for easy wound extension if necessary

Disadvantages-

  • Poor cosmetic results
  • Higher fascial dehiscence 
  • Higher incisional hernia rates
  • Greater postoperative pain

questions.text: A male sewer worker had an on-and-off fever for 2 weeks, followed by jaundice, and purple-blue spots on his skin. He developed hematuria and neck stiffness soon after that and was found to have deranged hepatic and renal parameters. He succumbed to death. A  hepatic tissue section is stained as shown below. What special stain has been used to visualize the specimen?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is consistent with a diagnosis of leptospirosis caused by Leptospires which are best visualized in tissue sections by staining using Levaditi's silver impregnation method.

Leptospirosis is caused by contact with the blood or urine of an infected organism in a contaminated water body. It is a type of zoonosis and can affect all mammalian species. Rats are well-known reservoirs. 

The clinical picture varies from mild disease to severe fatal disease, referred to as Weil's disease. Signs and symptoms of leptospirosis include fever, jaundice, meningismus, hemorrhage, and acute kidney injury. Faget sign (temperature pulse dissociation) is also seen.

A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis. In the acute phase of the disease, leptospires can be seen in blood in the first week of infection. This is done with darkfield microscopy or immunofluorescence.

Leptospires should be treated with IV penicillin. Ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, or doxycycline are alternatives for the treatment of severe leptospirosis.

Other options-

Option A: Albert's stain is used to demonstrate Corynebacteria with metachromatic granules. On staining with Albert stain, it shows delicate green bacilli with purple-blue metachromatic granules. 

Option C: Gomori’s methenamine silver stain is commonly used for staining fungal cell walls. It stains the fungal wall black.

Option D: Loeffler’s methylene blue is used to stain the granules of Corynebacteria a bluish-purple color.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: A 25-year-old obese woman comes to the clinic with complaints of multiple painful lesions associated with a foul-smelling discharge in the axilla. Examination findings are as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing multiple lesions with foul-smelling discharge in the intertriginous area (axilla) in an obese female is strongly suggestive of hidradenitis suppurativa.

Hidradenitis suppurativa is also called acne inversa and is seen more commonly seen after puberty. It is a chronic, inflammatory, recurrent, debilitating, follicular disease.

The following three criteria must be met for the diagnosis to be made:

  1. Typical lesions - The lesions can manifest as deep‐seated painful nodules, abscesses, draining sinuses, bridged scars, and paired or multiheaded open pseudo comedones.
  2. Typical locations - axillae, groin, perineal and perianal region, buttocks, and infra‐ and intermammary folds.
  3. Chronicity and recurrence of lesions. 

Treatment includes: 

  • General measures - lifestyle modifications such as cessation of smoking, weight loss, and general cleanliness are advised. 
  • Antibiotics - Topical clindamycin lotion 0.1% can be used to manage milder lesions. Systemic antibiotics like tetracycline and a combination of clindamycin and rifampicin can be used in such conditions.
  • Intralesional corticosteroids such a triaminolone can be used.
  • Acitretin
  • Anti-TNF alpha therapy
  • Surgery - Many lesion‐directed therapies have been identified as beneficial in the therapy of HS. Incision and drainage are done in a presence of a fluctuant abscess. Deroofing can also be done which is a tissue-saving procedure in which the roof of an abscess or sinus tract is surgically removed using either electrosurgery (using a loop) or conventional surgery. Ablative lasers and electrosurgery are also useful in removing all the involved tissues. 

Other options:

Option A: Acne vulgaris is one of the most common skin diseases, highly prevalent in adolescents. The lesions can manifest as open and closed comedones, papules, pustules, or nodules with variable degrees of inflammation and depth. The most usually affected areas are the face, back, and/or chest. These would not be found in the axillary region.

Option B: Necrobiosis lipoidica can happen at any age, it typically is seen in young adults and those in their early middle years. It is associated with diabetes. The lesion starts as a hard, dull red papule or plaque on the pretibial skin and enlarges radially to become a yellowish atrophic plaque with an erythematous edge. Telangiectatic vessels may be seen, and the surface is frequently glazed in appearance.

Option C: Pyoderma gangrenosum (PG) is a rare non‐infectious neutrophilic dermatosis. It is commonly associated with inflammatory bowel disease. The major criteria to diagnosis classical PG are a rapid progression of a painful, necrolytic cutaneous ulcer with an irregular, violaceous, and undermined border; and the elimination of any other causes of cutaneous ulceration. These lesions are usually not found in the axilla.

questions.text: A patient comes to the sleep clinic and the following pattern is seen on polysomnography. What type of breathing pattern is it?
questions.solution:
The breathing pattern shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes respiration. It is characterized by progressively deeper and sometimes faster breathing, followed by a gradual decrease that results in a temporary stop in breathing called apnea.

It is caused by an increased sensitivity of the respiratory center to arterial PCO2. There is an apneic phase, during which arterial PO2 falls and arterial PCO2 rises. These changes in the arterial blood gas content stimulate the respiratory center, resulting in hyperventilation and hypocapnia, followed by recurrence of apnea. It is present in 40% of patients with advanced HF and usually is associated with low cardiac output.

questions.text: While doffing after examining patients in the COVID ward, you would dispose of the item shown in the image below into the bin coloured:
questions.solution:
The shoe cover should be disposed into the bin colored yellow.

  • To report opening/operation of COVID 19 Ward/ICU/Lab/Collection Centre to SPCB (State Pollution Control Board) and CBWTF (Common Biomedical Waste Treatment Facility) in that area
  • Dedicated sanitation workers deputed only to collect COVID 19 BMW
  • It is mandatory for all BMW bags and containers from COVID 19 areas to carry "COVID 19 WASTE" label
  • Keep separate colour coded bins with foot operated lids
  • The inner and outer surfaces of these containers must be disinfected daily with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution
  • To ensure no leaks, double layers (2 bags) are used

questions.text: A school-going girl presents with jaundice and chronic fatigue. Examination revealed splenomegaly and conjunctival pallor. Blood tests show normocytic anemia, large spherical red blood cells without central pallor, and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Her elder brother also has similar symptoms. Genetic testing shows a mutation in the gene coding for ankyrin. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Normocytic anemia with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and splenomegaly is suggestive of hemolytic anemia. Ankyrin deficiency as well as family history points to the diagnosis as hereditary spherocytosis.

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hereditary hemolytic anemia that is passed down in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations of the red blood cell surface proteins spectrin and ankyrin can result in unstable cell membranes, leading to hemolysis.

This disorder can present at a young age with severe jaundice and fatigue. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones. Hence, childhood gallstones should raise suspicion for this diagnosis.

Laboratory findings include normocytic anemia with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The peripheral smear will show large spherical red blood cells without central pallor. The diagnosis can be confirmed by the acid glycerol lysis test and the eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test. 

There is no specific treatment available besides splenectomy. However, due to the possible adverse effects, it is only indicated in severe cases and after the child attains puberty in moderate cases. It should be followed up with the appropriate antibiotic and vaccine prophylaxis.

Other options:

Option (A): Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is a type of inherited hemolytic anemia. It is associated with exacerbations after consuming anti-malarial drugs and in periods of oxidative stress. It is not associated with ankyrin mutations. It is an X-linked disorder so it is unlikely to be seen in this patient.

Option (B): Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is a hemolytic disorder that also presents with pancytopenia and a tendency to form venous thrombi. It occurs due to defective GPI anchors on the red blood cell surface which are normally used to anchor CD 59 (cell-protective proteins) to the surface. These patients can present with episodes of dark brown urine in the morning, anemia, pancytopenia, and recurrent abdominal pain due to thrombosis of abdominal veins.

Option (D): Hereditary elliptocytosis is also a type of inherited hemolytic anemia that results from spectrin and similar surface protein mutations. The clinical presentation is very similar to spherocytosis, but the peripheral smear will show elongated elliptical red blood cells instead of spherical ones.

Related Pearl: Hyperbilirubinemia- Causes

 Predominantly Unconjugated Hyperbilirubinemia  Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Excess production of bilirubin

  

Hemolytic anemias

Biliary tract obstruction

Resorption of blood from internal hemorrhage (e.g., alimentary tract bleeding, hematomas)

 Biliary tract diseases like primary biliary cirrhosis and primary sclerosing cholangitis

Ineffective erythropoiesis (e.g., pernicious anemia, thalassemia)

Dubin Johnson syndrome

Reduced hepatic uptake

Rotor syndrome

Drug interference with membrane carrier systems

 Benign recurrent intrahepatic cholestasis

Some cases of Gilbert syndrome

 Progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis

Impaired bilirubin conjugation

  

Physiologic jaundice of the newborn (decreased UGT1A1 activity, decreased excretion)

  

Breast milk jaundice (β-glucuronidases in milk)

  

Genetic deficiency of UGT1A1 activity (Crigler-Najjar syndrome types I and II)

  

Gilbert syndrome

  

Diffuse hepatocellular disease (e.g., viral or drug-induced hepatitis, cirrhosis)

  

Related Pearl: Classification of Hemolytic Anemias

Hemolytic anemias can be classified in 2 ways:

1. Based on the type of defect:

Type  Intracorpuscular Defects Extracorpuscular Factors
Hereditary

Hemoglobinopathies

Enzymopathies

Membrane-cytoskeletal defects

 Familial (atypical) hemolytic uremic syndrome
Acquired Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)

Mechanical destruction (microangiopathic)

Toxic agents

Drugs

Infectious

Autoimmune

2. Based on the sites of hemolysis:

Intravascular hemolysis:

  • Mechanical injury
    • Trauma caused by cardiac valves 
    • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias (hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura) 
    • Repetitive physical trauma
  • Complement fixation (antibody-mediated destruction)
    • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- ABO incompatibility
    • Transfusion reaction  
    • Drug-induced 
  • Infections of red blood cells 
    • Malaria
    • Babesiosis
  • Exogenous toxic factors - clostridial sepsis

Extravascular hemolysis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Thalassemia
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- Rh incompatibility

Both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis:

  • G6PD deficiency
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A child is brought with complaints of bitemporal hemianopia, severe headaches associated with vomiting, growth failure, and delayed sexual maturation. CT scan showed the presence of a tumor with calcifications. T1 weighed MRI of the brain is done and is shown below. What is the embryonal basis for this tumor?
questions.solution:
The child has a craniopharyngioma derived from the Rathke pouch, which may persist in the roof of the nasopharynx as a pharyngeal hypophysis.

Rathke’s pouch appears as an evagination of the oral cavity at about 3 weeks of embryonic life. It grows dorsally towards the infundibulum and eventually loses its connection to the oral cavity by the end of the 8th week. The anterior wall cells multiply rapidly to form the anterior pituitary or adenohypophysis, and the posterior wall of the pouch forms pars intermedia. The anterior wall cells have a small extension that grows along the stalk of the infundibulum, forming pars tuberalis.

Craniopharyngiomas are benign masses usually present in the suprasellar or intrasellar regions. They arise near the pituitary stalk and can produce functional impairment of the hypophysis due to the mass effect. They can be clinically aggressive due to their tendency to recur. Adamantinomatous (children) and papillary (adults) are two variants of craniopharyngioma. 

Patients usually come to attention due to a headache and visual changes, including decreased acuity or visual field abnormalities (bitemporal hemianopia). These children also have endocrinologic abnormalities such as growth failure and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypofunction and growth hormone deficiency. They are minimally invasive, adhere to the adjacent brain parenchyma, and engulf normal brain structures.

CT may show calcifications within the tumor. MRI shows the presence of solid tumors with cystic components. These tumors appear bright on T1.

They are treated by trans-sphenoidal or trans-cranial resection followed by adjuvant radiation therapy.

questions.text: You are attending a quiz competition, and the quiz master asks you to enlist the components of Saint's triad. Which of the following will not form a part of your answer?
questions.solution:
Renal stones are not a component of Saint’s triad.

Components of Saint's triad:

  • Gallstones
  • Hiatus hernia
  • Diverticulosis coli

There is no underlying pathophysiology that explains the simultaneous presence of these three conditions.

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic man who developed rhinocerebral mucormycosis post-COVID-19 infection was prescribed amphotericin B. All of the following are the rationales behind choosing liposomal amphotericin B over amphotericin deoxycholate for the treatment of this patient, except?

choices.text: Better CNS penetration than amphotericin deoxycholate
Amphotericin deoxycholate needs to be infused at higher rates

questions.solution:
Amphotericin deoxycholate is an FDA-approved drug for the treatment of mucormycosis but the rationales behind the usage of liposomal amphotericin B over amphotericin deoxycholate in mucormycosis are:

  • Less nephrotoxic than amphotericin B deoxycholate
  • Better CNS penetration than amphotericin B deoxycholate or amphotericin B lipid complex
  • Better outcomes than with amphotericin B deoxycholate 

Liposomal amphotericin B is given in the dose of 5 - 10 mg/kg once per day; 10mg/kg is given in case of CNS infection. Liposomal amphotericin B is more commonly used in the treatment of mucormycosis, than the other conventional formulations of amphotericin B, provided it is readily available.

Infusion-related adverse events are commonly seen with amphotericin B and it has been nicknamed "shake and bake" due to the associated chills and fever. 

Amphotericin B colloidal dispersions cause more infusion-related reactions than conventional amphotericin B. Liposomal amphotericin B (L-AMB) and Amphotericin B lipid complex (ABLC) have a lesser incidence of infusion reactions than C-AMB. L-AMB may cause slightly lesser infusion-related reactions, and can be infused at higher rates than amphotericin deoxycholate.

Amphotericin B acts by extracting ergosterol from the fungal cell membrane, disrupting the structure and leading to fungal cell death.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A patient developed generalized pruritis and swelling of the face, lips, and tongue after having dinner at a new restaurant. He also complained of difficulty in breathing. Which of the following is incorrect about the immunoglobulin causing this reaction?

choices.text: It is the only heat stable antibody
Levels are raised in helminthic infections
It does not pass the placental barrier
It has a half-life of 1-5 days

questions.solution:
This is an example of an IgE-mediated type of hypersensitivity reaction. It is also known as a type I hypersensitivity reaction. IgE immunoglobulin is the only heat-labile antibody.

The primary mediators of type 1 hypersensitivity reactions are histamine and serotonin. The secondary mediators are prostaglandins and leukotrienes. The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mild rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis.

IgE:

  • Half-life: 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat-labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.
  • It does not pass the placental barrier or fix complement.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the clinic with complaints of numbness and paresthesia in the thighs and legs. It begins after standing upright or walking for 5-10 minutes and is consistently relieved by sitting, squatting, or leaning against a wall. On examination, distal pulses are felt. MRI shows the following findings. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
An elderly man with numbness and paresthesia in the thighs and legs which comes on after walking for 5-10 minutes and is consistently relieved by sitting, squatting, or leaning against a wall is likely to have spinal claudication and the given MRI image shows the narrowing of the spinal canal which is are suggestive of spinal stenosis.

The term spinal stenosis is used to describe an abnormal narrowing of the central canal, the lateral recesses, or the intervertebral foramina to the point where the neural elements are compromised. When this occurs the patient develops neurological symptoms and signs in the lower limbs.

Some of the causes of spinal stenosis are as follows:

  • congenital vertebral dysplasia
  • chronic disc protrusion
  • displacement and hypertrophy, or osteoarthritis, of the apophyseal(facet) joints
  • hypertrophy, folding or ossification of the ligamentum flavum
  • bone thickening due to Paget's disease
  • spondylolisthesis

The patient is usually a male aged above 50 years with complaints of aching, heaviness, numbness, and paresthesia in the thighs and legs. 

The patient prefers walking uphill which flexes the spine ( maximizes the spinal canal capacity ) to downhill.

Investigations include imaging studies like X-ray or CT scans of the spinal canal. An anteroposterior diameter of less than 11mm or a transverse diameter of less than 16mm is considered abnormal.

Treatment includes conservative management. In severe conditions, operative decompressions are almost always successful.

Other options:

  • Option A: Sciatica - The patient complains of pain radiating down the back of the thigh and calf. Sciatica can either be because of inflammation of the sciatic nerve or because of compression of one of the roots constituting the sciatic nerve
  • Option C: Vascular Claudication occurs due to injury to blood vessels and leads to exercise-induced ischemia. The collaterals are good enough to keep the limb viable but any further demand on the blood supply like walking uphill or riding a stationary bicycle causes ischaemic pain. Symptoms of vascular claudication reduce on taking rest or by standing still but spinal stenosis requires flexion for relief.
  • Option D: Pott's Disease, that is, tuberculosis of the spine begins as a dull ache in the early stages and later becomes localized to the affected diseased segment. Other features like stiffness, cold abscess, constitutional symptoms will be present.

questions.text: Bollinger inclusion bodies are seen in which of the following infections?
questions.solution:
Bollinger inclusion bodies are seen in fowlpox. 

Inclusion bodies are the most characteristic histological features seen in virus-infected cells. Inclusion bodies can be demonstrated under a light microscope. 

Inclusion bodies can be situated in the:

  • Cytoplasm as in poxviruses, rabies. 
  • Nucleus as in herpesviruses
  • Both cytoplasm and nucleus as in measles virus

Inclusion bodies are generally acidophilic and appear as pink structures when stained with Giemsa stain or eosin methylene blue but some viruses like adenovirus have basophilic inclusions. 

Other options:

Option A- In measles, infected cells show acidophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions. The lymphoid tissues of measles patients show multinucleated giant cells named Warthin-Finkeldey cells. 

Option C- Vaccinia infected cells have small multiple inclusion bodies named Guarnieri bodies. 

Option D- In rabies infected brain cells, intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions named Negri bodies are seen.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with complaints of a firm neck swelling associated with dysphagia for the past 3 months. A blood workup shows increased serum calcitonin levels. She reveals that her mother had similar complaints. A biopsy is taken to confirm the diagnosis which is given below. Which mutation is this condition associated with?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from medullary thyroid carcinoma. RET mutation is associated with this condition. The points that favor the diagnosis are the age of the patient, the presence of neck swelling, elevated calcitonin levels, positive family history, and histopathology image showing the presence of amyloid-rich stroma.

Medullary carcinoma tumors of the thyroid are neuroendocrine tumors that are derived from parafollicular C cells, that secrete calcitonin. Most of these cancers occur sporadically. However, around a quarter of the cancers are associated with familial multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome: MEN 2A, and MEN 2B. Sporadic cases occur between 40-50 years of age while familial cases occur early. RET mutation plays an important role in the development of both familial and sporadic cancers. 

Patients with sporadic medullary thyroid carcinoma mainly present with a mass in the neck and are associated with dysphagia or hoarseness. Patients with familial syndromes present with symptoms localized to the thyroid or as endocrine neoplasms in other organs.

Histopathology shows polygonal to spindle-shaped cells which form nests, trabeculae, or follicles. Amyloid deposits that are derived from the altered calcitonin molecules are present in the stroma. Calcitonin in the tumor cells and stroma is easily demonstratable by immunohistochemistry.

Related Pearl: Gene alterations in thyroid cancer

    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was scheduled for left frontal craniotomy and excision of a meningioma. After induction of anesthesia, a sudden brief dip in CO2 during the expiratory plateau phase on the capnograph was noticed. Which among the following are likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: History of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
A dramatic increase in body temperature and muscle rigidity
Obvious inspiratory efforts by the patient

questions.solution:
A sudden brief dip in CO2 during the expiratory plateau phase of the capnograph is known as the curare notch, seen in spontaneous breathing during mechanical ventilation. Obvious inspiratory efforts by the patient will be seen.

The patient's inspiratory effort causes some fresh gas to be sucked into the capnometer, resulting in a lower carbon dioxide concentration and a notch.

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:

  • Phase I: exhalation of dead space gas (i.e., partial pressure of CO2, pCO2 ∼0).
  • Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau indicates the sampling of transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 
  • Phase III: The plateau region of the capnograph, corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveolar compartment. 
  • Following phase III, a sharp inspiratory downstroke occurs, which is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV by some authors.

Other options:

Option A- Breath sounds in the epigastrium are a sign of oesophageal intubation. Endotracheal intubation is characterized by the absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium.

Option B- In the capnograph of a patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, there is no plateau before the next inspiration with an increased upslope of phase III. Seen in bronchospasm (asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), or if the endotracheal tube or breathing circuit is partially obstructed. 

Option D- A dramatic increase in body temperature and muscle rigidity suggests malignant hyperthermia. The increased metabolic rate caused by malignant hyperthermia causes a marked rise in ETCO2.
 

 

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

Related Pearl: Signs of correct endotracheal intubation

  • Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Bilateral breath sounds
  • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volumes
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with dyspnea. She had been complaining of fatigue and worsening dyspnoea over the last 3-5 days. Examination revealed BP of 80/50 mmHg, tachypnea, tachycardia, elevated neck veins, and muffled heart sounds. The echocardiography finding is shown below. Which of the following findings is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation with the classic Beck's triad and the echo showing the swinging heart sign are indicative of the diagnosis being cardiac tamponade. Physical examination would reveal the presence of pulsus paradoxus in this patient.

This patient has the classic Beck's triad of cardiac tamponade:

  • Hypotension
  • Muffled heart sounds
  • Raised jugular venous pressure (elevated neck veins) with a prominent x descent(early systolic) but an absent y(early diastolic)descent. 

The echocardiography shows swinging heart sign, which is characteristic of cardiac tamponade. The pericardial pressures exceed the left ventricular diastolic filling pressures, causing the collapse of the left ventricular free wall during diastole.

Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration. In cardiac tamponade, the ventricles are covered by an incompressible pericardial sac with increased pressure in the pericardial sac. Increased blood flows into the right ventricle during inspiration causes the interventricular septum to bulge into the left ventricle, which in turn causes a reduction in left ventricular volume, stroke volume, and arterial blood pressure. This inspiratory fall in systolic pressure is an exaggerated consequence of interventricular dependence. Severe cases may show weakening or disappearance of arterial pulse on palpation during inspiration.

Other causes of pulsus paradoxus include:

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Severe obstructive lung disease
  • Hemorrhagic shock

ECG in a patient with cardiac tamponade shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans. Electrical alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction. When the heart is nearer to the chest wall, the amplitude deflection on the ECG is increased; in contrast, when the heart moves away from the chest wall, the amplitude deflection is lower. 

 

Management of cardiac tamponade -   Intravenous infusion of normal saline improves the cardiac haemodynamics in a significant proportion of tamponade patients. The best course of action is performing pericardiocentesis, preferably carried out under echocardiographic guidance. In cases of recurrent tamponade, a small catheter may be left in place to drain subsequent collections of fluid. 

Other options:

Option B: Pulsus bisferiens also known as bifid pulse has two systolic peaks. It is seen in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. There is a rapid upstroke to the first peak (percussion wave) and a slower rise to the second peak (tidal wave). It is also rarely appreciated in patients with severe aortic regurgitation.

Option C: Pulsus parvus et tardus refers to a weak pulse (parvus), which rises slowly to a delayed peak (tardus) seen in aortic stenosis.

Option D: Pulsus alternans is defined as beat-to-beat variability in the amplitude of the pulse. It is seen in patients with severe LV dysfunction.

Related Pearl: Causes of Pulsus Paradoxus

Physiological causes

Obesity

Pregnancy

Cardiovascular causes

Cardiac tamponade – most common cause

Constrictive pericarditis ( in 1/3rd cases )

Massive pulmonary embolism

Severe CCF

Hypovolemic shock

Respiratory causes

Severe obstructive lung disease

Acute severe asthma

Severe emphysema

Tension pneumothorax

questions.text: A  35-year-old woman presents with complaints of fatigue and difficulty in swallowing for the past few months. On examination, she has pallor, angular stomatitis, and a bald tongue. There is no history of weight loss. Her hemoglobin level is 9 g/dL and a peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia. A barium swallow shows the following findings. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical and laboratory findings along with the barium swallow showing an esophageal web suggest a diagnosis of Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

Plummer-Vinson syndrome, also known as Patterson-Kelly-Brown syndrome, refers to a triad of iron deficiency anemia, dysphagia, and the presence of an esophageal web. These patients present with anemia, dysphagia, glossitis, angular stomatitis, koilonychia, etc. The iron deficiency is thought to cause mucosal injury during swallowing which forms a web during the process of healing. The post-cricoid region sustains the maximum trauma during swallowing, and so this is the most common site of web formation.

The diagnostic investigation is a barium swallow, which will show a narrow filling defect in the upper esophagus. Treatment includes iron supplementation and endoscopic dilatation of the webbed region in more severe cases of dysphagia.

It is important to have a regular follow-up for such patients because the webbed area is at a higher risk for malignant transformation (squamous cell carcinoma).

Other options-

Option A- Zenker's diverticulum classically presents with dysphagia, regurgitation, and bad breath. It occurs due to an outpouching of the esophageal mucosa due to weakness in the pharyngeal muscles. It has no correlation with iron deficiency anemia. The barium swallow findings are shown below-

 

Option C- Achalasia cardia is a disorder that occurs due to the degeneration of inhibitory neurons in the myenteric plexus in the lower end of the esophagus. This is results in unopposed muscular contraction, which causes a narrowing of the lower esophagus. This presents as dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. Barium swallow shows the classic bird's beak appearance. This disorder is not caused by anemia, however, the patient can develop nutritional anemia due to this disorder.

The image below shows the bird's beak appearance on barium swallow-

 

Option D- Diffuse esophageal spasm is defined as two or more simultaneous uncoordinated contractions of the esophageal muscles with normal esophagogastric junction relaxation. This results in dysphagia, retrosternal chest pain, regurgitation, and the sensation of an object getting stuck at the back of the throat. Diagnosis is best made with esophageal manometry. Barium swallow shows the classic "cork-screw" appearance as depicted below-

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect. 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Pharyngo-esophageal diverticula

 

Diverticula Weak space Site
Zenker diverticulum Killian triangle/ Killian dehiscence

Above the upper esophageal sphincter

Between the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus muscle and the horizontal fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle
Laimer's diverticulum Laimer’s triangle/ Laimer–Hackermann’s area

Posteriorly below cricopharyngeus and above longitudinal muscle layer of the esophagus
Killian– Jamieson Diverticulum Killian–Jamieson area
 
Laterally between the oblique and transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus
at its attachment to the cricoid cartilage

questions.text: A 37 week G2P1L1 lady comes with reduced fetal movements. Her non-stress test shows a non-reactive trace. The fetus has 3 discrete gross body movements and opens and closes the palm 2 times. There are two amniotic fluid pockets measuring 2 cm in two perpendicular planes. The sonologist counts 2 fetal breathing episodes lasting 30 secs and 45 secs. What is the Manning score in this case?
questions.solution:
The Manning Score/Biophysical Score is 8 in this case, adding the scores on the following parameters:

  • The trace is nonreactive (NST) - Score of 0
  • ≥3 discrete body/limb movements (gross body movements) - Score of 2
  • Opens and closes the palm 2 times (fetal muscle tone) - Score of 2
  • 2 pockets measuring 2 cm in two perpendicular planes (amniotic fluid) - Score of 2
  • 2 fetal breathing episodes lasting 30 secs and 45 secs (fetal breathing movements) - Score of 2

Biophysical score/ Manning score:

  • It consists of 5 variables.
  • Parameters are observed for a period of 30 mins.
  • Each parameter has a maximum score of 2 and a minimum score of 0. Therefore, the total maximum score will be 10.
Parameter Normal criteria of score 2
Non-stress test Reactive pattern
Fetal breathing movements ≥1 episode lasting  > 30 second
Gross body movements ≥3 discrete body/limb movements
Fetal muscle tone ≥1 episode of active extension (limb or trunk) with the return of flexion; opening and closing of the hand, considered normal
Amniotic fluid ≥1 pocket measuring 2 cm in two perpendicular planes (2 × 2 cm pocket)

 

Score Interpretation
8- 10 Normal
6-7 Equivocal
≤5 Abnormal-  suspect asphyxia

 

Biophysical Score  Interpretation  Management 
8-10 Normal;
less risk of fetal asphyxia		 Repeat testing weekly or more 
6 Suspect chronic asphyxia  >36weeks- deliver 
Can repeat test after 4-6 hours to look for improvement 
4 Suspect chronic asphyxia 

>36 weeks- deliver 
<32 weeks- repeat testing in 4-6 hours for 120mins 
If score still </=4, deliver 
2 Strongly suspect asphyxia  >36 weeks- deliver 
<32 weeks- repeat testing in 4-6 hours for 120mins 
If score still </=4, deliver

 

Modified Biophysical Score: Only 2 parameters are included in the biophysical score, which are NST and AFI.

questions.text: A young woman presented with a butterfly-shaped malar rash, a history of recurrent oral ulcers, and pain in multiple joints. Investigations revealed pancytopenia and IgG antibodies to double-stranded DNA. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This woman with a butterfly-shaped malar rash, a history of recurrent oral ulcers, pain in multiple joints with thrombocytopenia, and antibodies to double-stranded DNA has a diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

SLE is an autoimmune disorder that results in damage to multiple organs and organ systems in the body most commonly seen in women of reproductive age.  

Clinical and immunological manifestations in SLE:

  1. Skin
    • acute, subacute cutaneous manifestations (photosensitivity, malar or maculopapular rash)
    • chronic cutaneous manifestations (discoid lupus, panniculitis, lichen planus like) 
  2. Oral or nasal ulcers
  3. Non-scarring alopecia
  4. Synovitis involving ≥2 joints
  5. Serositis (pleurisy, pericarditis)
  6. Renal: 
    • Protein/Creatinine ratio >0.5
    • RBC casts
  7. Neurologic: seizures, psychosis, myelitis, neuropathy, confusional state
  8. Hemolytic anemia
  9. Leukopenia
  10. Thrombocytopenia
  11. Immunological manifestations
    • Antinuclear antibodies >reference value (positive in >98% patients)
    • Anti-dsDNA >reference value (specific)
    • Anti-Smith antibody (specific)
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (lupus anticoagulant, false-positive rapid plasma reagin)
    • Low serum complement

To diagnose SLE, at least 4 out of 11 of the above criteria must be positive. However, if a renal biopsy is suggestive of lupus nephritis and lupus autoantibodies are positive then four criteria are not required. 

Other options: 

Option A: Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory myopathy that presents with symmetrical weakness in the proximal muscles. Classical dermatological manifestations include- gottron's papules (raised erythematous rash) on the knuckles, elbows, shawl sign on the back, and the heliotrope rash over the eyelids (erythematous discoloration with periorbital edema). Laboratory findings include elevated creatinine kinase levels and autoantibodies like anti-Mi2.

Option B: Behcet's disease is a multisystem disorder that requires recurrent oral ulceration plus two of the following criteria for a definitive diagnosis -

  • Recurrent genital ulceration
  • Occular lesions
  • Skin lesions 
  • Positive pathergy test

Laboratory findings are usually non-specific signs of inflammation and elevated C-reactive protein levels.

Option C: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disease that results in damage to the articular cartilages. It can also have a broad range of extra-articular manifestations. The autoantibodies seen in this disease are anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies and rheumatoid factor.

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

Anti dS-DNA 70 DNA(double stranded) High titres are SLE specific & in some patients correlates  with disease activity, nephritis & vasculitis

More common in black & asians than white
Anti-RNP 40 Protein complexed to U1 RNA Not Specific for SLE; high titre associated with syndromes that have overlap features of several rheumatic syndromes including SLE;
More common in blacks and whites

Primarily 60kDA and 52kDA		 Not Specific for SLE; associated with sicca syndrome, predisposes to subacute cutaneous lupus & to neonatal lupus with congenital heart block; associated with decrease risk of nephritis

(In nucleosome & chromatin)		 More frequent in drug induced lupus than in SLE

This is not a useful clinical test

(includes antiglutamate receptor)		 60 Neuronal & lymphocyte surface antigens In some series, a positive test in CSF correlates with active CNS lupus

Related Pearl: Autoantibodies Seen in Autoimmune Diseases

questions.text: During a labor posting, you happen to witness the management of a patient with difficult delivery for which the senior resident performs the maneuver shown in the image below. Name the condition for which this maneuver is performed.
questions.solution:
The image depicts McRoberts maneuver, which is performed in case of shoulder dystocia

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal shoulder impacts on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively.

Risk factors for the development of shoulder dystocia include maternal diabetes mellitus, obesity, postdatism, prior history, excessive weight gain during pregnancy, etc.

Turtle sign is positive: This is when the fetal head suddenly retracts back against the mother's perineum after it has emerged from the vagina. The baby's cheeks bulge out, resembling a turtle pulling its head back into its shell. This retraction of the fetal head is caused by the baby's anterior shoulder being caught on the back of the maternal pubic bone, preventing the delivery of the remainder of the baby.

Management of labor in case of shoulder dystocia is as follows: 

  • First line: 
    • McRoberts maneuver (flexion and abduction of the thigh)
  • Second line:
    • Woods corkscrew maneuver (Rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a corkscrew fashion) 
  • Third line:
    • Zavanelli maneuver (Push the head back and do a cesarean)
    • Cleidotomy (#clavicle of the baby)
    • Symphysiotomy (divide pubic symphysis of the mother)

Other maneuvers: Rubin, gaskin (mother on all four limbs), Hubbard, Barnum maneuver.

The image below illustrates the McRoberts maneuver.

 

The image below illustrates cleidotomy being performed: 

 

The image below illustrates Zavanelli maneuver. Here, the fetal head is rotated to the direct occiput anterior position and pushed back into the uterus so that the fetus can be delivered by cesarean section. The cardinal movements of labor are reversed. 

Note:

  • In a case of bilateral shoulder dystocia, directly proceed to perform cesarean section after doing Zavanelli maneuver.
  • Never give fundal pressure in shoulder dystocia (suprapubic pressure can be given).

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was referred to the dermatology outpatient department with painful, erythematous nodular lesions on the extensor surface of the upper limbs. He also complains of fever and malaise. He had completed treatment for leprosy six months ago. This condition is caused by __________.
questions.solution:
The given scenario of painful, erythematous nodules over the limbs (extensor surface) in a patient with leprosy is suggestive of erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) or type II lepra reaction. It is caused by type III hypersensitivity reaction which is immune-complex mediated.

Type II lepra reactions (ENL) are mainly seen in multibacillary disease; LL (50%) > BL (15%). They can occur before, during, or after treatment, and are commonly recurrent. These reactions are caused by immune complexes (type III hypersensitivity). ENL presents with painful, erythematous nodules on the face and extensor surfaces of limbs. Systemic manifestations like fever, malaise, anorexia, neuritis, uveitis, dactylitis, arthritis, myositis, etc. can also be seen. Treatment of type II lepra reactions includes high-dose steroids, thalidomide (drug of choice in young men with severe ENL), and clofazimine.

Type I lepra reaction, on the other hand, is caused by type IV hypersensitivity reaction, i.e. cell-mediated immune inflammation within existing skin lesions.

Related Pearl: Lepra Reactions

Lepra Reactions:

Type 1 Reaction

(Reversal/Upgrading)

Type 2 Reaction

(Erythema Nodosum Leprosum)

Mainly seen in the Borderline spectrum (BT, BB, BL)

Most severe in Borderline Lepromatous(BL) leprosy

 Mainly seen in LL(50%)>BL(15%)

Usually seen within 12 months of initiation of Multidrug Therapy

 Unrelated to Multidrug therapy. May occur before, during or after treatment

Type 4 Hypersensitivity

Due to enhanced cell-mediated response increased destruction of bacilli following treatment in reversal

Type 3 Hypersensitivity

Primarily Humoral

(Immune complex Deposition in tissues and vessels)

Cytokine involved - TNF-α

Inflammation of existing skin lesions (red, painful edematous skin lesions) that may ulcerate

New lesions may occur (rare)

Neuritis and Nerve abscesses (red, painful inflamed nerves)

New, erythematous and tender, subcutaneous and dermal nodules that are widely distributed over extremities and face

Existing lesions do not change
No systemic involvement Systemic symptoms present - fever, myalgias, arthralgias, anorexia, keratitis, iritis, nephritis, synovitis, orchitis, lymphadenopathy

Treatment:

Supportive therapy for mild reactions with NSAIDs

In case of severe reactions with neuritis and eye lesions- Oral corticosteroids

(Drug of Choice)

Nerve Abscess - Additional surgical drainage

Other drugs: Clofazimine, Cyclosporine

Treatment:

Oral Corticosteroids - First-line drug

Clofazimine (Steroid dependent ENL)

Thalidomide -most effective but not used first due to various side effects

 

 

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

  • Atopic dermatitis
