questions.text: A 34-year-old farmer presents with complaints of shortness of breath and productive cough with orange mucus plugs for the past 2-3 weeks. His symptoms began after exposure to plant waste. He has a history of bronchial asthma and examination revealed rhonchi. Chest X-ray of the patient is shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the chest X-ray showing the finger-in-glove appearance are suggestive of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is a hypersensitivity reaction involving the major airways. It is most commonly seen in patients with longstanding asthma. It can also be associated with cystic fibrosis. The condition is diagnosed in younger patients usually before 40 years of age. The patient typically presents with atopic symptoms. Sometimes expectorant cough with orange mucus plugs may be seen.

Radiographic findings in ABPA include:

  • Lobar collapse
  • Non-segmental areas of opacities commonly involving the upper lobe
  • Branching thick tubular opacities due to distended bronchi filled with fungus and mucus - Finger-in-glove appearance 
  • Pulmonary cavitation is rarely seen

Other features of aspergillus infection:

Aspergilloma: Aspergillomas are mass-like fungus balls that are typically composed of Aspergillus fumigatus and are a non-invasive form of pulmonary aspergillosis. Aspergillomas occur in patients with normal immunity but structurally abnormal lungs, with pre-existing cavities. The most common underlying condition is pulmonary tuberculosis. Radiographic findings of aspergilloma include:

  • Air crescent sign - The fungal ball can be seen on both plain film and CT as an intracavitary mass surrounded by a crescent of air.
  • The mass usually moves within the cavity when the patient moves and this sign is called the Monod sign.

Angioinvasive aspergillosis: It is seen in immunocompromised individuals, especially in patients with neutropenia. Halo sign is the typical CT finding in these patients.

  • The halo sign in chest imaging is a feature seen on HRCT where ground glass opacity surrounds a pulmonary nodule or mass and represents hemorrhage. 

Air crescent sign:

Halo sign:

 

Other options:

Option A- Bronchiectasis is characterized by local and irreversible dilatation of bronchi. Radiographic findings are:

  • Tramline appearance is seen in chest X-rays.
  • Ring or curvilinear opacities on end-on appearance.
  • CT shows bronchial dilatation and lack of tapering of bronchial lumen. It is the cardinal sign.
  • Signet ring sign - Internal diameter of the bronchi is greater than the adjacent pulmonary artery.

Signet ring sign:

 

Option B- Blastomycosis is a chronic infection, characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions, especially in the lungs and skin. The pulmonary disease resembles TB or histoplasmosis. There can be focal or diffuse consolidation, miliary lesions, or abscess formation.

 

Option C- Pulmonary tuberculosis chest radiograph typically shows upper lobe infiltrates with cavities. In immunocompromised individuals like in HIV patients, there can be lower zone infiltrates without cavity formation. In disseminated TB miliary reticulonodular patterns may be seen.

Chest X-ray showing miliary TB:

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with P2L2 presented with heavy menstrual bleeding and lower abdominal discomfort. On examination, the uterus appears uniformly enlarged and the adnexa is free. On further investigation, the uterus shows the following finding seen on the MRI. The patient doesn't desire any more children. What will be the initial plan of management for this patient?

IUD- Intrauterine device
questions.solution:
The clinical history of menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, and pelvic discomfort in a parous woman and a symmetrically enlarged uterus on examination are suggestive of adenomyosis.  Sagittal MRI of this woman's pelvis shows a uterus with adenomyosis in the posterior wall. The initial step in management is diagnostic hysteroscopy with curettage.

Adenomyosis (Endometriosis interna):

Etiology: Prior curettage, prior uterine surgery, repeated childbirth, excess of estrogen, intake of tamoxifen (SERM)

Clinical features:

  • Multiparous women >40 years
  • Most common symptom - Menorrhagia > Dysmenorrhea
  • Per-Vaginal examination: Symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to <12-14 weeks of pregnancy
  • Bimanual examination: Halban’s sign - Tender, softened uterus

Diagnosis:

  • It is mainly clinical. The uterus is symmetrically enlarged and rarely exceeds 14 weeks in size.
  • Diagnostic hysteroscopy with curettage
  • TVS or MRI ( MRI is superior to USG in showing hypo or anechoic areas in the uterine wall)

Management:

  • A diagnostic hysteroscopy combined with curettage is the initial step in the management of adenomyosis (because of menorrhagia).
  • Total Hysterectomy is the treatment of choice
  • Localized excision/ Levonorgestrel containing IUCD, Mirena is tried in younger women

IMAGE: The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with a spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of hemorrhage. The H&E stained specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis. Uterine size rarely exceeds 14 weeks in adenomyosis.

 

Note:

Uterine Artery Embolization/Uterine Fibroid Embolization (UAE/UFE) is a promising non-surgical alternative treatment option for patients with menorrhagia and adenomyosis. It is an angiographic interventional procedure that delivers polyvinyl alcohol microspheres or other synthetic particulate emboli into both uterine arteries thus producing ischemia and necrosis. Because vessels serving leiomyomas have a larger caliber, these microspheres are preferentially directed to the tumors, sparing the surrounding myometrium. UAE helped in decreasing the uterine size and junctional zone thickness in cases of adenomyosis.

questions.text:
The pulmonary function of a patient is tested and the following recording is noted. A physiology resident observes the graph and enters the values given below. Which of the following parameters has been calculated erroneously?
Volumes Values
1. Tidal volume  500 mL
2. Inspiratory reserve volume 3L
3. Expiratory reserve volume 1L
4. Inspiratory capacity 4.5L
questions.solution:
The resident has calculated the inspiratory capacity wrongly.

In the above graph, 

Tidal volume (TV) is the amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration or the amount that moves out with each expiration during quiet breathing. In this patient, it is 500 mL. The normal values are 500-750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) is the air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the tidal volume. In this patient, it is 6-3L = 3L. The normal values are around 3 L.

Expiratory reserve volume is (ERV) is the volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration. In this patient it is 2.5-1.5 = 1L. The normal value is around 1.1 L.

Inspiratory capacity (IC) is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level. It can be calculated as TV+IRV which is 0.5L + 3L= 3.5L. The normal value is around 3.5 L.

Expiratory capacity (EC) is the maximum amount of air that expired after a normal inspiration. It is calculated as TV+ERV, which is 0.5L + 1L = 1.5 L. Normal value is around 1.5 L

Vital capacity (VC) refers to the maximum amount of air expiring from the fully inflated lungs. It is calculated as TV+IRV+ERV. In this patient it is 0.5+ 3+1 =4.5L. The normal value is around 4.5 L.

Other important lung values:

The forced vital capacity (FVC), is the largest amount of air that can be expired after a maximal inspiratory effort.

Forced expiratory volume in the first second, FEV1, is the fraction of the vital capacity that expired during the first second. 

Respiratory minute volume (RVV) is a measurement of the amount of air that enters the lungs per minute. It is calculated as respiratory rate X tidal volume.

Maximal voluntary respiration (MVV), is the largest volume of gas that can be moved into and out of the lungs in 1 min by voluntary effort.

Total lung capacity is the total volume of the lung. It can be calculated by adding tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume. Normal total lung capacity is around 5.8 L.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

questions.text:
Identify the correct statement about pituitary gonadotropins.

LH- Luteinizing hormone

FSH- follicle-stimulating hormone

choices.text: LH levels are lower than FSH during the reproductive years
LH and FSH are strikingly low after menopause
FSH: LH ratio is typically elevated before menarche
The LH surge magnitude decreases after puberty

questions.solution:
FSH: LH ratio is typically elevated before menarche.

GnRH is initially secreted in low-frequency pulses early in puberty, which favors FSH secretion initially. FSH: LH ratio is typically increased in the premenarchal girl. Later in puberty, the GnRH pulsatile frequency increases with a greater rise in LH surges, leading to the establishment of the adult pattern of gonadotropin release. 

Increased gonadotropin levels stimulate estradiol production from the ovaries. This in turn prompts the growth spurt, maturation of the female internal and external genitalia, and development of female secondary sexual characteristics - thelarche, pubarche, adrenarche. Increased gonadotropin levels ultimately lead to ovulation and subsequent menses - menarche.

During the reproductive years, LH levels exceed FSH levels, and the FSH: LH ratio gets inverted.

After menopause, the ovary contains only a few follicles, leading to low levels of estrogen and inhibin. LH and FSH levels are subsequently elevated due to loss of the negative feedback from estrogen and inhibin.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the area marked on the visceral surface of the spleen?
questions.solution:
The area marked on the visceral surface of the spleen is related to the left kidney.

The visceral surface of the spleen as shown here faces inferomedially. It has three important surface impressions i.e. the gastric impression, the renal impression, and the colic impression.  The superolateral surface is in relation to the diaphragm, and this area is separated from the gastric impression by the anterosuperior border as shown in the above diagram. The anterosuperior surface has 1-2 notches, which are thought to be remnants of the lobulated form of the spleen during embryological development. The renal impression is the area that is related to the left kidney. This impression is separated from the diaphragmatic surface by the posteroinferior border of the spleen. It is separated from the gastric impression by the splenic hilum and a small ridge of tissue. 

The spleen has two poles. The superior pole is more angulated than the inferior pole, which is broader. The superior pole is the poster-most part of the spleen, close to the vertebral column. The inferior pole is related to the colic impression, which is close to the splenic flexure of the large colon, as well as the phrenicocolic ligament (the ligament connecting the diaphragm and the colon). The inferior pole is also most likely to be injured during blunt abdominal trauma. 

The hilum of the spleen in the middle of the visceral surface is the part of the spleen where the splenic vessels, nerves, and lymphatics penetrate the splenic tissue. The tail of the pancreas has its visceral impression between the hilum and colic impression.

The image below depicts the various anatomical relations of the spleen-

questions.text: A young man is brought to the ER with weakness in both legs since yesterday. The weakness has progressed to his arms now and he is having difficulty in breathing. He had an episode of diarrhea 2 weeks ago. Physical examination shows flaccid paralysis in all four limbs and arreflexia. CSF examination shows elevated protein levels but normal cell count. What is the further management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The presence of ascending, flaccid type of paralysis following an episode of diarrhea 2 weeks ago, and CSF examination showing increased protein with normal cell count, point to a diagnosis of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). 

Guillian-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute, autoimmune polyneuropathy. The possible antecedent events include respiratory or gastrointestinal infections. The implicated organisms include Campylobacter jejuni, CMV, EBV, and Mycoplasma pneumonia.

The usual presentation is symmetrical, ascending paralysis evolving over hours to a few days. The legs are usually more affected than the arms. Lower cranial nerves are also frequently involved, causing bulbar weakness and difficulty in maintaining an airway and handling secretions. Almost one-third of the patients require mechanical ventilation due to weakness of the respiratory muscles. Deep tendon reflexes also attenuate or disappear within a few days of onset. 

Sensations carried by large myelinated fibers like deep tendon reflexes and proprioception are also affected. Pain and temperature sensations are relatively preserved. Autonomic involvement usually presents with loss of vasomotor control with wide fluctuations in blood pressure and postural hypotension. Fever and constitutional symptoms are absent at the onset of the weakness. Similarly, bladder dysfunction occurs only in severe GBS and is transient. Prominent bladder dysfunction occurring early in the disease course goes against the diagnosis of GBS. 

The patient is likely to have clinical worsening during the first four weeks following the onset of weakness. After this, there's a plateauing of the symptoms and any further deterioration is unlikely.

The treatment for GBS should be initiated as early as possible. High-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis can be used for the treatment. A sequential combination of the two has not been found to be more effective than either of them alone. Corticosteroids (option A) are not effective in the treatment of GBS.

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in Guillian Barre syndrome

Type Antibody
AIDP Anti GM1
AMAN Anti GD1a
AMSAN Anti GD1a
Miller Fisher syndrome Anti GQ1b
  • AIDP-Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy 
  • AMAN-Acute motor axonal neuropathy 
  • AMSAN-Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

questions.text: On a particularly busy day in the labor room, you are requested by the PG to take anthropometric measurements and calculate the ponderal index of a baby while she attends to another baby. You find the ponderal index to be 1.45. Which of the following organs is unlikely to be affected in this neonate?
questions.solution:
A ponderal index of <2 suggests asymmetric intrauterine growth restriction. Asymmetric IUGR is associated with a brain-sparing effect, unlike symmetric IUGR, where there is no sparing of head growth.

Ponderal index = Birth weight (gm)/Length (cm)3 x 100.

It is a weight-height-related parameter used as an indicator of fetal growth status.

Symmetric IUGR Asymmetric IUGR
Insult on fetal growth occurs early Insult occurs in late gestation
Head circumference, length, and weight are equally affected Relative sparing of brain growth
A ponderal index greater than or equal to 2  A ponderal index less than 2 
Caused by genetic, chromosomal disorders, or TORCH infections Caused by placental insufficiency, pregnancy-induced hypertension, or maternal medical diseases

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of a constant leakage of urine and dysuria even after undergoing fistula repair surgery for vesicovaginal fistula. You decide to attempt a second fistula repair surgery. In order to perform the second surgery, you would counsel the patient to wait for at least
questions.solution:
In order to perform the second surgery, you should counsel the patient to wait for at least 3 months.

The given scenario is suggestive of failed surgery. If the fistula repair fails, one should wait for at least 3 months before attempting a second repair.

Patients usually present with constant dribbling of urine (true incontinence). The constant leakage of urine may lead to excoriation of genital regions. The fistula located at the vaginal vault post-hysterectomy is the most difficult to treat.

Most vesicovaginal fistulae are repaired per vaginally. The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF (vesicovaginal fistula) are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure
  • Chasser Moir technique
  • Ureteric implantation

questions.text: Which of the following flaps involves the isolation of blood supply, disconnection, and finally reconnection using microsurgery?
questions.solution:
Free flaps involve isolation of blood supply, disconnection, and then reconnection using microsurgery at the new site. 

Flaps are tissues that bring vascularity as they are transferred with their blood supply. Different types of flaps are: 

  1. Random flaps have no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters. It is basically three sides of a rectangle, and the length-to-breadth ratio is less than 1.5:1. 'Delaying the flap' is a process in which cuts are partially made and the flap is partly lifted at a first operation. It is then replaced, thus ‘training’ the blood supply from a single border of the rectangle. A second procedure is conducted where it is raised further and finally transferred.
  2. Axial flaps - These are longer flaps. They are based on known blood vessels supplying the skin. This technique enables many long thin flaps to be safely moved across large distances.
  3. Pedicled/islanded flaps - They can be swung around on a stalk or even fully ‘islanded’ because of the axial blood supply. The business end of the skin being transferred can hence have the pedicle buried.
  4. Free flaps - In this case the blood supply is isolated, disconnected, and then reconnected using microsurgery at the new site 
  5. Composite flaps - Often skin with bone or muscle is transferred with the flap (osseocutaneous or myocutaneous flaps, respectively).
  6. Perforator flaps - Tissues are isolated on small perforating vessels that run from more major blood vessels to supply the surface. It is a subgroup of an axial flap.

Skin-bearing flaps are also classified based on -

  • Composition: Refers to the tissue contained within the flap, such as cutaneous, musculocutaneous, fasciocutaneous etc
  • Method of movement:
    • Local transfer, eg. advancement or rotation flaps
    • Distant transfer, eg. pedicle flaps from the abdomen to the perineum or micro-vascular free flaps.
  • Blood supply:
    • Musculocutaneous arteries travel perpendicularly through muscle to the overlying skin.
    • Septocutaneous arteries travel with intermuscular fascial septa to supply the overlying skin.

questions.text: A  man suffering from ulcerative colitis for the past several years presents with jaundice and pruritus. Investigations show elevated serum alkaline phosphatase levels, and MRCP shows beading in the bile ducts. Biopsy reveals fibrosis of the bile ducts, as shown below. Which of the following is true about the disorder that has caused jaundice?

choices.text: Antimitochondrial antibodies present in most patients
Strictures and dilatations are restricted to intra-hepatic ducts
p-ANCA is positive in most of the patients

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) in a patient with a past history of ulcerative colitis. p-ANCA is positive in this condition.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is a progressive inflammatory disorder characterized by obliterative fibrosis of both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts (Option C). It is strongly associated with ulcerative colitis.

Clinical features comprise right upper quadrant abdominal pain, pruritus, obstructive jaundice, fatigue, steatorrhea, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies. It can progress to biliary cirrhosis, portal hypertension, cholangiocarcinoma, and liver failure. (Option A)

Laboratory findings are a two-fold or greater increase in alkaline phosphatase levels, elevated aminotransferase levels, and prolonged prothrombin time. p-ANCA is positive in 65% of the patients with PSC.

The imaging test of choice is magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP). Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) can also be performed to further localize areas of dominant strictures. The cholangiography findings include multifocal strictures with intervening dilated or normal bile duct segments producing a classic beaded appearance. Liver biopsy reveals periductal fibrosis and onion skinning.

Glucocorticoids are used to treat initially. Azathioprine may be added if there is inadequate response or relapse. Endoscopic dilatation of the strictures may help to improve symptoms. Definitive management is only with liver transplantation. PSC is one of the risk factors for the development of colon cancer in patients with ulcerative colitis.

The image below shows a cholangiogram of primary sclerosing cholangitis. There are diffuse strictures of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with dilatation of the areas in between:

Other options-

Option B: Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are seen in most patients with primary biliary cholangitis, and not in PSC.

Related Pearl: Differences between primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

  Primary Biliary Cholangitis Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis
Antibodies

Antimitochondrial antibodies positive in most patients

Antinuclear antibodies positive

Antimitochondrial antibodies /AMA typically negative

p-ANCA-positive
Age group 40–60 years 30-45 years
Gender predominance Females Males
Site Intrahepatic bile ducts only Intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts
 Associated with

Sjogren syndrome

Hashimoto's thyroiditis 

CREST syndrome

Rheumatoid arthritis

Celiac disease

 Ulcerative colitis
Diagnosis Biopsy MRCP/ERCP-strictures 
Biopsy findings  Florid duct lesion (granuloma) Concentric "onion-skin" fibrosis    
Long-term complication Cirrhosis

Cirrhosis

Cholangiocarcinoma

questions.text: The following muscle is marked in the anatomy practical exam, the examiner asks you to provide the origin, insertion, and nerve supply of it. What would your answer be?

choices.text: Origin:  Radius, Insertion: Ulna, Nerve supply: Median nerve
Origin:  Radius, Insertion: Ulna, Nerve supply: Radial nerve
Origin: Ulna, Insertion: Radius, Nerve supply: Median nerve
Origin: Ulna, Insertion: Radius, Nerve supply: Radial nerve

questions.solution:
The marked structure in the image is the pronator quadratus muscle. The answer is origin: Ulna, insertion: Radius, nerve supply: Median nerve. 

The pronator quadratus is a flat quadrilateral-shaped muscle, that extends across the front of the distal ends of the radius and ulna. It arises from the anterior surface of the shaft of the ulna and inserts into the shaft of the radius and the ulnar notch of the radius.

The pronator quadratus is innervated by the median nerve (C7 and 8). It is supplied by the anterior interosseus artery. It causes the pronation of the forearm at the radioulnar joint.

questions.text:
In the given image, the value of the ratio y/x is pathognomic if it is above:

y - thickness of the mucous gland layer
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the Reid index. It is the ratio of the thickness of the mucous gland layer (y) to the thickness of the wall between the cartilage and the epithelium (x). It is normally 0.4 and is increased in chronic bronchitis. The increase is in proportion to the severity and duration of the disease.

Chronic bronchitis is defined by the presence of a persistent productive cough for at least 3 consecutive months in at least 2 consecutive years.

The single most important cause is cigarette smoking. The distinctive features of chronic bronchitis are as follows:

  • Hypersecretion of mucus
  • Hypertrophy of submucosal glands
  • Goblet-cell hyperplasia
  • Inflammation
Difference between emphysema and chronic bronchitis:

Severe; early

Common

questions.text: You are assisting a case of superficial parotidectomy as a junior resident. Your consultant asks you to identify the buccal branch of the facial nerve to trace back to the facial nerve trunk. Which of the following anatomical landmarks is used for the identification of the buccal branch of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
The buccal branch of the facial nerve lies in relation to the parotid duct and is used as an anatomical landmark for the retrograde identification of the facial nerve trunk.

There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk: 

1. Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on the anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. They are then traced distally to arrive at the facial nerve trunk. The anatomical landmarks include:

  • Tragal pointer/Conley's pointer: It is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
  • Posterior belly of digastric: The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle. (Option D)
  • Squamotympanic fissure: It is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympanic cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.
  • Styloid process: The facial nerve lies superficial to it. (Option B)
  • Mastoid process: Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.

2. Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified and are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some of the main branches that are commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:

  • Buccal branch: It lies in relation to the parotid duct.
  • Marginal mandibular branch: It lies in relation to the facial vessels. (Option A)
  • Temporal branch

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with developmental delay, short stature, a tendency to sunburn easily, and dry, scaly skin.  He has short and brittle hair and sparse eyebrows. Under polarized light microscopy of the hair strand, a pattern of alternating light and dark ‘tiger‐tail’ bands is seen.  What can be the  DNA repair defect in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of trichothiodystrophy (TTD) which is caused by defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER). Features like developmental delay, short stature, photosensitivity, and ichthyosis with short, brittle, and sparse hair are suggestive of the diagnosis. 

Trichothiodystrophy is an autosomal recessive disorder of DNA repair. Most patients carry mutations in the ERCC2 (XPD) gene of the nucleotide excision repair mechanism.

It is a multisystem disorder characterized by short, brittle, sulfur-deficient hair with a pattern of alternating light and dark ‘tiger‐tail’ bands under polarized light microscopy. Other features include photosensitivity, ichthyosis, developmental delay, and short stature.

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

questions.text:
A young woman presented with dizziness, vomiting, and foul-smelling vaginal discharge. She had a fever for the past 3 days. On examination, she has low blood pressure, conjunctival hyperemia, and a red rash over a large portion of her skin. She says that her menstrual period got over last week, but on vaginal examination, a retained tampon was discovered. What is the most likely diagnosis?

DRESS: Drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms
questions.solution:
The above presentation of fever, hypotension, erythroderma, conjunctival hyperemia, vomiting, and the finding of a retained vaginal tampon point towards a likely diagnosis of toxic shock syndrome.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a toxin-mediated disease that is most commonly associated with staphylococcal and group A streptococcal infections. Streptococcal TSS is associated with pyrogenic exotoxin and other toxins that act as superantigens and mediate the release of proinflammatory cytokines. Staphylococcal TSS, on the other hand, is associated with the toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), which binds directly to the MHC II complex and T-cell receptors. This results in a massive increase in T-cell production, leading to a cytokine storm.

Streptococcal TSS is usually seen in the setting of soft tissue infections like necrotising fasciitis, cellulitis, etc., and staphylococcal TSS is seen in settings of retained tampons, nasal packing, wound packing, etc. Hence, in this case, we are more likely to suspect a staphylococcal aetiology.

The clinical criteria required to diagnose TSS include fever >102 °F, erythroderma with desquamation after 1-2 weeks, hypotension, and the involvement of >3 organ systems. The laboratory diagnosis of staphylococcal TSS can be made with a Gram stain of the infected site, which would show gram-positive cocci in clusters.

These patients should be managed aggressively with fluids and systemic antibiotic therapy. They can be started on drugs like intravenous vancomycin/ daptomycin initially to allow for MRSA (methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus) coverage. Antibiotics can later be changed based on culture sensitivity reports. 

The T-cell activation which produces the cytokine storm in TSS can be seen in the image below:

Other options:

Option (A): DRESS refers to drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms. Although it can also present with an exfoliating erythroderma, DRESS is usually seen after the use of drugs like anticonvulsants, sulphonamides, etc. It presents with hepatic dysfunction and profound eosinophilia.

Option (B): Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is a disorder commonly seen in newborns and children. It presents with multiple fluid-filled blisters that rupture easily on applying mild pressure.

Option (D): Steven-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is most commonly a drug-induced condition that has a wide range of skin manifestations like purpuric papules, bullae, erythroderma, as well as desquamation. Nikolsky's sign (skin slippage on applying pressure) is often positive. It is usually seen in immunocompromised individuals. SJS involves <10% of the skin surface. However, it can progress to involve >30%, and at this point, it is called TEN (toxic epidermal necrolysis).

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Staphylococcus

Staphylococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Furuncle/boil- Infection of the hair follicle.

The given image shows a furuncle:

 

b. Carbuncle: A cluster of several furuncles:

The given image shows a carbuncle:

 

c. Bullous impetigo: Results in large blisters called bullae, usually seen in areas with skin folds such as armpits, groin, buttocks, etc.

The given image shows ruptured bullous impetigo:

 

d. Cellulitis: It is a rapidly spreading infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, usually associated with wounds, incisions, burns, etc.

The given image shows cellulitis following an abrasion. The red streaks indicate the involvement of the lymphatics:

 

e. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by exfoliating toxin that causes peeling of the skin.

The given image shows SSSS:

 

Note: The conditions shown above are most commonly caused by Staphylococcus. It is important to remember that they may also be caused by other bacteria. Cellulitis is more commonly caused by Streptococcus.

Related Pearl: Cutaneous Infections/Diseases caused by Staphylococcus aureus

Cutaneous Infections/Diseases caused by Staphylococcus aureus

A. Direct infection of skin and adjacent tissues

  • Carbuncle
  • Ecthyma
  • Folliculitis
  • Furunculosis
  • Impetigo
  • Sycosis

B. Secondary infection

  • Eczema, infestations, ulcers, etc.

C. Cutaneous disease due to effect of bacterial toxin

  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)
  • Toxic shock syndrome
  • Staphylococcal scarlatina
  • Recurrent toxin‐mediated perineal erythema

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: Ovarian tumors containing nests of neoplastic epithelial cells resembling urothelium surrounded by abundant dense, fibrous stroma are called:
questions.solution:
Ovarian tumors containing nests of neoplastic epithelial cells resembling urothelium surrounded by abundant dense, fibrous stroma are Brenner tumors or transitional cell tumors.

Transitional cell tumors are a rare type of ovarian epithelial tumor. They contain neoplastic epithelial cells resembling urothelium and are usually benign. They are often detected incidentally and even when large they do not produce any symptoms.

Microscopy features include fibrous stroma, with sharply demarcated nests of urothelial cells, often with mucinous glands in their center, called Walthard cell rests, as seen in the image below:

Other options:

Option B- Krukenberg tumor is a bilateral metastatic ovarian malignancy with the primary site in the gastrointestinal tract. Microscopically, it is characterized by the appearance of mucin-secreting signet-ring cells in the tissue of the ovary.

Option C- Sertoli cell tumor is a sex cord-stromal tumor that commonly produces masculinization or defeminization. These tumors showed a range of  differentiation:

 - Well-differentiated tumors show tubules composed of Sertoli cells or Leydig cells interspersed with stroma
 - Intermediate forms show immature tubules with large eosinophilic Leydig cell
 - Poorly differentiated show sarcomatous pattern

Option D- Hilus cell tumors or pure Leydig cell tumors are also sex cord-stromal tumors. They are rare and unilateral tumors. Large lipid-laden Leydig cells with distinct borders and characteristic rod-shaped cytoplasmic structures called Reinke crystalloids are present in these tumors. Females with hilus cell tumors usually have features of masculinization.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal

Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient had to undergo a cesarean section in a hospital due to a complicated delivery. She was discharged on her 5th-day postpartum. How many visits by an ASHA worker is recommended in this case?
questions.solution:
As this case is an institutional delivery through LSCS, the patient would be discharged after 5-6 days from the hospital, therefore 5 visits by the ASHA worker are recommended here.

The total incentive received by ASHA for HBNC (Home-based newborn care) is Rs. 250 if she completes all her visits.

ASHA visits all newborns on proper schedule up to their 42 days of life. The number of home visits will be,

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42).
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (no visit on day 1).
  • 5 visits to those born in a facility through LSCS (no visits on day 1 and day 3).

In case a newborn is discharged from SNCU, then ASHA will receive a full incentive after completing the remaining visits. ASHA will do additional follow-up visits every month for low-birth-weight newborns up to two years, and SNCU discharged babies up to one year. For each follow-up visit, ASHA will receive an additional Rs. 50.

If the woman delivers at her maternal house and returns to her husband’s house or vice versa, the visits might have been done by two ASHAs at the two different places. In such cases, if each ASHA completes at least 3 visits, they will receive Rs 125 each. If ASHA completes less than 3 visits, they will not receive any incentive.

In the case of twins/triplets, then ASHA will receive twice (Rs. 500) or thrice (Rs. 750), the regular payment.

The payments are made to ASHA on the 45th day, subject to the following conditions:

  • The birth weight is recorded in the Maternal and Child Protection (MCP) Card.
  • Ensuring that the newborn is immunized with BCG, first doses of OPV and DPT/Pentavalent, and entered into the MCP card.
  • Enabling birth registration.
  • Both mother and newborn are safe until the 42nd day.

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant with dysmorphic facies was brought to the clinic with complaints of recurrent bacterial infections of the skin, mouth, and respiratory tract. Interestingly, the baby has a Bombay blood group. Which of the following is likely to be associated with the underlying condition in this infant?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation points towards a diagnosis of leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD)- type 2, which results from defective fucose incorporation. Craniofacial dysmorphism and the Bombay blood group are features unique to LAD-2.

LAD-2 is also known as the congenital disorder of glycosylation II-C. This abnormality prevents the incorporation of fucose into various cell surface glycoproteins, including the carbohydrate structure Sialyl Lewis X, which is critical for the rolling and adhesion of neutrophils to vascular endothelium.

Other options:

Option A- Defective β2 integrin occurs in LAD-1 in which steady adhesion of leukocyte to endothelial surfaces is defective. Some of the characteristics seen in LAD-1 are delayed separation of the umbilical cord, recurrent pyogenic infections with onset in the first week of life, infections caused by Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, absent pus formation, and periodontitis. 

Option C- Defective kindlin-3 gene, which affects integrin activation cascade, is seen in LAD-3. LAD-3 is characterized by a Glanzmann thrombasthenia-like bleeding disorder, delayed separation of the umbilical cord, and skin and soft tissue infections similar to those seen in LAD-1.

Option D- Defective lysosomal traffic regulator (LYST) gene in chromosome 1 is associated with Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS). Patients have light skin and silvery hair. They frequently complain about recurrent infections, photosensitivity, photophobia, infections, and neuropathy. 

Note:

Both LAD and CHS are autosomal recessive disorders. 

Related Pearl: Defects in Leukocyte Function

Disease

Defect

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 1

Mutations in β chain of CD11/CD18 integrins

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 2

Mutations in fucosyltransferase

Chediak–Higashi syndrome

Decreased leukocyte functions because of mutations affecting protein involved in lysosomal membrane traffic (LYST)

Chronic granulomatous disease

Defect in gene encoding phagocyte oxidase

Myeloperoxidase deficiency

Decreased microbial killing because of defective MPO-H2O2 system

questions.text: An epidemiologist, upon data collection, notices that the nation in which the study had been done had a death rate that was declining faster than the birth rate. Which stage of the demographic cycle does this country belong to?
questions.solution:
The country belongs to the late expanding stage of the demographic cycle. It is also called the third stage of the demographic cycle.

In the third stage of the demographic cycle, the population continues to grow because the number of births exceeds the number of deaths. Here the death rate keeps declining and the birth rate has a tendency to fall. India is an example of a country in this stage of the demographic cycle.

Other options:

Option A: Declining or the fifth stage of the demographic cycle involves a decline in population because the birth rate is lower than the death rate. Germany is an example of this stage of the demographic cycle.

Option B: Early expanding or the second stage of the demographic cycle involves countries that have a death rate that begins to decline and a birth rate that remains unchanged. This includes many countries in Africa.

Option D: Low-stationary or fourth stage of the demographic cycle involves countries with a stationary population owing to a low birth and death rate. An example of this would be Austria between the years 1980 and 1985.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is diagnosed to have cervical cancer. MRI and PET-CT imaging reveal tumour extension up to the pelvic wall and involvement of the para-aortic lymph nodes. It also shows features suggestive of hydronephrosis. What is the best plan of management in this case?

choices.text: Modified radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy

questions.solution:
Cervical cancer involving the para-aortic lymph nodes is classified as Stage III C2 according to FIGO staging. Chemotherapy with radiation is the best plan of management in this case.

Note: If the patient just had carcinoma extension up to the pelvic wall and/or the presence of hydronephrosis, it would have been classified as Stage IIIB.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

Related Pearl: General treatment for primary invasive cervical carcinoma

Stages Fertility preserved Fertility not preserved
IA1 Cervical conization Simple hysterectomy
IA1 (LVSI) Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Modified radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
IA2

1. Cervical conization with extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy

2. Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

 Modified Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

IB1

Some IB2, IIA1

 Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or)chemoradiation Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or) chemoradiation
Bulky IB3, IIA2 Chemoradiation
IIB to IVA Chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration 
IVB Palliative chemotherapy or palliative radiotherapy or supportive care

questions.text: A 21-year-old student presents with ocular redness, foreign body sensation, and excessive tearing following the use of a contact lens. An interface contrast microscopy from his corneal scraping is shown below. What would be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of redness, watering and foreign body sensation in a contact lens wearer along with the demonstration of polygonal cysts in interface contrast microscopy are suggestive of amoebic keratitis caused by acanthamoeba.

Acanthamoeba culbertsoni is an opportunistic protozoan pathogen. It exists as a trophozoite form and resistant cystic form. Both these forms are infective. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia called acanthopodia.

Human beings acquire the infection by inhalation of cysts or trophozoites, directly through traumatized skin or eyes, or ingestion of cysts.

It chiefly presents as two chronic conditions:

  • Acanthamoeba keratitis
  • Granulomatous amoebic encephalitis

Acanthamoeba keratitis is an infection of the eyes that typically develops from the entry of the amebic cyst through abrasions on the cornea. Most of the cases are associated with the use of contact lenses. 

Patients usually present with photophobia, excessive tearing, redness, and foreign body sensation and it can be bilateral in contact lens users.

Diagnosis of amoebic keratitis is made by the demonstration of the cyst in corneal scrapings by wet mount, histology, and culture. The cysts are smaller (12-25 micrometer) and polygonal or star-shaped.

Topical administration of biguanides or chlorhexidine with or without diamidine agents can be used for the management of acanthamoeba keratitis. In severe cases penetrating keratoplasty can be done.

The below image shows the ring lesion seen in acanthamoeba keratitis.

Other options:

Option B- Naegleria fowleri causes a brain infection, primary amebic meningoencephalitis that leads to brain tissue destruction. Their cysts are spherical and have a smooth double wall. 

Option C- Entamoeba histolytica causes intestinal and extraintestinal amebiasis. Their cysts are spherical in shape. A mature quadrinucleate cyst is an infective form.  An amebic ulcer is a typical lesion seen in intestinal amebiasis which is a flask-shaped ulcer on cross-section. Amebic liver abscess is extraintestinal amebiasis. The center of the abscess contains thick brown-colored pus termed anchovy sauce pus.

Option D- Balamuthia mandrillaris is a free-living ameba that causes granulomatous amebic encephalitis. Their cyst is usually spherical and surrounded by a three-layered cyst wall.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: The type of taste evoked by monosodium glutamate is sensed via which type of receptor?
questions.solution:
The type of taste evoked by monosodium glutamate is Umami. Umami tastes are sensed by the activation of G-protein coupled receptors.

Taste Receptors: Humans have five established basic tastes: sweet, salt, sour, bitter, and umami. The taste receptors for these five basic tastes are of two major types:

  • Ligand-gated channels (ionotropic receptors): Salt and sour taste are mediated through epithelial sodium channels (ENaC)
    • Na+ movement through ENaC →salt taste
    • H+ movement through ENaC → sour taste
  • G-Protein Coupled Receptors (metabotropic receptors): Sweet, bitter, and umami are sensed via GPCRs
    • T1R2, T1R3 families→ sweet taste
    • T2R family → bitter taste
    • Metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR4) or T1R1, T1R3 families → Umami

L-glutamate was identified as having a unique taste, that cannot be categorized as bitter, sweet, salty, and sour. Therefore, it was called umami, with the Japanese word "umai" meaning "delicious". Ribonucleotides such as inosine 5′-monophosphate (IMP) and guanosine-5'-monophosphate (GMP), elicit umami taste on their own. It wasn't until the identification of G protein-coupled receptors specific for glutamate taste, that umami was completely accepted as a unique taste.

Related Pearl: Taste sensations and their mediators

Taste Sensations Mediated by
Salt Na+ movement in ENaC
Sweet G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) T1R family
Umami Glutamate receptor family (mGluR4) and G-protein coulped receptors (GPCRs) T1R family
Bitter G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) T2R family
Sour H+ movement through ENaC

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with symptoms of fatigue and headache. On further examination, he is found to have pallor, tingling, and numbness over his extremities. Peripheral smear shows macrocytic anemia. Laboratory findings revealed methylmalonic acid excretion in the urine. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 15 years ago and has been taking metformin. Which of the following is most likely deficient in him?
questions.solution:
A vitamin B12/ cobalamin deficiency is most likely seen in him.

The given clinical features of peripheral neuropathy, peripheral smear finding of macrocytic anemia with hypersegmented neutrophils, methylmalonic acid excretion in the urine, and history of metformin intake after being diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus indicate a vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 or cobalamin is a water-soluble vitamin that is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Its absorption in the terminal ileum is facilitated by the presence of intrinsic factor, produced by parietal cells in the stomach. There are two vitamin B12-dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (homocysteine methyltransferase): Catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine.
  • Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: methylmalonyl CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine, and propionyl CoA is converted to succinyl CoA.

The activity of methylmalonyl CoA mutase is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonic acid and its excretion in urine. Since vitamin B12 is also linked to the regeneration of methionine from homocysteine, its deficiency can result in hyperhomocysteinemia as well.

Risk factors for B12 deficiency include gastric atrophy (pernicious anemia), terminal ileal disease, strict vegetarianism, acid-reducing drugs (e.g., H2 blockers), and prolonged use of metformin. The interference by metformin on calcium-dependent membrane action is responsible for vitamin B12-intrinsic factor malabsorption in the terminal ileum.

On examination, patients present anemia, fatigue, and pallor symptoms. Other presenting complaints may include peripheral neuropathy, glossitis, diarrhea, headaches, neuropsychiatric disturbances like dementia, and subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord (SACD) leading to ataxia. A peripheral smear shows macrocytic anemia and hypersegmented neutrophils.

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin B9 (Folic acid) deficiency can also be seen in patients on prolonged use of metformin and can cause macrocytic anemia. Urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid differentiates between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency. Folate deficiency results in:

  • Megaloblastic anemia 
  • Homocystenemia
  • Neural tube defects (spina bifida, Anencephaly) in the fetus.

Option C: A patient with pyridoxine/ Vitamin B6 deficiency presents with symptoms of seborrhea, glossitis, convulsions, neuropathy, depression, confusion, and microcytic anemia.

Option D: A patient with thiamine/ Vitamin B1 deficiency presents either dry Beriberi with predominantly neurological symptoms like neuropathy, muscle weakness and wasting or wet Beriberi with predominant cardiac symptoms like cardiomegaly, tachycardia, high output congestive cardiac failure.

questions.text: A 2-week-old neonate is being evaluated for failure to thrive, excessive vomiting, abdominal distention, and steatorrhea.  Abdominal CT reveals hepatosplenomegaly and calcified adrenals bilaterally. Further investigation reveals a deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid lipase (LAL). Which of the following is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly, intractable vomiting, steatorrhea, and bilateral adrenal calcification points towards a probable diagnosis of Wolman disease.

Wolman disease is a rare disorder that results from a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase (LAL). This leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in most of the visceral organs, leading to organomegaly as in this case. Patients present in the first few weeks of life with failure to thrive, vomiting, abdominal distention, steatorrhea, hepatosplenomegaly, and hyperlipidemia with extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands.

LAL deficiency can present in two forms- Wolman disease and cholesterol ester storage disease. Cholesterol ester storage disease is less severe and usually presents late in adulthood, whereas Wolman disease presents within the first few weeks of life and results in death within the first 6 months of life. 

Wolman disease can be diagnosed by measuring LAL activity in peripheral leukocytes or cultured skin fibroblasts. Treatment is with a recombinant form of LAL. Those treated have been seen to survive beyond one year of age.

Other options-

Option (A): Krabbe disease is also a fatal disease of early infancy but it occurs due to a deficiency in the enzyme galactocerebrosidase and hence, the accumulation of galactosylceramide in the white matter of the brain.

Option (B): Farber disease results from a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme acid ceramidase. Thus, ceramide accumulates in various tissues, especially the joints. Symptoms include painful joint swelling and nodule formation, resembling rheumatoid arthritis within the first year of life.

Option (D): Gaucher disease is one of the most common lysosomal storage disorders. It occurs due to a deficiency of acid β-glucosidase. It presents most commonly with organomegaly, bone pain, and pathological fractures. It is most prevalent among Ashkenazi Jews.

questions.text: A gynecologist is examining a 28-year-old female patient. On performing a per vaginal examination, the lowest part of the cervix that can be palpated is the anterior lip. What information does that convey about the position of the uterus and cervix?

choices.text: External os is directed forwards and downwards
Uterus is flexed backwards on cervix
External os is directed backwards and downwards
Uterus is directed backwards and downwards

questions.solution:
If the examining fingers palpate the anterior lip as the lowest part of the cervix, it means that the uterus is anteverted and the external os is directed downwards and backwards.

The normal position of the uterus is antiflexed and anteverted, ie the body of the uterus is flexed forwards on the cervix and the external os is directed downwards and backwards.

In a retroverted uterus, the external os of the cervix is directed downwards and forwards. The lowest part of the cervix palpated is the posterior lip. The body of the uterus may also be flexed backwards in a retroverted uterus.

The angle of anteversion: The angle between the cervix and vagina. Normally it is 90 degrees. (Remember: V for version, V for vagina)

The angle of anteflexion: The angle between cervix and uterus. The angle is at the level of the internal os and is 120 degrees.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with an obstetric code of P3L3 came with complaints of heaviness in her pelvic region. The uterine prolapse was similar to the illustration given below. What is the degree of prolapse?
questions.solution:
The given condition is a second-degree uterine prolapse, where the cervix descends to the level of the vulva as seen in the image above. 

Pelvic organ prolapse is a condition where the pelvic organs herniate into the vagina due to weakness of supports. It is classified based on compartment of descent. 

It has multifactorial etiology. It is thought that combinations of anatomical, physiological, genetic, lifestyle, and reproductive factors are responsible for pelvic floor dysfunction. However, pregnancy, vaginal delivery, prior pelvic surgeries, or conditions associated with sustained episodes of increased intraabdominal pressure increase the risk of developing pelvic organ prolapse. 

Patients may be asymptomatic. Those who have symptoms may present with a feeling of a bulge protruding through the vaginal opening. It may cause bladder outlet obstruction, affect sexual activity, body image, and quality of life. 

The following image depicts the degrees of prolapse:

questions.text: What is the use of this surgical instrument?

choices.text: Dilate the punctum of lacrimal gland
Curette the lacrimal sac in cases of epiphora

questions.solution:
The given image shows Bowman's lacrimal probe.  It is identified by the ends of the lacrimal probe which are blunt with a central stable platform. It is used to probe the lacrimal sac in the management of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction. It is also used to identify the lacrimal sac during DCR and DCT.

Other common instruments used in lacrimal gland surgeries:

Nettleship's lacrimal punctum dilator (shown in the image attached below) is used to dilate the punctum before lacrimal sac surgeries (Option-C)

 

Lacrimal gland cannula is used for syringing the lacrimal gland and the passage. It is a long curved hypodermic needle with a blunt tip. (Option-A)

 

Lacrimal sac curette is used to curette the lacrimal sac in cases of epiphora (Option-D). It is a cylindrical instrument, one end of which is a blunt-tipped dissector, and the other end is curetted.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man is being evaluated for recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis. His fasting triglyceride levels were 1100 mg/dL. He mentions that his mother was diagnosed with a deficiency of lipoprotein lipase and on further investigation, he too was diagnosed with the same condition. Which of the following lipoproteins will be elevated in this patient's plasma?

VLDL- very low density lipoprotein

LDL- low density lipoprotein

HDL- high density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the presence of lipoprotein lipase deficiency indicate a diagnosis of type I hyperlipoproteinemia, where chylomicron, triglycerides and VLDL levels will be elevated.

Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, also known as familial chylomicronemia syndrome or familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency is due to lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency, abnormal LPL, or apo C-II deficiency causing inactivation of LPL. It is an autosomal recessive condition. 

These patients show slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL, low levels of LDL and HDL. 

Clinical features include hepatosplenomegaly, eruptive/ pruritic xanthomas on the back, buttocks, and extensor surfaces, and recurrent episodes of pancreatitis. On funduscopic examination, the retinal blood vessels may appear opalescent, known as lipemia retinalis. The diagnosis should be suspected if the fasting triglyceride levels are greater than 750 mg/dL.

Lipoprotein lipase is required for the hydrolysis of triglycerides into fatty acids and glycerol in circulating chylomicrons, that transport dietary lipids from the intestine to the peripheral tissues. Therefore, patients who are deficient in lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) show increased levels of chylomicrons in the plasma after a fatty meal.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: A woman at her 31st week of gestation presented to the emergency department with lower abdominal pain. The on-duty clinician is concerned if the patient is in preterm labor and asks you to arrange and collect a sample to check for fetal fibronectin. From where is the sample taken?
questions.solution:
Fetal fibronectin in cervicovaginal secretions is used as a marker for impending preterm labor before membrane rupture.

Qualitative and quantitative fetal fibronectin levels are measured using ELISA, and levels >50 ng/mL is considered positive.

Fetal fibronectin is a glycoprotein present in high concentrations in maternal blood and in amnionic fluid, however, sample contamination by amnionic fluid and mater­nal blood should be avoided.

It aids in intercellular adhesion during implantation and in the maintenance of placental adherence to uterine decidua. It reflects stromal remodeling of the cervix before labor.

Preterm labor (PTL) refers to the onset of labor before the 37th completed week, counting from the first day of the last menstrual period.

questions.text: Certain bony nodules exist within the body that are found embedded in tendons or joint capsules. Which of the following is not one of them?
questions.solution:
Certain bony nodules exist in our bodies that are found embedded within tendons or joint capsules. These are called sesamoid bones. The clavicle is not a sesamoid bone.

The clavicle is classified as a long bone, and it is not found within a tendon or joint capsule.

Sesamoid bones are those which have no periosteum and ossify after birth. They get lubrication from the synovial membrane or bursa in which they are present.

The main functions of sesamoid bones include- resisting pressure, reducing friction, changing the direction of muscle pull, and improving circulation locally. 

Examples of a sesamoid bones are:

  • Pisiform bone- It is embedded in the tendon of the flexor carpi ulnaris.
  • Patella- This is the largest sesamoid bone. It is embedded in the tendon of the quadriceps femoris.
  • Fabella- It is embedded in the tendon of the lateral head of the gastrocnemius. 
  • Sesamoid bones can be found under the first metacarpal and first metatarsal.

questions.text: A woman who adopted a cat during her current pregnancy delivers a baby. The baby had features of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications. Transplacental transmission is suspected. If she had been diagnosed early, what drug could have been administered to her to reduce the severity of the baby's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Spiramycin could have been administered to her during pregnancy to reduce the severity of the baby's symptoms. 

Toxoplasmosis refers to the infectious disease caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondi. It comes under TORCH infections which consist of toxoplasmosis, others (syphilis, hepatitis B), rubella, cytomegalovirus, and herpes simplex.  It can be transmitted to humans by:

  • Ingestion of raw or inadequately cooked infected meat
  • Ingestion of oocysts through exposure to cat litter or soil
  • A newly infected pregnant woman passing the infection to her unborn fetus
  • Blood transfusion or organ transplantation 

Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs when a pregnant woman acquires the infection during gestation. The organism may cross to the fetus transplacentally or at the time of vaginal delivery. The severity of disease in the neonate is greater if the woman gets infected early in her pregnancy.

The classical triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications can be seen in infected neonates. Other possible features include small size for gestational age, prematurity, jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hydrops fetalis, and perinatal death.

The diagnosis can be made by real-time PCR which provides quantitative results. Sabin-Feldman dye test, IgG indirect fluorescent antibody test, agglutination test, etc are the serological tests used.

 Pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine are also used in the treatment.  

Other options-

Option (A) and (B): Valganciclovir and Ganciclovir are therapeutic agents used to treat cytomegalovirus infections.

Option (D): Doxycycline is not used to treat toxoplasmosis.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding glucose transporters:

choices.text: GLUT2 is involved in transport of glucose out of enterocytes
SGLT1 is involved in absorption of glucose into the enterocytes
GLUT 4 is involved in the transport of fructose in the sperms
GLUT 2 acts as a beta cell glucose sensor in the islet cells

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is option C. 

The transport of fructose in sperms is carried out by GLUT 5, not GLUT 4.

GLUT-5 is present in the small intestine, mature spermatids, kidneys, and brain. It is exclusively involved in the transport of fructose, with no ability to transport glucose or galactose. 

GLUT 4 is involved in insulin-stimulated glucose uptake in skeletal, cardiac, and adipose tissue. 

Other options:

Options A and D: GLUT2 acts as a beta cell glucose sensor in the islet cells of the pancreas and is also involved in the transport of glucose from the enterocyte into the interstitium or out of the enterocytes.

Option B: SGLT1 is involved in the absorption of glucose into the enterocyte. SGLT2 is responsible for glucose transport out of the renal tubules.

questions.text: A  primigravida was brought to the emergency department with the sudden onset of fever, altered mental status, confusion, and petechiae over both lower limbs. She has no history of similar episodes. Laboratory reports revealed thrombocytopenia, anaemia, features of acute kidney injury, and antibodies to ADAMTS13. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a primigravida who presents with sudden onset of fever, neurologic abnormalities(altered mental status, confusion), thrombocytopenia (petechiae over lower limbs), hemolytic anaemia, acute kidney injury and antibodies to  ADAMTS13 suggests the diagnosis of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).  

TTP is a thrombotic microangiopathy that can be inherited or spontaneously acquired. It results from a deficiency of, or antibodies to, the metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which normally cleaves multimers of vWF. Failure to cleave these multimers results in abnormally large vWF multimers which activate platelets and lead to excessive platelet adhesion and aggregation. This causes platelet thrombi to form, and fibrin deposits to take place at various sites. These thrombi result in the classic pentad of clinical features: 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal failure
  • Neurologic findings
  • Fever

The platelet thrombi narrow the vessel lumen, causing shearing stress on the red blood cells that are passing through. This results in microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia. The same platelet thrombi cause microvascular occlusion and result in features like renal failure and neurological manifestations.

On peripheral smear, these fragmented red cells appear as schistocytes or helmet cells, as shown in the image below:

 

Timely diagnosis is important to prevent devastating outcomes like profuse bleeding and renal failure. The best method to treat these patients is using plasma exchange therapy. It should be continued until the platelet counts are back to normal and there are no signs of hemolysis for at least 2 days. Glucocorticoids can also be used along with this therapy. In refractory cases, rituximab, and caplacizumab an antiVWF nanobody decreases mortality when used in patients with ADAMTS13 <10%.

Other causes of microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia include:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) (Most common)
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)
  • Malignant hypertension
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Disseminated cancer 

Other options-

Option (A): Immune thrombocytopenic purpura occurs as a chronic disease in adults with several episodes over time, usually following infections. It presents as mucocutaneous bleeding and very low platelet counts. These patients have otherwise normal peripheral blood pictures.

Option (B): Disseminated intravascular coagulation refers to the widespread intravascular clot formation, commonly due to sepsis, trauma, and obstetric complications. These patients present with petechiae, ecchymoses, oozing from venipuncture sites, etc. They do not display the classic pentad seen in TTP. Schistocytes may be present on peripheral smear. Deranged clotting parameters are seen only in DIC and not in TTP.

Option (C): Hemolytic uremic syndrome is a disorder seen predominantly in children, following an episode of bloody diarrhea. Escherichia coli O157:H7 is most commonly the cause of this diarrhea. It can also present with acute renal failure, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia, but neurological manifestations are less common. ADAMTS13 levels are normal in a majority of patients. It can be low in some rare cases.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has been brought to the physician following a drop in school performance, personality changes, and behavioral difficulties. After thorough investigations, he is diagnosed with metachromatic leukodystrophy. The accumulation of which of the following lipids is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The accumulation of sulfogalactocerebroside is seen in metachromatic leukodystrophy. 

Metachromatic leukodystrophy is a lysosomal storage disease caused due to deficiency of the enzyme arylsulfatase A. It follows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. It is a serious condition and causes death within 5-6 years in early-onset form.

Clinical manifestations of the diseases can be categorized by the age of disease onset:

Late infantile-onset: Occurs in children < 30 months of age. Typically, early milestones are met, followed by a progressive regression of motor skills, ataxia, dysarthria, hypotonia, spasticity, hypotonia, hyporeflexia, extensor plantar posturing, and optic atrophy. Accounts for a majority of the cases.
 
Juvenile onset: Occurs between 30 months and puberty. Early milestones are met, followed by psychomotor regression, intellectual decline in the form of dropped school performance, behavioral difficulties, and personality changes.
 
Adult-onset: This type shows neurocognitive and neuropsychiatric difficulties. Patients may have dysesthesias like peripheral neuropathy, psychosis, schizophrenia, or seizures. 

Other options

Option A: Galactosylceramide accumulation occurs in Krabbe’s leukodystrophy.

Option C: Sphingomyelin accumulation occurs in Neimann-Pick disease

Option D: Globoside accumulation occurs in Sandhoff's disease.
