questions.text: A patient presents with odynophagia and trismus. Examination of the oral cavity reveals that the floor of the mouth is swollen and the tongue is pushed up and back. The submental area is tender with a woody-hard feel. Which of the following is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above patient with odynophagia, trismus, swollen floor of the mouth with a woody-hard feel, and the tongue being pushed up and back is likely to have Ludwig's angina. The most common cause of Ludwig's angina is dental infections. 

Ludwig's angina is the infection of the floor of the mouth. The submandibular space is present between the mucus membrane of the floor of the mouth and tongue on one side and the superficial layer of deep cervical fascia that extends between the hyoid bone and the mandible on the other side. The mylohyoid muscle divides this space into the sublingual space (above the mylohyoid) and the submaxillary and submental compartment (below the mylohyoid). 

Dental infections account for 80-90% of cases of Ludwig's angina. Infections of the premolars can spread to sublingual space, while infections of molar teeth can spread to the submaxillary space. The infections are usually polymicrobial. Alpha-hemolytic streptococci, staphylococci, and Bacteroides groups are commonly associated.

Patients present with difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) and trismus. Examination of the oral cavity will reveal that the floor of the mouth is swollen and the tongue is pushed up and back. The submental and submandibular space becomes swollen, tender, and has a woody-hard feel. Severe infection can lead to a threatened airway due to displacement of the tongue. 

It is treated by systemic antibiotics, incision and drainage of the abscess, and tracheostomy if the airway is threatened. 

Complications of this condition include the spread of infection to the parapharyngeal space, retropharyngeal space, and the mediastinum, airway obstruction, septicemia, and aspiration pneumonia. 

Below image shows Ludwig's angina

Other options: 

Option A: Acute tonsilitis can lead to peritonsillar abscess (quinsy). It is characterized by severe throat pain, fever with chills and rigors, odynophagia, hot potato voice, and foul breath. The examination will reveal edema of tonsils, tonsillar pillars, soft palate, and uvula. The tonsils might not be visible due to edema of the tonsillar pillars. The uvula is pushed to the opposite side.

Option B: Submandibular sialadenitis is a less common cause of Ludwig's angina. 

Option D: Mycobacterium tuberculosis causes a chronic retropharyngeal abscess. It presents with dysphagia, fluctuating swelling in the posterior pharyngeal wall, and cervical lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A young man presented with right-sided chest pain and paradoxical respiration after he fell off a tree. The chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following should be avoided in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray showing contiguous rib fractures on the right side suggest flail chest. Chest strapping or splinting should be avoided in the management of a flail chest. Mechanically impairing the chest wall movements along with the underlying lung contusions contribute to hypoxia.

A flail chest occurs when 3 or more ribs are fractured in 2 or more places usually due to blunt trauma. It can increase the risk of developing pneumothorax and hemothorax.

Diagnosis is made clinically by observing the paradoxical motion of the chest wall segment during respiration (paradoxical respiration). On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall gets displaced inwards and moves outwards on expiration. The gold standard investigation is a CT scan with contrast, with a 3-D reconstruction of the chest wall, displaying the vascular structures.

Treatment consists of oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates), epidural analgesia, and physiotherapy. Mechanical ventilation is recommended to treat respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen.

The chest X-ray shows contiguous rib fractures on the right side of the chest:

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Score Severity of injury

questions.text: After a structural collapse in a nearby factory, several factory workers arrive at your emergency department. One of them presents with the findings as shown below in the image. Which color code will you triage him under?
questions.solution:
The image in the question shows a degloving injury which should be classified under the yellow color.

Triage is done to categorize the need for priority of patients in cases of mass casualties. The aim of triage is the identity patients who would benefit the most by being treated earlier.

Priority Colour Medical need Clinical status Examples
First (I) Red Immediate Critical, but likely to survive if treated early
  • Severe facial trauma
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Profuse external bleeding
  • Hemothorax
  • Flail chest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed
  • Extradural hematomas
Second (II) Yellow Urgent Critical, likely to survive treated  within hours
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Ruptured abdominal viscus
  • Pelvic fractures
  • Spinal injuries
Third (III) Green Non-urgent Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed hours- days
  • Simple fractures
  • sprains
  • Minor lacerations
Last (0) Black Unsalvageable Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help
  • Severe brain damage
  • Very extensive burns
  • Major disruption/loss of chest or abdominal wall structures

 

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text:
A child presented with impaired cognitive function. Detailed history and observation revealed multiple types of seizures and his EEG showed slow (<3Hz) spike and wave discharges. A diagnosed of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome was arrived at. Which among the following options is a first-line drug for his condition?

EEG: Electroencephalogram
questions.solution:
Sodium valproate is a first-line drug for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.

Valproate is an broad spectrum antiseziure drug. It is used in:

  • Partial seizures
  • Generalised tonic-clonic seziures (GTCS)
  • Absence seziures
  • Myoclonic seziures 
  • Atonic seziures

Valproate act via multiple mechanisms like:

  • Prolonged sodium channel inactivation
  • Attenuation of calcium-mediated 'T' current 
  • Enhanced release of  inhibitory transmitter GABA due to inhibition of its degradation and increasing its synthesis from glutamic acid
  • Inhibition of excitatory NMDA glutamate receptors

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is a rare severe form of childhood epilepsy. It is characterized by a triad of:

  • Multiple types of seizures including GTCS, atonic, myoclonic, atypical absence seizures
  • <3Hz spike and wave pattern in EEG
  • Impaired cognitive function

They are predominantly seen in early childhood between the age group of 1 to 7 years peaking at around 3 years of age. Intellectual impairment in the form of developmental delay starts usually after the occurrence of seizures.

An EEG of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is given below:

Other options:

Option A- Zonisamide is an antiepileptic drug used as adjuvant therapy of focal seizures in adults. It can also be used as an add-on in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. 

Option B: Levetiracetam is also effective in most of the seizures present in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, but is not a first-line drug for this condition.

Option D: Vigabatrin is also effective in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, but is not a first-line drug for this condition.

 

Related Pearl: Important Adverse Effects of Anti-epileptic Drugs

Antiepileptic drugs

Adverse effects
Carbamazepine Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), diplopia, ataxia, hyponatremia
Phenytoin Gum hyperplasia, hirsutism, osteomalacia, ataxia
Valproic acid Hepatotoxicity, thrombocytopenia, transient alopecia, tremors, pancreatitis
Phenobarbital Sedation, depression, ataxia, automatism
Vigabatrin Loss of peripheral vision
Felbamate Fulminant hepatic failure, aplastic anemia
Lamotrigine Hypersensitivity reactions, SJS
Topiramate Paresthesias, renal calculi, weight loss, acute glaucoma
Oxcarbazepine Hyponatremia, SJS
Ezogabine Urinary retention
Zonisamide Renal calculi
Perampanel Homicidal ideation

questions.text: A  hosteller developed papules with excoriation in the interdigital web spaces, groin, and under-surface of the breasts. She tells that lesions are intensely pruritic at night and her roommate has similar complaints. Identify the wrong statement about the vector causing this condition, shown in the image below.

choices.text: Life cycle of  the vector has 4 stages
Male parasite burrows into the epidermis
The entire life cycle takes about 15 days

questions.solution:
The clinical background is probably suggestive of scabies. The given image depicts an itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei. The incorrect statement is that the male parasite burrows into the epidermis.

The female parasite burrows into the stratum corneum layer of the epidermis and lays eggs in the burrow. A single female may lay about 30 eggs at a rate of 2 to 3 per day and ultimately dies at the end of the burrow. The larval stage, which emerges from the eggs, has 3 pairs of legs. After the larvae moult, the resulting nymphs have 4 pairs of legs.

The life cycle has 4 stages- egg, larva, nymph, and adult. It takes about 10-15 days to progress from egg to adult. However, the adult mites live for 1 to 2 months.

Itching is a hypersensitivity reaction to the eggs and dead parasites in the epidermis. Clinical features include itching severe at night, superficial burrows in the affected site, and secondary infection of the lesions leading to crusted papules and pustules. Multiple members of a household may be affected, hence simultaneous treatment of all the household contacts is essential.

 

The diagnosis is made by visualizing the parasite in skin debris under a microscope. Permethrin cream - 5% is the treatment of choice.

Related Pearl: Difference between classic and neonatal scabies

  Classic scabies Neonatal scabies
Site of involvement Interdigital webs, trunk, genitals, flexors, sparing of palms and soles, and skin above neck Face, scalp, palm, and soles
Morphology of Lesion Papules, pustules, excoriation, eczematization, burrow Vesicles, pustules, bullae, erosions, and ulcerations
Burrows Present Usually absent

questions.text: The smallest unit of antigenicity is called
questions.solution:
The smallest unit of antigenicity is called the epitope or antigenic determinant. An epitope is defined as a small area present on the antigen that is capable of sensitizing immunocytes and reacting with a specific site of a T-cell receptor or an antibody.

A paratope (option B)is the specific site of an antibody that reacts with the corresponding epitope of an antigen.

Haptens are low molecular weight molecules that lack immunogenicity (cannot induce an immune response) themselves. They can become immunogenic by combining with a large molecule carrier. Haptens are classified as:

  • Complex haptens (option D): They contain two or more epitopes and can precipitate with specific antibodies.
  • Simple haptens (option C): They contain only one epitope. They bind to antibodies but are not precipitating.

questions.text: You decide to prescribe a drug that binds with proliferative-activated receptor alpha (PPARα) to a patient with type III hyperlipoproteinemia. Which of the following drugs can be given?
questions.solution:
Among the given drugs, fibrates bind to proliferative-activated receptor alpha (PPARα) leading to their activation. 

Activation of PPARα enhances the synthesis of lipoprotein lipase which is the key enzyme in the degradation of VLDL. This results in lowering the circulating triglycerides. PPARα also enhances fatty acid oxidation and mediates LDL receptor expression in the liver. 

Fibrates are considered the drug of choice for treating severe hypertriglyceridemia and chylomicronemia syndrome. 

Other options:

Option A- Statin inhibits HMG-COA reductase which is the rate-limiting step in cholesterol synthesis. 

Option B- Niacin or nicotinic acid inhibits intracellular lipolysis of triglycerides by hormone-sensitive lipases. This causes a reduction in the transport of free fatty acid to the liver and decreases hepatic triglyceride synthesis. 

Option D- Ezetimibe acts by inhibiting intestinal cholesterol absorption by jejunal enterocytes. It inhibits the transport protein NPC1L1.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with primary hyperoxaluria is most likely to have a deficiency of which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
A patient diagnosed with primary hyperoxaluria is most likely to have a glycine deficiency.

Primary hyperoxalurias are a group of inborn errors of metabolism characterized by oxalate overproduction, with an autosomal recessive inheritance. There are 3 types of primary hyperoxalurias, of which primary hyperoxaluria type 1 (PH1) is the most common form.

The defect in PH1 is the deficiency of the alanine-glyoxylate aminotransferase in liver peroxisomes. This causes failure to catabolize glyoxylate to glycine. Glyoxylate is instead converted to oxalate, with consequent calcium oxalate stone formation and crystal deposition in various organs like the kidney. 

Age at onset of symptoms ranges from infancy to the sixth decade, with the median age being 4–6 years. Presenting symptoms include hematuria, dysuria, pain, urinary tract infection, or stone passage. In severe, early-onset disease, there is nephrocalcinosis with or without nephrolithiasis and failure to thrive related to renal failure.

A urinalysis shows elevated urinary oxalate and elevated urinary glycolic acid. There is also an elevated level of plasma oxalate. Renal ultrasound may show multiple bilateral radiopaque calculi. 

The FDA recently approved lumasiran, an RNA interference therapeutic agent targeting glycolate oxidase, as the first treatment option for PH1, a rare genetic disorder.

questions.text: A gross specimen of the colon obtained from a 14-year-old boy is shown below. Which of the following statements is false about this pathology?

choices.text: It occurs as a result of a defect in the DNA mismatch repair mechanism.
At least 100 polyps are needed to make the diagnosis.
Prophylactic colectomy is done for patients with APC mutations.
It is associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium.

questions.solution:
The gross specimen in the image shows the presence of multiple polyps in the colon, along with an area suspicious of colorectal carcinoma. Multiple polyps in the colon of a 14-year-old boy make familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) the likely diagnosis.

FAP is an autosomal dominant disorder that is caused by mutations of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene and not due to defects in the DNA repair mechanism. Defects in DNA mismatch repair genes result in hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer, MYH-associated polyposis, and some sporadic colon cancers.

Familial adenomatous polyposis, as the name suggests, is an inherited disorder presenting with numerous colorectal adenomatous polyps. It is an autosomal dominant disease caused by mutations in the APC gene, which is a regulator in the Wnt signaling pathway. At least 100 polyps are required to make a diagnosis of FAP. 

Patients are usually teenagers and multiple polyps are visible in the colon during sigmoidoscopy. It is associated with a variety of extraintestinal manifestations including congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigmental epithelium. Colorectal adenocarcinoma occurs in almost all cases before the age of 50. 

Prophylactic colectomy is recommended in patients with APC gene mutations. The surgeries used are colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA), restorative proctocolectomy with an ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (RPC), or total proctectomy and end ileostomy. The first 2 surgeries are preferred in young patients as it avoids a permanent stoma. 

Note- FAP along with brain tumors is called Turcot syndrome. FAP along with multiple osteomas, skin, and soft tissue tumors is called Gardner syndrome.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: A 42-year-old man had a fall followed by one episode of vomiting. When brought to the casualty, he was awake and conscious but had unrelieved anterograde amnesia. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given history of fall and anterograde amnesia points towards the diagnosis of concussion. 

A concussion is the most common type of traumatic brain injury. It can result from vehicle accidents, falls, sports injuries, etc. Anterograde amnesia/post-traumatic amnesia is the hallmark of a concussion. In this type of amnesia, the events following the injury cannot be recalled. 

Other clinical features of concussion include headache, dizziness, nausea, and vomiting.

Option A: Drunkenness - the patient will be drowsy or sleepy and not awake.

Option B: Diffuse axonal injury - seen in high-speed deceleration which causes disruption and shearing of axons leading to microhemorrhages. Usually results in a persistent vegetative stage.

Option D: Cerebral venous thrombosis - acute thrombosis in dural venous sinuses; manifests as headache, visual abnormalities, or seizures.

questions.text: A baby having a continuous murmur was sent for cardiac evaluation.  2-D echocardiography showed a connection from the aorta to the main pulmonary artery and color doppler imaging revealed left to right shunting from the aorta into the main pulmonary artery. Which among the following syndromes is not likely to be associated with this cardiac condition?
questions.solution:
Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), the most likely diagnosis in this scenario is not usually associated with Marfan's Syndrome. Marfan's syndrome is associated with aortic aneurysms and mitral valve disease.

Conditions commonly associated with a patent ductus arteriosus are:

  • Edward's syndrome (Trisomy 18- Atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, valve abnormalities)
  • Patau's syndrome (Trisomy 13- Atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, valve abnormalities)
  • Cri du chat (deletion of chromosome 5p15.2- Atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, Tetrology of Fallot)
  • Noonan's syndrome (Pulmonic stenosis, atrial septal defect, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy)
  • Char syndrome (craniofacial, limb defects, PDA)
  • Congenital Rubella syndrome

PDA is an abnormal communication between the pulmonary artery and the aorta. The ductus arteriosus attaches to the aorta just distal to the left subclavian artery. It closes functionally and anatomically soon after birth. Its persistence causes left to right shunt and is known is called PDA. 

On examination, there are prominent carotid pulsations, hyperkinetic cardiac impulse, palpable systolic or a continuous thrill at the second left intercostal space with continuous machinery murmur.

On chest x-ray, patients with a large PDA show a prominent pulmonary artery with increased pulmonary vascular markings. On an echocardiogram, the ductus can be visualized directly and its size can be estimated. Color and pulsed Doppler examinations demonstrate rleft to right or bidrectional shunting. 

Treatment is by medical closure with indomethacin or by surgical closure of the ductus. 

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

Related Pearl: Classification of congenital heart disease

Acyanotic
Cyanotic (5TE²VP)
Left to right shunts:

Ventricular septal defect (VSD)

Atrial septal defect (ASD)

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

Obstructive lesions:

Coarctation of aorta

Infundibular stenosis

Pulmonary valve stenosis

Congenital mitral & tricuspid regurgitation
Right to left shunt:

Persistent Truncus arteriosus

Transposition of great vessels

Tricuspid atresia

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy was brought to your clinic by his worried mother. He had been suspended twice from his school for bullying, assaulting his classmates and stealing from them. He would sometimes stay out all night despite his parents telling him not to, and he was recently warned by the local police for vandalism. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 13-year-old boy with a history of aggression towards people within the past 6 months, destruction of property, and theft for the last couple of years points towards a diagnosis of conduct disorder. If it persists beyond 18 years of age it is referred to as anti-social personality disorder.

Conduct disorder is diagnosed when at least 3 behaviors have been present within the previous 12 months, with at least 1 present in the past 6 months.

Conduct disorder can be classified based on onset as:

  • Childhood-onset type: Individuals show at least one symptom characteristic of conduct disorder before the age of 10 years.
  • Adolescent-onset type: Individuals do not show features of conduct disorder before the age of 10 years.
  • Unspecified onset: Criteria for a diagnosis of conduct disorder are met, but there is not enough information available to determine whether the onset of the first symptom was before or after the age of 10 years.
DSM-5 criteria for Conduct Disorder 
Aggression towards people and animals

Initiating physical fights, bullying, threatening, or intimidating others

Using a weapon to cause serious harm to others

Being physically cruel to people

Being physically cruel to animals

Stealing while confronting a victim

Forcing someone into sexual activity
Destruction of property

Setting fires

Intentionally destroying the property of others
Serious violation of rules

Running away overnight at least twice or once without returning for a lengthy period.

Being truant from school often starting before age 13.

Frequently staying out at night despite parental prohibitions starting before age 13
Deceitfulness or theft

Frequently lying to obtain goods or favors

Breaking into a car or building

Stealing items of nontrivial value without confronting a victim

Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD):

  • A persistent pattern of negativistic, hostile, and defiant attitude/behavior towards adults.
  • Seen in children less than 10 years of age.
  • The symptoms must be present at least 6 months, during which 4 or more of the following have to be present:
    • Argues with others
    • Loses temper
    • Blames others
    • Easily annoyed
    • Refuses and defies to listening to adults
    • Annoys other people quite often

Unlike conduct disorder, children with ODD do not indulge in destructive and physically harmful activities.

Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder: Onset before age 10. Severe, recurrent temper outbursts out of proportion to the situation. Child is constantly angry and irritable between outbreks.

questions.text: You are promoted to the position of district medical officer. While getting oriented, you learn that your district recorded an Annual parasite index (API) of 1.7 in the year 2015. Which category does your district fall under according to the National Strategic Plan for Malaria (2017-2022)?
questions.solution:
The National Strategic Plan for Malaria classifies the districts under Category 2 of the NVBDCP as districts/units having API one and above but less than two per 1000 population. These districts are said to be under the pre-elimination phase.

The goal of the National Strategic Plan for Malaria for Category 2 districts is to completely eliminate malaria by the year 2022.

Category Definition API
Category 0 Prevention of re-establishment phase No incidence in last 3 years
Category 1 Elimination phase < 1 per 1000 population
Category 2 Pre elimination phase 1-2 per 1000 population
Category 3 Intensified control phase > 2 per 1000 population

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is undergoing evaluation for premature cataracts, thinning of skin, alopecia, osteoporosis, and atherosclerosis. She is found to have a hereditary genetic mutation in the WRN gene. This gene encodes which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of Werner syndrome, a premature aging disorder. The mutated gene encodes a DNA helicase. 

Werner syndrome is an autosomal recessive disease caused by mutations in the WRN gene. This gene encodes a protein with multiple DNA-dependent enzymatic functions including:

  • ATPase
  • Helicase
  • Exonuclease

DNA helicase is involved in DNA replication and repair. A defect in this enzyme causes rapid accumulation of damaged chromosomes that may mimic the injury that normally accumulates during cellular aging. Affected persons show various manifestations of premature aging including:  

  • Atherosclerosis
  • Senile cataract
  • Skin atrophy
  • Alopecia
  • Osteoporosis

They are also at risk for the development of a variety of cancers. Patients typically die in the 5th decade from either cancer or cardiovascular disease.

Defective DNA Mismatch Repair (MMR)

Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

questions.text: An elderly man presents with weakness in his right arm and leg for the past 3 hours with a deviation of mouth to the left side. Non-contrast CT is normal. Which of the following medications is not useful in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset hemiparesis and facial palsy with apparently normal CT points to ischemic stroke in this patient. Tranexamic acid is not useful for managing this patient with ischemic stroke as it is an anti-fibrinolytic agent used to arrest bleeding and it can cause thromboembolic events. 

Non-contrast CT is the imaging modality of choice in patients with acute stroke. CT may appear normal for the first few hours and the infarct may not appear until 24-48 hours. Diffusion-weighted MRI is more sensitive to detect early brain infarction. 

Initial treatment of acute ischemic stroke includes maintaining the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation. Complications such as hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, or fever should be treated if present.

Serum glucose should be maintained between 60 mg/dL and 180 mg/dL. Reduction of blood pressure is suggested if >220/120 mmHg, presence of malignant hypertension or concomitant myocardial ischemia, or if blood pressure is >185/110 mmHg in a patient planned for intravenous thrombolysis.

Intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA), alteplase (dose 0.9 mg/kg ) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. 

Oral aspirin is recommended for the acute treatment of ischemic stroke.

IV Mannitol by raising the serum osmolarity is used to prevent the development of cerebral edema.

Endovascular mechanical thrombectomy is done in patients who do not respond to thrombolytic therapy or in whom thrombolysis is contraindicated.

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: The X-ray of a 14-year-old boy shows the presence of a well outlined, centrally located lytic lesion as shown below. A diagnosis of a unicameral bone cyst was made. Identify the false statement about this lesion.

choices.text: Commonly affects males in the second decade of life
Ilium and calcaneus are more commonly affected in adults
The presence of clear fluid confirms the diagnosis
Fallen fragment  sign seen when associated with fractures

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding a unicameral or simple bone cyst is the presence of clear fluid confirms the diagnosis. The diagnosis of a simple bone cyst is confirmed with the help of imaging and not by aspiration of the fluid. Plain radiographs are used the majority of the time. If required, MRI and CT can be used to further evaluate the cyst.

A simple bone cyst usually affects males within the first two decades of life and most commonly affects the proximal femur and humerus. In adults, the ilium and calcaneus are more commonly affected. They are asymptomatic and are an incidental finding unless a pathological fracture has occurred, in which case, mild pain and swelling are present.

An X-ray of the cyst shows the presence of a well outlined, centrally placed lytic lesion. The presence of a "fallen fragment" sign is indicative of a fracture of the cyst and occurs due to a fragment of the cortex falling into the base of the lesion.

 

Management of simple bone cyst:

  • Small, asymptomatic lesions are managed by routine observation with plain radiographs, as these lesions regress following skeletal maturity
  • Larger lesions (at risk of pathologic fracture) and symptomatic lesions - 
    • Curettage 
    • Aspiration and injection using:
      • Corticosteroids
      • Bone marrow aspirate
      • Demineralized bone matrix
  • Pathological fractures -
    • Upper limb: managed conservatively as the fracture may initiate cyst healing
    • Lower limb: curettage, bone grafting, and internal fixation

questions.text: During your internship, you observe a resident doctor examining the thyroid gland using the method shown in the video below. Identify the method.
questions.solution:
The above video shows Crile's method of thyroid palpation.

Crile's Method: The patient is asked to swallow while palpating the gland with the thumb. This method helps to identify mild enlargements and for detecting the presence of nodules.

Other options:

Option B: Lahey's Method: The lobes are pushed to one side for palpation. For palpating the left lobe, the examiner should push the lobe laterally with the left hand and the lobe is palpated with the right hand.

 

Option C: Kocher's method: It is done to demonstrate the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx. Lateral compression will result in stridor.

Option D: Pizillo's method: In short-necked and obese individuals the thyroid can be better inspected by asking the patient to place his hands behind the occiput of his/her head.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl who is a known case of sickle cell anemia presented to the emergency department with severe bone pain. An abdominal CT scan shows evidence of splenic infarcts. Which of the following renal diseases is a direct complication of this patient’s vasoocclusive disease?
questions.solution:
Renal papillary necrosis can occur as a complication of sickle cell disease.

Patients with sickle cell anemia may develop episodic painful crises. The rigidity of sickled erythrocytes results in obstruction of the microcirculation, with subsequent hypoxia and ischemic injury in many organs.

Sickle cell nephropathy is various clinical significant abnormalities due to alterations in renal morphology and function due to sickle cell disease. Hematuria and diminished concentrating ability (hyposthenuria) are the most common abnormalities seen in sickle cell nephropathy. 

It occurs due to the accelerated sickling in the hypertonic hypoxic background of the renal medulla. The hyperosmolarity dehydrates red cells and increases intracellular sickle hemoglobin (HbS) concentrations.  This leads to infarcts in the medulla and papillae and causes renal papillary necrosis. 

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. It occurs when negatively charged glutamine is replaced by a neutral valine at the sixth position of the beta-globin chain. This causes deoxygenated hemoglobin to self-associate into long polymers that sickle the red cell.

Vaso-occlusive crises are episodes of hypoxic injury and infraction that causes severe pain in the affected region in sickle cell anemia. Bones, lungs, liver, brain, spleen, penis are the most commonly affected sites. 

Hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of bones of the hand and feet is a painful bones crisis that occurs in children. It is difficult to distinguish it from acute osteomyelitis. Acute chest syndrome is the vaso-occlusive type of crisis involving the lungs that typically present with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates. Priapism occurs in less than half of affected males after puberty and leads to hypoxic damage and erectile dysfunction. 

Sequestration crisis occurs in the intact spleen of children. Sickled red cells get entrapped in the spleen which leads to rapid splenomegaly and hypovolemia. Transient cessation of erythropoiesis and sudden worsening of the anemia occurs in aplastic crisis in sickle cell patients with parvovirus B19 infection.

questions.text: An elderly man came with complaints of fever, headache, myalgia, and arthralgia. He gives a history of a rat bite a few weeks back. On examination, the maculopapular rash was present in the soles and palms. The rat-bite wound was fully healed.  Which of the following is the drug of choice for his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of rat-bite fever (RBF) and the drug of choice is penicillin G.

Rat-bite fever usually presents with relapsing fever, chills, headache, myalgia, and severe migratory arthralgia after days or weeks of a rat bite followed by a maculopapular rash characteristically involving palms and soles. Bacteria responsible for rat-bite fever are Streptobacillus moniliformis and Spirllum minus. Rat-bite fever can be distinguished from acute bite wound infection by the fact that the initial wound is healed.

S. moniliformis is a pleomorphic, gram-negative, non-motile bacillus. S. minus is short motile gram-negative bacteria

The two types of rat-bite fever are:

  • Streptobacillary RBF develops 2–10 days after a rat bite, associated with sudden onset of fever, headache, and myalgia followed by petechial rash and arthritis.
  • Haverhill fever is an S. moniliformis infection due to the consumption of contaminated milk or drinking water. 
  • Spirillary RBF is similar to streptobacillary type but it is also associated with regional lymphadenopathy. It is also called Sodoku. 

Diagnosis is based on the demonstration of causative organisms in peripheral blood films. Serology can also be used for diagnosis.

Both organisms are sensitive to penicillin G and it is the drug of choice. They also respond to tetracycline. Oral penicillin or doxycycline can be used for prophylaxis

questions.text: You were posted for the forensic examination of victims of an airplane explosion, following an emergency landing.  You decide to use Gustafson's method for age estimation.  Which of the following statements is correct regarding the method?

choices.text: Root transparency is the most reliable criteria.
Age above twelve  years can be estimated.
Weight and length of the teeth are measured.
Nitrogen content of the enamel is  measured.

questions.solution:
According to Gustafson's method, root transparency is the most reliable criterion.

Gustafson's method of estimating the age of an individual is based on physiological changes in dental tissues. It is mainly useful in adults over 21 years of age (option B).

Gustafson’s criteria:

  • Attrition - Gradual wear and tear changes of the occlusal or upper surface due to mastication
  • Periodontosis -  Regression of gums and periodontal tissue surrounding the tooth, resulting in loosening of the tooth and falling
  • Secondary dentin - Deposition of dentin in the pulp cavity and gradual decrease in the size of the cavity
  • Cementum apposition - Cementum increases in thickness near the end of the root due to changes in the tooth position. Secondary cementum deposition occurs continually and slowly, forming incremental lines.
  • Root resorption -  Involves both cementum and dentin, which show characteristic sharp grooves 
  • Transparency of the root - This is the most reliable criteria. Canals in dentin get filled with minerals, and they become transparent gradually. Dentine becomes transparent due to rarefaction.

Other options:

Option C - Weight and height of the erupting teeth of a child are used to estimate the age of infants by Stack's method, not Gustafson's method.

Option D -  Chemical methods for estimation of the nitrogen content of enamel, which increases with age, are used for estimating the age beyond 25 years. It is not a part of Gustafson's criteria.

questions.text: A 30-year-old apparently healthy man developed abdominal pain at the airport. An x-ray was obtained, which is shown below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows multiple cylindrical capsules in the stomach and intestine, which are consistent with a diagnosis of body packer syndrome.

Body packers are individuals who swallow illegal drugs like heroin and cocaine with the purpose of smuggling. Usually, the drugs are carefully wrapped in latex or plastic and swallowed, to be excreted later with the help of laxatives.

Drugs are usually of similar radio-opacity as fecal material and may be difficult to detect on x-rays. CT scan may be done to aid in diagnosis.

The image below shows multiple cylindrical capsules in the stomach and intestine. 

A similar term is body stuffer syndrome, which refers to consumption or stuffing drugs in the rectum or vagina just when the person is apprehensive of being caught. Drug toxicity may be seen due to systemic absorption.

Other options:

Option A-  Bezoar formation is an indigestible mass due to the consumption of a variety of materials that were intentionally or accidentally ingested indigestible substances.

The image below shows a colonic bezoar due to the ingestion of box myrtle seeds.

Option B- Pica is eating non-nutritive, non-food substances like chalk, paper, ash, and mud over a period of at least one month in patients with iron-deficiency anemia.

Option D- Appendicolith is the accumulation of firm feces with mineral deposits. These deposits are seen incidentally in abdominal computed tomography without any signs of appendicitis. It may obstruct the appendix lumen, causing appendicitis, and is rarely found in patients with appendix inflammation.

The image below shows a CT of an appendicolith.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding nutrient artery?

choices.text: The vessels terminate in the periosteum
It supplies outer 1/3rd of the cortex
The nutrient foramen is directed away from the growing end

questions.solution:
The nutrient foramen is directed away from the growing end is the only true statement regarding nutrient artery. 

A nutrient artery enters the shaft through the nutrient foramen. It then runs through the cortex, and divides into ascending and descending branches in the medullary cavity. Each branch then divides into numerous small branches. These branches run parallel to the main artery and end in metaphysis by anastomosing with the epiphysial, metaphysial, and periosteal arteries.

The nutrient artery supplies the medullary cavity, inner two-thirds of the cortex, and metaphysis.

Nutrient foramen is directed away from the growing end of the bone. It can be remembered as "to the elbow I go and from the knee, I flee".

Blood supply of the Bone
Artery Regions supplied
Nutrient artery  Medullary cavity, inner 2/3 of the cortex, metaphysis
Metaphyseal arteries Metaphysis
Epiphyseal arteries Epiphysis and growth plate
Periosteal arteries Periosteum, outer 1/3 of the cortex

questions.text: Which of the following fungal infections can be diagnosed by using β 1-3 glucan assay?
questions.solution:
Aspergillosis can be diagnosed by β 1-3 glucan assay.

The test detects the presence of (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) which is an abundant cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi, except those which lack the glucan entirely or produce it at a minimal level like Cryptococcus neoformans, Zygomycetes like mucor species and Blastomyces dermatitidis.

It is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect beta D glucan by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes. 1,3 Beta D Glucan level of ≥80 pg/ \mL is considered a positive result. They are mainly used for invasive candidiasis, aspergillosis, and Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with increased shortness of breath. His ABG analysis is as shown. What is the most probable underlying acid-base disorder?

pH- 7.24

pCO2- 60 mmHg

pO2- 52 mmHg

HCO3- - 27 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The underlying acid-base disorder is respiratory acidosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.24 signifies acidosis.

Step 2: A plasma HCO3- is 27 mEq/L is within normal limits. This is very likely to be due to compensation as it does not reflect the direction of the pH change.

Step 3: A pCO2 of 60 mmHg along with an acidotic pH signifies respiratory acidosis. 

Step 4: The expected compensatory increase in HCO3- can be calculated using the following formula:

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 X Δ PaCO2 (as COPD is a chronic condition and the presentation of the patient is not acute)

Thus, the increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x (60-40) = 8 mEq/L

Therefore expected HCO3- is 24 + 8 = 32 mEq/L.

The actual HCO3- measured is 27 mEq/L (which is less than the expected value) indicating that there could be a component of metabolic acidosis also.

But, the predominant disorder is respiratory acidosis and thus it is the best answer.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2
